definition: Objects originally created to serve a purpose that cannot be identified at the time the object is cataloged.
Objects created to be used as toys or to carry on the activities of games, sports, gambling, or public entertainment.

Objects originally created as playthings. Toys often represent functional objects, such as toy teapots or toy ships, or living things, such as baby dolls or stuffed animals. Toys also include objects developed primarily for play, such as balls, tops, or kites. Note: Toys that are small representations of objects normally used in human activity should be given the object name "Toy."  The cataloger may also use "Model" from Other Documents or "Miniature" from Art if appropriate.  Information about what the toy represents should be recorded in a subject field; this information may be entered according to the naming conventions and object terms used throughout Nomenclature.

Objects originally created for physical activities that are often competitive. This class includes equipment used in all forms of athletic games, including individual and team sports. Sports and their specialized equipment have proliferated over the years. Object groupings in this class focus on the most popular sports while not attempting to be encyclopedic. Object terms seek to cover the forms that are most familiar and most likely to be part of museum collections. If a specific term is not listed, consider using the broader "Gear" term. Terms covering practice, warm-up, and exercise equipment can be found in Recreational Devices. Note: The word “Gear,” employed in many of the primary object terms below, suggests a plural connotation even though Nomenclature object terms are in the singular.  The use of “Gear” as an object term (rather than as a sub-class) provides the cataloger with terms that allow the indexing of an unlisted object or an object whose term is listed elsewhere with its associated sport.

Objects originally created for participatory, usually non-competitive, recreational activities other than athletic games. This class includes equipment for entertainment, such as a carousel, a pinball machine, a swing, or a slide, whether such equipment is publicly or privately owned and whether or not a charge is associated with its use.
Objects originally created for the presentation of non-competitive spectator entertainment.

Objects originally created for competitive activities based on chance, problem-solving, manual dexterity, or calculation, rather than strenuous physical effort, and conducted according to stated rules. This class also includes all forms of gambling devices.

term: Pin the Tail on the Donkey Set

definition: Objects originally created as expressions of human thought.  Communication objects comment on, interpret, or enhance people's environments.  Communication objects can function symbolically or literally.  This category excludes the tools and equipment that are used to create communication objects.

Objects originally created to communicate a particular personal belief, opinion, achievement, status, rank, occupation, membership, office, or identity. This class includes articles of adornment or clothing worn primarily for their symbolism; these objects may be assigned additional terms from Personal Objects to ensure appropriate cross-indexing. A personal symbol differs from a ceremonial object in that it expresses individual ideas, not the ideas of a group, or it communicates the relationship of individuals to a group.

Articles of adornment, clothing, accessories, and personal gear, the primary purpose of which is to communicate a particular status, rank, occupation, membership, or office. Such an article serves to associate individuals with social roles and relationships, either generally or under certain circumstances.

A distinctive and standardised suit that is sometimes of particular colours and that may sometimes have particular insignia. Used to protect the body, and to identify the wearer as belonging to a particular profession, civilian group, class, or rank.

A wide, usually rectangular, ecclesiastical veil or scarf. It is of the same colour and material as the sacred vestments of the clergy; may have fringes. Worn over the shoulders by the sub-deacon while he holds the paten between the offertory and the Paternoster. It may also be worn over the shoulders by the priest as he raises the monstrance to give the Benediction. It is also used to cover the celebrant’s hands while holding a sacred vessel.

An ecclesiastical upper-body garment that consists of a piece of fabric which gathers at the neckline, from which it falls freely down to the mid-thigh. It also has wide sleeves. Worn to cover the upper body during the liturgy by the clergy over a cassock, as well as by other officers of the church, and the choir.

An ecclesiastical vestment, typically consisting of a narrow band of embroidered woven fabric, often matching that of the maniple; usually finished with a fringe at each end. Used in two ways by members of the Christian clergy (notably Roman Catholics and Anglicans) during the performance of certain liturgical functions. The sacerdotal stole is worn by a priest or a bishop around the neck, either with the ends hanging parallel down the front as the outermost garment or underneath the chasuble, crossed over the chest and held in place at the waist by a girdle (a belt or a cord) with the ends hanging parallel down. The diaconal stole is worn by a deacon (or priest, cardinal or bishop filling that office) around the left shoulder and down to the right hip.

An ecclesiastical garment accessory consisting of a long strip of cloth that is usually bi-fold, which often has a tab on top (for hanging up when not in use) and a tab in the middle (to prevent it from falling off the arm). Sometimes the ends fan out and are decorated with fringe. Worn until May 4th, 1967 by the members of the Christian clergy, such as Roman Catholics and Anglicans, on the left forearm during the celebration of the Eucharist. It usually matches a stole worn at the same time.

An ecclesiastical robe consisting of a loose-fitting tunic that is usually made from two identically-shaped pieces of cloth sewn together, leaving a partial slit up either side. The sleeves are loose and rectangular, and it resembles a cross when fully open. Originally worn by deacons during religious ceremonies, it is now also worn by prelates.

An ecclesiastical upper-body garment consisting of a long cloak made from two semi-circles, or originally four quadrants sewn together. The front and back seams are reinforced by an orphrey or by a narrow strip of braid that extends along the length and that usually forms either a Y-shape or a cross. It may be round, oval, or pointed at the base of the front and back. Worn by priests or bishops over the alb and stole during the celebration of the Eucharist.

An ankle-length ecclesiastical robe that has a standing collar that may be worn under the surplice. It is usually form-fitting at the torso, loose and flaring below the waist, and generally buttoned from hem to neckline. Used to distinguish a man according to his religious order. It is also worn by a choir member.

A stiff hat that has three or four upright sides that project outwards. It is either black , violet, or red, and may have a tassel at the top. Used by a priest (black), a bishop (violet), or a cardinal (red), as part of the religious dress to identify the rank. It is also used to protect the head from the elements. (It appeared in the 16th to 17th centuries and was mandatory headwear until the 20th century. The type with four projections is only worn by a cleric holding a doctorate degree.)

An ecclesiastical garment consisting of a rectangular piece of fine linen. It has an embroidered cross in the centre and ties at the two ends. Used by Christian priests and bishops, such as in the Roman Catholic church, to cover the neck and shoulders during the celebration of mass. It is worn under the alb to protect it from neck perspiration.

A usually white ecclesiastic garment made of linen or, sometimes of silk, that is loose-fitting, long-sleeved, and collarless. The length varies from hip- to full-length and the hem, cuffs, breast, and back may be embroidered. Worn by a priest over the cassock during mass. It is also worn by other attendants during mass.

A set of ecclesiastical garments consisting of a full-length robe and a cloak of equal length. The man’s version may have a hood attached to the cloak, whereas the woman’s version may be equipped with a veil covering a wimple. The modern habits may not include the cloak. Some modern female orders have recently adopted a shorter skirt. Worn by religious orders and officers of the church to identify the order of the wearer. Also used everyday to provide warmth and during travel because of its durability.
Objects that note individual identity.
Personal objects, usually worn or carried, that express an individual's thoughts, opinions, convictions, allegiances, interests, or attitudes.
Objects that convey social recognition of achievements by individuals or groups of people.
Objects originally created to be used as media of exchange, such as currency, or as a means of obtaining specific goods and services, such as admission tickets, coupons, postage stamps, or tokens.
A paper or pasteboard document printed with a monetary value. Gave the bearer the right to a specific sum of money or to a predetermined quantity of goods.
A metal or paper document, embossed or printed, often dated and numbered. Used as a baggage claim receipt.
A paper or pasteboard document often with printed text on both sides. Used to obtain a right of passage on a mode of transportation or a right of entry to an event.
Piece of paper with a monetary value and images printed on the observe and a gummed reverse. Issued by a private merchant to be redeemed for pre-specified items sold by said merchant.
A paper document with an embellishment and a monetary value printed on the front and an adhesive substance coated on the back. Issued by the government, used to indicate the amount of tax collected.

A paper document with an embellishment and a monetary value printed on the front and an adhesive substance coated on the back. Issued by the postal service and used certify the postage paid on items sent via mail.
A paper or pasteboard document with printed text on both sides. Issued and endorsed by a government and used as a unit of monitary value.
A metal disk struck on both sides with a minting mark. Issued by a government and used as a unit of monitary value.

A spherical or oblong piece of glass with a hole through its center, worked in various colours. Served as a trade item. Threaded or made into beadwork to make necklaces and belts or to adorn clothing.
Paper document printed with a monetary value. Distributed by a manufacturer or vendor, gave the bearer the right to a price reduction on predetermined goods and services.

Objects originally created to communicate information to people. Unlike Advertising Media, a Documentary Object is not generally intended to elicit a specific response in regards to products, services, or events. Instead, it presents a point of view, an image, or a set of ideas, often with the aim of enlightening or swaying the attitude of people. This class includes printed documents on paper and also non-print, non-paper objects that serve a documentary purpose.

Documentary objects that routinely may be classified in none or more than one of the other sub-classes. These include objects that are defined more by form than by function or context. Many terms may be used in addition to other terms for cross-referencing purposes.
Tokens of remembrance or commemoration of a person, place, event, or experience.  This sub-class includes objects created to contain or display such tokens.

Written or printed items that express creative works intended to be read, heard, or performed. Such works include fictional and non-fictional literature, oral presentations, music, and theatrical productions.
Documents that pertain to legal actions and rights.
Prints or non-print items created to impart, test, or demonstrate knowledge or skill, either in the context of formal teaching and training or in more informal contexts.

Documents that provide primarily non-textual visual information.  Included in this sub-class are maps, charts, graphs, diagrams, and pictorial works produced through photographic, photomechanical, electronic, printing, or other processes.  Terms in this sub-class may be used in addition to terms from Art to index graphic documents that are also works of art.
Records created or maintained by a government agency. Included in this sub-class are legislative, judicial, trade, immigration, patent, military, census, and vital records.
Records that document the exchange or management of money or other items of value.
Public notices intended to be posted or distributed, the primary purpose of which is not advertising.
Records that document organizational functions or business operations.

Objects originally created for carrying on governmental, fraternal, religious, or other organized and sanctioned societal activities. Such objects are intended to evoke, symbolize, or express certain aspects of the traditions or heritage of a community or group of people. Usually, they are associated with rituals or ceremonies. This class includes: (1) any religious object, such as communion cups and altar pieces; note that personal devotional objects (such as religious medals or talismans) and religious symbols of office (such as vestments or crosiers) are classified under Personal Symbols; (2) any object used specifically in a ceremony concerned with a major personal event or crisis, such as birth, puberty, sickness, or death, or concerned with a community event or crisis, such as a harvest festival or the need for rain; and (3) any object, except for personal symbols, used in the ceremonial activities of a fraternity, lodge, club, governmental, or military organization, such as the pennant of a Girl Scout troop.
Objects intended for use in weddings, independent of formal religious worship or general partying and gift-giving.

A dress that is often made of white silk, satin, or velvet, and that is usually elaborately trimmed. It may have a train of various lengths attached at the back, and may be accompanied by accessories, such as a veil, gloves, etc. Worn by a bride, and in some cultures, a groom, during the wedding ceremony and sometimes during festivities that follow.
Objects intended for use in public religious worship or spiritual ceremonies.

A long, low wooden bench, often cloth- or leather-covered, sometimes padded and with a ledge for hymn books. It may pivot at the base of the pew in front to fold up out of the way. Used in church to kneel on during prayer.
A low-footed chair with a straight high back that widens at the top and a low seat. It often has a wide shelf for a prayer book instead of a top rail. Used to kneel on by a person at prayer.

A long white ceremonial dress, which may have long or short sleeves, and which is generally adorned with lace, ribbons, and embroidery. It usually extends well past the feet of an infant. Worn by an infant during the baptismal ceremony.
Objects intended for use at parties or on gift-giving or other special occasions, but not exclusively for weddings.

Objects routinely used by organizations, businesses, governments, or other corporate bodies in codified formal proceedings or ritual events. These objects sometimes serve to symbolize civic or corporate identities. This sub-class does not include objects used to associate individuals with corporate bodies; these are organized under Personal Symbols.
Objects intended for use in the celebration of religious or secular holidays, independent of formal religious worship or general partying and gift-giving.

A set of specific clothing pieces (such as pants, gown, and jacket), and accessories representing a character, such as Santa Claus, a witch, etc. Used usually in conjunction with make-up, on stage, or informally during seasonal celebrations, such as Christmas or Halloween.

Objects intended for use in funerals, burials, mourning, or other death rites, independent of formal religious worship.  This sub-class does not include structures, vehicles, memorabilia, or official records of death or burial.

Objects originally created for the expression and communication of ideas, values, or attitudes through images, symbols, or abstractions. Art often reflects aesthetic pleasure or demonstrates creative skills and dexterity. Art can be uniquely created or it can be produced in a medium that allows many duplicates to be made. Terms from this class, whether the generic "Artwork" term or more specific terms, may be used in addition to terms from other classes that index objects by other, practical functions (e.g., "Vase" and "Artwork," "Pillow" and "Embroidery," "Mocock" and "Quillwork," "Moccasin" and "Beadwork").

Objects originally created to call public attention to a product, service, or event and to elicit a specific response in regard to a product, service, or event.  Generally, the intended response is to urge people to acquire, use, or participate in the product, service, or event that is being advertised.  Note: Subjects and themes of advertisements may be indicated in a separate subject field.

Objects originally created to transport or distribute animate and inanimate things.  This category also includes objects originally created to facilitate such transportation or as an adjunct to such transportation.  This category includes propelled vehicles such as automobiles or wheelbarrows as well as containers that facilitate distribution.  Also included are parts of aircraft, spacecraft, land vehicles, rail vehicles, and watercraft.
Objects originally created to transport people or goods on or under water.

Objects originally created to transport people or goods on or under water. Watercraft terms are generally organized by functional context; watercraft that may be used in multiple contexts are organized by size (boat, ship) or positional use (semisubmersible, subsurface), and organization at more specific levels take other properties, such as shape and power source, into account. Catalogers are encouraged to use multiple terms to cross-index as needed (e.g.: Ship, Clipper and Ship, Sailing; Whaleboat and Boat); some cross-referencing suggestions are made in notes below.
Objects originally created as accessories for the transportation of people or goods on or under water.  Included are objects created to be parts of watercraft.
Objects originally created to transport people or goods on or along a fixed route determined by a track, rail, cable, or similar device.
Objects originally created to transport people or goods on or along a fixed route determined by a track, rail, cable, or similar device.

Objects originally created as accessories used in the transportation of people or goods on or along a fixed route determined by a track, rail, cable, or similar device.  Included are objects created to be parts of rail vehicles.
Objects originally created to transport people or goods on land without restriction to a fixed route determined by a track or other guidance device.

Objects, powered by some kind of self-acting mechanism such as a motor, originally created to transport people or goods on land without restriction to a fixed route determined by a track or other guidance vehicle.  Included are wheeled vehicles towed by motor vehicles.

A wheeled machine, equipped with a gas motor or steam engine, a steering wheel, a seat and a hitch. Used for pulling, pushing, carrying and operating various kinds of farm equipment or other agricultural machinery.
Objects, powered by human energy alone, originally created to transport people or goods on land without restriction to a fixed route determined by a track or guidance device.
Objects, powered by animal energy, originally created to transport people or goods on land without restriction to a fixed route determined by a track or guidance device.

Objects originally created as accessories used in the transportation of people or goods on land without restriction to a fixed route determined by a track or other guidance device.  Included are objects created to be parts of land vehicles.
A piece of rigid leather, often doubled, with a band of supple leather and a pair of fastening straps. Used to protect the fetlock joint of a horse’s legs.

A wooden and iron rack consisting of a trestle-shaped stand that usually rests on four legs. It may have hooks that are attached at regular intervals, as well as drawers, clappers, and shelves. Used to hold and store a saddle, a harness, and other horseback riding equipment.

Objects originally created to transport or distribute objects or substances.  Included in this class are terms to describe generic forms used to store or ship any variety of materials.  The term "Package, Product" from Merchandising T&E should be used in addition to a term from the Container class to describe containers used for the marketing and merchandising of specific products; the products themselves may be noted in a subject field.  Containers made for the personal storage or transport of specific objects are listed in Storage & Display Accessories, Personal Carrying & Storage Gear, or other classes with the objects for which they were made.
Objects originally created to transport people or goods above the surface of the earth.
Objects originally created to transport people or equipment outside the confines of earth's atmosphere.
Objects originally created to transport people or goods above the surface of the earth but within the confines of earth's atmosphere.
Objects originally created as accessories used in the transportation of people or goods above the face of the earth.  Included are objects created to be parts of aircraft or spacecraft.

Tools, equipment, and supplies used to enable communication.  This category includes those classes for literal and abstract communication -- Printing T&E and Musical T&E.  This category does not include things produced as communication, such as works of art or documents.  These are the objects created by the tools in this category, and they are listed in Communication Objects.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to facilitate the preparation and maintenance of written documents.  This class does not include the documents themselves or equipment and supplies relating to the replication or electronic transmission of documents.  This class includes objects relating to the sending and receipt of postal communication, but not to the actual processing, transportation, or delivery of mail by postal agencies or other delivery services.

Paper and other materials intended for the recording of written and printed communications.  Note: if any items listed in the sub-class have contents, terms from Documentary Objects also may be used to describe the contents, e.g., "Label, Identification" for a label, "Tag, Identification" for a tag, "Letter" for a sheet of letterhead, "Note" for a notecard, and "Correspondence" and "Print, Photographic" for a postcard.

Tools, equipment, and supplies that play a direct and essential role in the creation or transmission of written messages, such as writing implements or typewriters.  This sub-class does not include computer printers, which are included in Peripherals.
Tools, equipment, and supplies intended to facilitate written communication but that do not play a direct or essential role in the creation or transmission of written messages.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to facilitate communication by means of symbols, patterns, colors, text, or pictures that are directly observable by and intelligible to the recipient.  Included in this class are signs, visual signals, and devices that project images.
Tools, equipment, and supplies that play a direct role in the generation or display of visual symbols.
Tools, equipment, and supplies that facilitate visual communication but do not play a direct role in the generation or display of visual content.
Tools, equipment, and supplies intended to facilitate communication at a distance by electrical or electronic means.  This class includes telegraph, telephone, radio, and television equipment.
Objects that function as carriers of telecommunication messages.
Tools and equipment that play a direct role in the generation or reception of telecommunication messages.
Tools, equipment, and supplies that facilitate telecommunication but do not play a direct role in the transmission or reception of telecommunication messages.

Tools, equipment, and supplies, other than Instruments de musique, originally created to generate, amplify, reproduce, or store music, spoken words, or other sounds that are useful for human communication.

Objects originally created as repositories for the storage of sounds reproduced by a sound communication device.  This sub-class does not include digital media for sound, which are listed in Data Processing Media.  Note: If content is on the medium, "Recording" from Other Documents also may be used.
Tools and equipment that play an active role in the generation, amplification, or reproduction of sounds for communication.

An instrument consisting of a conical brass bore, often straight, curved or coiled in a helicon-shaped; equipped with a cupped mouthpiece at one end and a medium to wide, slightly flared bell at the other end. Used to produce a sound via sympathetic vibration of the air in the mouthpiece, in order to give a signal call during the hunt.

An instrument consisting of a straight, conical brass tube, equipped with a mouthpiece at one end and a funnel-shaped bell at the other. Used to produce a sound via sympathetic vibration of the air in the mouthpiece in order to announce the arrival of the stage coach.
Tools, equipment, and supplies that facilitate, but do not actually perform, the generation, amplification, reproduction, or storage of sounds for communication.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to reproduce written, photographic, or artistic material, whether in very limited quantities (as in the case of artistic engravings or lithographs) or in quantities required for widespread distribution.  This class includes specialized tools such as handpresses, engraver's blocks, or photocopiers, that are used for bookbinding, engraving, etching, lithography, or screen printing.

Tools and equipment used to assemble physical or virtual alphanumeric printing elements or "type" into assemblages (words, lines, paragraphs, etc.) in preparation for reproduction by replication equipment.
Tools and equipment that replicate written or graphic/photographic material through the application of ink or other pigment to the surface of paper or other media.

Tools, equipment, and supplies that play an ancillary or facilitating role in the printing process, but do not by themselves generate multiple copies of original written, graphic, or photographic material.
Tools, equipment, and supplies used in conjunction with replication equipment to reproduce quantities of graphic material.
A tool consisting of a short, pointed cutting edge, fixed to a wooden handle. Used to engrave leather, bone or ivory.
Tools and equipment used to assemble sheets of printed material into collated and/or bound volumes.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to capture a visual image by optical, chemical, or digital means, such as cameras, film, or darkroom equipment.
Tools, equipment, and supplies used in transforming a latent image, as captured by light-sensitive chemicals on film, into a visible negative or positive image.
Paper, film, and tape created to capture and present images.

Tools, equipment, and supplies that play an ancillary or facilitating role in the production of photographic images and are not used directly with cameras or photoprocessing equipment.  Included in this sub-class are maintenance gear and ancillary studio equipment.
Cameras and equipment attached to cameras for the purpose of capturing a visual image.  Included in this sub-class are camera parts, lenses, filters, lighting attachments, and camera supports.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to produce musical sounds or to be audibly incorporated into musical performances.  This class does not include devices that amplify, transmit, or record musical sound, or devices intended for other purposes whose sound may, on occasion, be integrated into a musical performance (e.g., cannons or churchbells to accompany the 1812 Overture).
Objects created to produce musical sounds.

An instrument consisting of an often wooden block perforated with a series of chambers sandwiched between two rectangular, metal casings equipped with a series of paired free reeds. Used to produce musical sounds and chords by blowing into the chambers, thereby pushing air over the unobstructed reeds and causing them to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a wooden or nickle silver cylindrical bore perforated with a series of holes on both sides often covered with moveable metal keys; closed at one end and equipped with a side-hole embouchure. Used to produce musical sounds by blowing by air over the edge of the mouth hole, thereby causing the column of air in the bore to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a wooden cylindrical bore perforated with 5 or 6 holes on one side; closed at one end, equipped with a side-hole embouchure and sometimes with metal ferrules. Used to produce high-pitched sounds by blowing by air over the edge of the mouth hole, thereby causing the column of air in the bore to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a wooden or tin conical bore that narrows towards the foot; perforated with a four holes on one the top side and two on the under side; equipped with a constricted metal mouthpiece inserted with a fipple plug. Used to produce high-pitched sounds by blowing air over the labium lip, thereby causing the column of air in the bore to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a wooden cylidrical bore with a series of side holes covered with several moveable metal keys; a mouthpiece fitted with a reed at one end and a funnel-shaped bell at the other end. Used to produce sounds by blowing air through the reed, thereby causing it to vibrate.
A metal device consisting of a fork-shaped, spring operated clip extending from a rod; sometimes equipped with fastening ring at the end. Used to hold a musical score on an instrument.

An instrument consisting of a gently waisted wooden resonance box with a sound hole in the middle of the upper third of the soundboard, a neck and headstock at the top end, a bridge at the bottom end and a set of 6 strings strung from the bridge to the tuning key-adjusted pegheads on the headstock. Used to produce sounds and chords by plucking the strings with the fingers or a plectrum, thereby causing them to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a narrow-waisted, fiddle-type wooden resonance box with a bridge and pegbox at one end, a soundpost in the middle, a tailpiece at the other end and a set of four strings strung from the taipiece, over the soundpost to the pegbox; sometimes equipped with a chinrest. Used to produce sounds by rubbing the strings with a violin bow, thereby causing them to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a large, narrow-waisted, fiddle-type wooden resonance box with a bridge and pegbox at one end, a soundpost in the middle, a tailpiece at the other end and a set of 4 strings strung from the tailpiece, over the soundpost to the pegbox; equipped with an cello endpin. Used to produce sounds by rubbing the strings with a bow, thereby causing them to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a round wooden or metal hoop with a screw-tensioned plastic or hide membrane stretched over its belly; equipped with a neck and headstock at the top end, a bridge fastened to the bottom third of the belly and a set of 4 strings strung from the bridge to the tuning key-adjusted pegheads on the headstock; often equipped with a fifth thumb string that can be tightened using the thumb string peg on the upper third of the neck. Used to produce sounds and chords by plucking the strings with the fingers or a plectrum, thereby causing them to vibrate.
An instrument consisting of two short wooden sticks, sometimes linked together at one end by a leather thong or cord. Used in pairs to produce a sound.

A metal instrument consisting of a flexible tongue fixed at one end to the centre of a round, oval or clover-shaped frame with a pair of parallel rods extending from the open end. Used to produce sounds by plucking the tongue, thereby causing the air in the buccal / oral cavity to resonate via sympathetic vibration.

An instrument consisting of a wide, shallow-rimmed metal disk; equipped with a hanging strap, often suspended from a wooden or metal frame with a base. Used to produce a sound by strinking with a mallet, thereby causing the disk to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a hollow, cylindrical shell with a tensioned hide membrane stretched over it; sometimes embellished with patterns. Used to produce sounds by hitting the drum head with the hand, a drumstick or a mallet.

An instrument consisting of a hollow, deep, inverted metal cup with flaired lip and a clapper inside; equipped with a wooden handle. Used to produce sounds by hitting the clapper against the inner wall of the bell, thereby causing it to vibrate.

A mechanical string instrument consisting of a viol-shaped resonance box; four strings sounded by a crank-handle-operated rotating wheel with rosin on it; a keyboard and tangent mechanism and a series of tuning keys. Used to produce sounds and chords by the rubbing action of the rosin wheel, thereby causing the strings to vibrate; the sounds are amplified by the resonating chamber and their pitch is adjusted by the tangents.

An instrument consisting of a rectangular wooden resonating case, a crank-handle operated bellows, a series of pnumatic tubes fitted with free reeds and a pin-hole music roll or disc. Used to produce musical sounds and chords by expanding and compressing the bellows, thereby pushing air over the unobstructed reeds and causing them to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a wooden sound board enclosed in an upright or horizontal wooden cabinet; equipped with a metal frame strung with a series of wire strings, a keyboard-operated, felt hammer and damper mechanism and two or three foot pedals. Used produce sounds and chords by striking the strings with the hammers, thereby causing them to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a wooden sound board enclosed in a horizontal wooden cabinet set on a base; equipped with a horizontally positioned metal frame strung with a series of wire strings that run parallel to the keyboard, a left-hand inset, partial-range keyboard, a simplified, felt hammer and damper mechanism and a set of foot pedals. Used produce sounds and chords by striking the strings with the hammers, thereby causing them to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a wooden sound board enclosed in a horizontal, wing-shaped wooden cabinet set on three or more feet; equipped with a horizontally positioned metal frame strung with a series of wire strings that run perpendicular to the keyboard, a full-range keyboard, a felt hammer and damper mechanism and a set of foot pedals. Used produce sounds and chords by striking the strings with the hammers, thereby causing them to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a rectangular wooden case set on a base; equipped with pedal-operated bellows, a wind chest with a perforated bellows board on top, a series of reed blocks inserted with free reeds, a set of stops and a keyboard. Used to produce musical sounds and chords by expanding and compressing the bellows and by depressing the keys, thereby pushing air over the unobstructed reeds and causing them to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a pair of rectangular, wooden or metal headboards joined together by an extendable leather bellows; each headboard includes a series of reedblocks operated by either a treble keyboard or a bass buttonboard; the whole is equipped with a pair of leather shoulder straps. Used to produce sounds and chords by expanding and compressing the bellows and by depressing the keys, thereby pushing air over the free reeds and causing them to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a wooden sound board with a sound hole in the middle enclosed in a horizontal, wing-shaped wooden cabinet set on three or more feet; equipped with a horizontally positioned wooden frame strung with a series of wire strings that run perpendicular to the keyboard, a partial or full-range keyboard and a series of plectrum-equipped jacks. Used produce sounds and chords by plucking strings with the plectra, thereby causing them to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of two hexagonal, metal or wooden casings joined together by an extendable leather bellows. Both casings are equipped with a series of reedblocks operated by a set of buttons and held by hand and thumb straps. Used to produce sounds and chords by expanding and compressing the bellows and by depressing the stops, thereby pushing air over the free reeds and causing them to vibrate.

An instrument consisting of a wide, conical brass bore coiled in a bugle or helicon-shape; equipped with a cup-shaped mouthpiece at one end, a wide, flared bell at the other end, as well as a set of valves, slides and water keys. Used to produce a sound via sympathetic vibration of the air in the mouthpiece.

An instrument consisting of a conical brass bore, coiled once or twice in a bugle-shape; equipped with a cup-shaped mouthpiece at one end and a medium-sized, slightly flared bell at the other end. Used to produce a sound via sympathetic vibration of the air in the mouthpiece.

An instrument consisting of a conical metal bore, often coiled in a bugle or helicon-shape with a cup-shaped mouthpiece at one end and a medium-sized, slightly flared bell at the other end; equipped with a set of valves. Used to produce a sound via sympathetic vibration of the air in the mouthpiece as a part of a brass band.

An instrument consisting of a wide conical brass bore, coiled once or twice in a oval shape; equipped with a cup-shaped mouthpiece at one end an a funnel-shaped bell at the other and sometimes a carrying cord. Used to produce a sound via sympathetic vibration of the air in the mouthpiece in order to give a signal call.

Tools, equipment, and supplies that facilitate the production of musical sound by manual or mechanical/electronic means, but do not themselves generate such sound.  Included in this sub-class are musical instrument components.
A wooden or metal rack consisting of an inclined, sometimes moveable, rectangular frame fixed to an upright set on a base. Used to hold musical score.

A seat consisting of a round, flat piece of wood, sometimes upholstered on top, mounted on a large adjustable screw fixed to a base. Enables a person to sit at the desired height while playing the piano.

An armless, backless wooden seat consisting of a rectangular plank, sometimes upholstered on top and equipped with storage space below; the whole set on a frame base. Enables one or two people to sit while playing the piano.

An armless, backless wooden seat consisting of a rectangular plank, sometimes upholstered on top and equipped with storage space below; the whole set on a frame base. Enables one or two people to sit while playing the organ.
An oblong, round-ended, wedge-shaped wooden or leather container lined with fabric; sometimes divided into compartments. Used to store, protect and carry a violin and a violin bow.

A device consisting of a stick with a length of horsehair stretched from the curved tip at one end to the movable frog at the other; equipped with an adjusting screw. Used to produce sounds by rubbing violin strings, thereby causing them to vibrate.
Awooden rod with a leather or felt head at one end. Used to produce a sound by striking the head of a drum or a gong, thereby causing it to vibrate.
A wooden rod which tapers to a round or oval wooden knob at one end. Used to produce a sound by striking the head of a drum, thereby causing it to vibrate.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to be used for the creation of precision drawings, such as architectural plans, mechanical designs, maps, or charts.  This class does not include general purpose writing, drawing, and lettering tools.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for processing information by manual, mechanical, or electronic means, and in a manner subject to human intervention (e.g., by physical manipulation of beads in an abacus, or by varying the parameters incorporated into computer software).  Single-purpose devices, such as a digital watch or a digital thermometer, whose functions involve only the conversion of physical input (e.g., temperature, pressure, etc.) into visual, audible, or mechanical output, are not included here, but are classified according to their specific function (e.g., Timekeeping T&E or Thermal T&E).
Tools and equipment specifically created to facilitate data processing by accomplishing input, storage, or output of data, but that do not have independent data processing capabilities.

Storage devices for processed information.  Note: "Recording" from Other Documents also may be used for media containing recorded music and video, and "Software" or a narrower term from Data Processing Accessories also may be used for media containing computer programs.
Tools and equipment originally created for processing information by manual, mechanical, or electronic means.
Tools, equipment, and supplies that facilitate the processing of information, but that do not themselves process information.

Tools, equipment, and supplies used for the observation of natural phenomena or to apply knowledge gained from such observation.  Tools in this category tend to be made to enlarge or record our understanding of the world or to help express such understanding.  The classes in this category are related by virtue of the fact that they include objects created to employ a particular body of knowledge.  The classes are based on knowledge rather than materials.
term: Category 05: Tools & Equipment for Science & Technology

definition: Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to observe, measure, or record light.  This class includes commonly used equipment, such as binoculars and microscopes.  It excludes specialized objects created for other scientific observation, such as visual acuity charts or telescopes that are used particularly for astronomy.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to study atomic structure and elementary particles as well as the physical properties of the universe.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to observe, measure, or document atmospheric phenomena.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to facilitate or enable the exchange of money, goods, or services.  This class includes those objects used to present goods, such as counters, as well as product packages and labels.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the examination, testing, diagnosis, or treatment of humans.  This class includes dental tools, objects used for sight and hearing, and objects used for psychological testing or treatment.  It does not include objects used to study physical phenomena (see Acoustical T&E, Biological T&E, Chemical T&E, and Optical T&E) or tools for veterinary medicine, which are included in Animal Husbandry T&E.
Tools and equipment used for human medical examination, testing, diagnosis, or treatment that are not specifically designed for dental purposes.
An undergarment consisting of a long, narrow strip of cloth which is tied around an infant’s waist. Generally used as a medical dressing to support and to protect an infant’s umbilical region.
Tools, equipment, and supplies intended to facilitate human medical examination, testing, diagnosis, or treatment but that do not play a direct or essential role in these activities.

A large, wide, and solid table that rests on thick legs which often have connecting stretchers. It may sometimes have draining wells. It is high enough to work around it while standing. Used by morticians and undertakers as a surface on which to perform the embalming of human corpses.
Tools and equipment originally created for the examination, testing, diagnosis, or treatment of the human mouth and teeth.
Tools, equipment, and supplies intended to facilitate dental examination, testing, diagnosis, or treatment but that do not play a direct or essential role in these activities.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the study, measurement, or utilization of the static or dynamic properties of solids, liquids and gasses.  This class includes general-purpose mechanical devices, such as wedges or hoists, and specialized devices, such as tensiometers or pressure gauges, used to measure mechanical properties.

Objects used for the study or measurement of the static or dynamic properties of solids, liquids, or gasses, including force, motion, pressure, flow, tension, friction, ductility, torque, velocity, and viscosity.

Objects that utilize the static or dynamic properties of solids, liquids, and gasses, including general-purpose mechanical devices and objects used specifically for the maintenance of mechanical devices.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for cleaning, laundering, or groundskeeping activities performed in and around a home or a public building, whether performed occasionally or as a business.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the cleaning, drying, or pressing of clothing and linens.

A press consisting of two long, flat wooden boards. The top board is made of heavy wood and contains several metal clamps. Used to give a pair of pants precise creases and folds after ironing. The pants to be pressed are placed between the two boards which are then clamped together.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the cleaning or tidying of furnishings, buildings, or building spaces.

A usually metal jar with or without a lid and handles, sometimes having a flared base and top. Used to receive waste from a washbowl or the contents of a chamber pot. It is sometimes used as a chamber pot.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the care or maintenance of areas around structures such as lawns, flower beds, or sidewalks, or for larger landscaped areas such as athletic fields or golf courses.  This sub-class does not include objects used to prepare land specifically for the cultivation of crops.

A tool consisting of two short, semi-crescent-shaped, scissored, steel blades attached to two metal or wooden handles that sometimes open with a spring. Used for cutting small branches and twigs from woody plants.
A tool consisting of a long, thin, straight-edged or toothed blade attached to a handle. Used to selectively cut branches from trees, to remove old stems or dead wood or to reshape a tree.

A tool consisting of a thin, slightly curved or straight iron blade attached to a short wooden handle into which the blade may sometimes fold. Used for removing new shoots on plants, for paring or grafting trees, particularly fruit-bearing varieties.
A tool consisting of a wide, curved, metal blade sometimes with a squared-shaped heel and a wooden handle. Used for pruning and cutting small branches off trees or bushes.
A tool consisting of two stout, straight-tipped, scissored steel blades attached to two long wooden handles. Used for pruning branches of trees or bushes.
A hand-held tool consisting of two long, scissored, steel blades attached to two wooden handles. Used to trim hedges.

A hand- or machine-drawn tool consisting of a solid metal, stone or wood cylinder set on an axle and equipped with a double handle. Used for smoothing or levelling surface soil and to crush larger clumps of soil.
A device consisting of a tapered metal pipe with an interior valve operated by a levered hand-grip. Used to regulate the flow of water from a garden hose.

A machine consisting of a rotary cylinder equipped with curved, metal blades set on a frame or axle, two or four wheels, sometimes a grassbox and a T-shaped wooden or metal handle. Used to cut lawn grass.
A tool consisting of a hooked, single- or double-edged blade attached to a wooden handle. Used to cut heavy brush, weed, shrubs and small trees.
A tool consisting of a semi-circular iron blade attached to a long wooden handle. Used to trim the edges of a lawn.

A cylindrical, metal or wooden container with a half-covered top and a spout, which may be topped by watering rose, and a handle. Used to carry and disperse a limited amount of water over garden plants and flower beds.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created  to wash or assist in the washing of food service or food preparation items.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to observe, measure, or document geological phenomena.  This class includes geologists' picks and seismic measuring devices, but it excludes tools used for harvesting or mining rock or mineral materials.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to generate, convert, or distribute energy or power.  This class does not include objects listed in Electrical System Components.
Objects related to energy production that do not meet the definitions of this class’s other sub-classes.
Objects originally created to assist in the transmission or regulation of power, particularly mechanical power in power-producing equipment or other machines.
Objects originally created to generate power.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to control, distribute, modify, observe, measure, or document electricity and magnetism. This class includes tools, equipment, and components used in the manufacture, installation, maintenance, or repair of electrical and electronic devices as well as those used in the delivery of electricity or electrical power.  This class does not include electrical or electronic devices created to serve other specific purposes, such as sound communication or data processing, nor does it include electrical motors and generators, which are listed in Power Producing Equipment.
Objects originally created to serve as part of an electricity delivery system.
Objects originally created to maintain or repair electrical monitoring equipment or install or repair electrical delivery systems.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to observe, measure, or document electrical or magnetic activity.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for moving earth or building structures.  This class includes paving machines and equipment that modify by demolition, such as wrecking balls or jack hammers.  It also includes tools such as pile drivers used for the construction of highways or structural facilities.  This class does not include specialized tools listed in other classes or used in the construction industries, such as cranes, hammers, or cement mixers.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the study or manufacture of substances based upon their molecular composition, structure, and properties.  Objects used for the study of atomic and subatomic particles are included in Nuclear Physics T&E, and objects used for the study of the interaction of physical objects are in Mechanical Measurement Equipment.
Glassware and other general equipment used in different types of laboratories.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the sampling, observation, measurement, or recording of specific chemical properties in specialized applications.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to observe, measure, or document physiological or anatomical aspects of the organisms for purposes other than diagnosis or treatment.  Tools for diagnosis and treatment of people are included in Medical & Psychological T&E; those for animals are in Veterinary Equipment.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to observe, measure, or document objects and events outside of the earth's atmosphere.  Objects listed in this class differ from those in Optical T&E in that they are not intended to address particular problems associated with vision.  They differ from those in Surveying & Navigational T&E in that they are concerned with observation rather than with the practical uses for such observation.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to be used for hunting, target-shooting, warfare, or self-protection.  This class includes firearms, artillery, bladed weapons, and striking weapons.  It does not include structures designed for housing troops or supplies and objects designed for transporting troops or supplies.
Armaments designed to batter or crush by weight or momentum, including weapons that propel non-explosive or non-penetrating missiles.

Projectile-firing weapons that can be deployed easily by one person and, in most cases, use explosive propellant.  This sub-class does not include ammunition, firearm accessories, or crew-served heavy armament.  Note: For combination and conversion pieces, use multiple terms, e.g., "Pistol" and "Carbine" for a pistol carbine, and "Musket, Flintlock" and "Musket, Percussion" for a musket converted from flintlock to percussion.
A weapon consisting of a short flared-muzzle, smooth-bore barrel fixed to a buttstock, and fitted with a flintlock, a trigger guard and a trigger. Used to fire small pellets.

A weapon consisting of a long rifled barrel, fitted with a wood stock, a trigger, a trigger guard,  originally a flint lock but ordinarily a percussion lock or a firing mechanism for breech loading, an aiming mechanism, stamped with identification and inspection marks, and usually equipped with a bayonet and sometimes with a sling. Used to fire bullets.
A weapon consisting of a short barrel with a front sight, fixed to a grip, and fitted with a breech, a magazine, a trigger guard, a trigger, and a safety lever. Used to fire a bullet.

A weapon consisting of a short barrel fixed to a forestock which ends in a grip, fitted with a lock plate, a trigger guard and a ramrod, and generally with furniture. Used to fire a bullet loaded from the muzzle, and coming in pairs.
A weapon consisting of a barrel block with several rotating barrels fixed to a stock fitted with a wooden grip, a percussion mechanism, a hammer and a trigger. Used to fire several bullets.

A weapon consisting of a very long rifled or smooth-bore barrel, fitted with a wood stock, a flint or percussion lock, a trigger and a trigger guard, sometimes mounted on a stand, and stamped with identification and inspection marks. Used to fire lead bullets.

A heavy weapon consisting of a barrel surrounded by a radiator, fitted with a receiver with a feed tray, an ejection port, a charging handle, a trigger, an aiming mechanism, and a magazine or munition belt, and mounted on a tripod. Used to fire bursts of projectiles.

A metal weapon consisting of a barrel with, at one end, a movable tip closed with a plug, and at the other end, a curved handle screwed to it and containing a firing pin and a spring. Used to fire a single bullet in personal protection.
Weapons that cut or pierce by cutting.  This sub-class includes edged weapons such as bayonets that are accessories to firearms and tools such as crossbows that launch edged weapons.
Clothing worn as defensive armament, including formal parts of a suit of armor and protective devices used in combat.

Heavy weapons that employ combustion or explosion to fire a projectile.   Artillery may be portable and may be employed by one person, but typically it is fired from a more or less stationary position.
Objects used as accessories for hunting, target-shooting, warfare, or self-protection.  This sub-class includes weapon components and objects used for weapon care or storage.

Ammunition for armament, whether intended for particular weapons, such as BBs and cartridges, or intended to be deployed alone, such as grenades, missiles, or bombs.  This sub-class includes ammunition casings, such as sabots, and planted explosive weapons, such as mines or petards.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the study of sound and its effect on hearing.  Objects listed in this class may be used for generating, detecting, observing, testing, modifying, and/or measuring sound.  They differ from objects in Sound Communication T&E in that their function is to study sound, not to transmit or receive it.  They differ from some related items in Medical & Psychological T&E in that the function of items in Acoustical T&E is to examine the nature and effects of sound, not to diagnose or treat medical conditions.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to observe, record, or measure mass (weight) or physical dimensions such as length, area, or volume.  This class includes general-purpose measuring devices such as precision balances or folding rules.  It excludes objects created to measure time and to measure particular scientific data.  Also excluded are specialized measuring devices and gauges such as sextants or carpenter's squares.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for recording or measuring time.  This class does not include timekeeping objects created for specialized purposes, such as chronometers.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to observe, measure, or document heat and its effects.  Excluded from this class are specialized objects created to serve specific purposes, such as a meteorological thermometer.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to determine the position of an observer relative to known reference points or to indicate the form and extent of a region, such as land surface.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to indicate the form or extent of a region such as a land surface.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to determine the position or course of an observer relative to known reference points.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for controlling the behavior of people or for providing security or protection for property.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to control the behavior of people.  This sub-class includes objects used for restraint, prosecution, punishment, torture, and execution.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to provide security or protection for property.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to manage, oversee, capture, harvest, or collect resources or to transform or modify particular materials, either raw or processed.  These objects are normally created in response to problems inherent in the materials themselves; for example, wood requires certain kinds of cutting devices, fish require certain lures, and food requires certain serving utensils.

Tools, equipment, and supplies that do not meet the definitions of this category's other classes.  This class includes specialized tools originally created to transform raw materials into specific finished products such as cigars, gems, and soap.
A rectangular-shaped wooden rod. Used to hang and dry tobacco leaves.
A tool consisting of a metal blade attached to a handle. Used to cut blocks of snow.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the fabrication of objects from wood.  This class includes objects used with and to create physically modified wood by-products such as plywood, chipboard, and masonite.  This class excludes tools and equipment for making objects out of chemically modified wood by-products such as paper, rayon, or rubber.  Note: Various woodworking trades, such as carpentry, coopering, shipbuilding, or wheelwrighting, may be noted in a subject field.

A metal device consisting of a second-class lever with a series of depressions on the underside attached to a base with a corresponding set of depressions on the upper surface. Used to compress a cork in order to facilitate insertion into a bottleneck.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the preparation of materials made from fibers and the preparation of woven fabrics.  Also included in this class are tools, equipment, and supplies used for manufacturing objects from fibers or cloth.  This class includes tools specific to the preparation of fibers, such as hatchels and cotton gins, but excludes tools, such as sheep shears and cotton balers, that are related to sources of fibers.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to assist in the processing of natural fibers into thread and yarn or in the processing of thread and yarn into finished textiles such as lace, cloth, or cordage.  Processes include spinning, weaving, knitting, knotting, twining, and finishing.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for processes and techniques involving needle and thread, including appliqué, beading, sewing, quilting, and embroidery.  This sub-class includes objects used in gathering, hooking, and pleating.  It includes objects used by dressmakers, tailors, hatters, and sailmakers.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the manufacture of materials formed from the residue of suspensions or in the fabrication of products made of such materials.  Paper (whether made from wood pulp, textile fibers, or plastic fibers) is the principal product that falls in this class.  Particles mixed with liquids form suspensions.  Although felt is made of materials that are matted like paper, tools for felting are listed in Textileworking T&E because felt is not formed from a suspension.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for working with materials that mask surfaces by depositing a residual film such as a paint film, or by using adhesives to attach a thin covering such as wallpaper or gold leaf to a surface.  This class includes tools, equipment, and supplies used in decorative, artistic, and protective applications.  Excluded from this class are tools and equipment that are used with thicker coatings, such as wood veneers or plastic laminates, and tools and equipment used for metal plating.  Also excluded are tools and equipment associated with printing processes, such as printing blocks and silkscreens.

Objects originally created to transform or modify materials in ways that extend beyond the range of one class.  This class includes terms for multi-purpose tools and tools that work with a variety of materials as well as generic terms that may be used if the particular context of use is unknown.

term: Multiple Use T&E for Materials (blank sub-class)

definition: A piece of cloth or material coated with powdered, abrading emery. Used for smoothing and polishing metal pieces which have been previously wetted.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for extracting materials in solid, liquid, or gaseous state from the natural environment.  This class includes equipment used for underground and surface mines, quarries, oil and water wells, for prospecting, and for supplemental processing operations such as breaking, milling, washing, cleaning, or grading.  It also includes tools used for ice harvesting and salt harvesting.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for casting, forging, machining, or fabricating metals or metal products.  This class does not include tools, equipment, and supplies used in mining or preliminary processing of ores, which are listed in Mining & Mineral Harvesting T&E.

A metal tool consisting of a long straight bar with a handle at one end and a socket drive at the other, and a graduated scale in between. Used to tighten nuts and bolts to a pre-determined, accurate tightness in a series of assembling motions.

A tool consisting of a rectangular piece of metal of various sizes that has one or more bevelled holes cut out of the centre and that is fitted with a handle on either side. Used for gripping a tap for making female threads.
A metal tool consisting of a rod with, at one end, a hollow section with four to six points, perpendicularly attached to a handle. Used to tighten or loosen nuts.
A metal tool consisting of two jaws, one mobile the other fixed, and extending from two long arms. Used to hold metal tubes and pipes of different diameters.
A metal tool consisting of a flat straight bar that flares outward at one or both ends into a rounded head with two fixed and curved jaws. Used to quickly tighten or loosen nuts.

A metal tool consisting of a flat head, with two jaws, one being fixed and the other adjustable, and a worm screw, extending from a metal handle or set in a wooden handle. Used to tighten or loosen nuts.
A metal tool consisting of a flat head, with two curved jaws, one being fixed and the other movable, and a worm screw, extending from a handle. Used to tighten or loosen nuts of various sizes.
A metal tool consisting of straight bar with an enclosed opening at both ends, each having multiple points. Used to tighten or loosen nuts with great force.

A tool consisting of a straight or L-shaped bar of hardened steel that has hexagonal-shaped holes cut out of one or both ends. Used to grip the head of a bolt or screw or a nut to unscrew, screw or adjust any female hexagonal nut, screw or bolt by fitting the hexagonal hole at the end of the wrench over the hexagonal head of the nut screw or bolt and turning.
A metal tool consisting of a vertical frame with two triangular jaws and a crank handle. Used to tightly clamp round metal pieces (pipes, bolts, bar).
A metal tool consisting of two thick arms ending with serrated jaws, and equipped with an adjusting lever and a long leg. Used to hold heavy metal pieces.
A tool consisting of two metal arms which form a pair of vertical jaws, through which runs a tightening screw. Used to fix a work-piece.

A metal tool consisting of two roughly rectangular horizontal jaws mounted on a base with two slide-rods arranged on either side of a threaded screw running the length of the base. Used to secure a work piece to the work bench.

A metal piece consisting of a square plate with a small tube on one face and a larger tube on the other face. Used to link the bellows to the fire in a blast furnace or forge, in order to control and focus the air blast from the bellows into the fire.
A circular receptacle made of hooped wood-staves, with two handles at the top. Used to hold the water needed to control the fire in the forge, to quench the iron or to cool the tools.
A tool consisting of a metal wheel, hollowed-out and mobile, set in a wooden or metal handle or shank. Used to measure the circumference of a wheel in order to install an iron tire.
A metal tool consisting of a flat, rectangular bar with multiple holes of various sizes. Used to form nail and bolt heads.
A tool consisting of a metal bar with round or square holes in it generally at both ends. Used to form the head of a bolt.

A metal tool consisting of two flat, curved jaws that band roughtly at right angles to the handles and taper to a threaded, gripping end. Used for holding iron or steel tires while being heated in the forge-fire.
A metal tool consisting of two straight jaws with a slightly curved face, extending from two arms connected by a joint. Used to handle horseshoes during forging or shoeing.

Tongs with a springy rivet hinge and jaws that are straight from the pivot to just before the tip where they curve dramatically, each tip curved to form a semicircle. Used for picking up and holding small pieces of odd-sized metals, such as pins and rivets, especially when they have to be taken from the fire and put in a vice or transferred to other types of tongs.

Tongs with flat jaws, bending at a right angle to the handles. Used to hold hoops or rings which may then be worked either on the edge, when laid flat on the anvil, or on the inside, when placed upon the beak-iron.

Tongs with a) hollowed jaws of various forms, such as round or square, gripping sideways with an approximately 5cm capacity or b) grooved front jaws that curve near the tips and rounded back. Used for holding straight, long, round or square irons bars, especially those with a forged piece on one end which may be too large for the ordinary flat tongs or the round-bit tongs.

Tongs with curved jaws that widen near pivot. Used to hold round stocks and the round shanks of bolts. They are also used to make bolts out of round stock by closing the jaws around the shank without touching the head which already fits into the swell of the jaws while the other end.

Tongs with jaws that curve inward to form a circle approximately 8.8 cm in diameter. Used for holding a hammer, an ax, a set chisel or other eyed tools while being forged, refaced, dressed up or repaired.
A metal tool consisting of two straight and long jaws extending from two curved arms connected by a joint. Used for holding flat pieces of metal that are being heated, forged or tempered.
Tongs with flat jaws that taper to form a square. Used to hold square pieces of iron during heating and forging in order to prevent them from slipping and twisting sideways.
A tool consisting of a metal head with a length-wise groove, and an eye in which a wooden handle is fitted. Used in conjunction with a bottom swage to make circular shapes on hot metal pieces.

A tool consisting of a rectangular metal head, with one or many length-wise grooves, and a short quadrangular shaft perpendicular to it. Inserted in an anvil eye, generally used in conjunction with a top swage to make round or half-round shapes on hot metal pieces.
An implement consisting of tightly wound strips of rope assembled in a bundle which is attached to a metal rod handle. Used to flick water in the forge-fire to keep the coal wet.
A metal tool consisting of a rectangular blade set into a wooden or metal handle. Used to carry coal to the forge-fire and to disperse ashes.
A abrading stone, usually rectangular with coarse, medium or fine grit, or with a different grit on each side. Used to sharpen knives and other sharp-edged tools.
A tool consisting of a circular metal rod, usually pointed at one end, attached to a handle made of horn, bone, wood, or metal. Used for sharpening the cutting edge of a blade.
A metal tool consisting of a straight, serrated blade attached to a bow-shaped frame with a straight handle or pistol grip. Used to cut hard and thick metal.
A metal tool consisting of a rod bent to a 90° angle at one end, with a handle at the other end. Used to poke the forge-fire or to rake out the ash.
A wooden tool consisting of a triangular head attached perpendicularly to a shaft. Used to make grooves in the sand in order to form a pig mold.

A cylindrical metal tool consisting, at one end, of a circular cutting edge with a depression in it and, at the other end, a flat striking head. Used to produce round cut-outs from sheet metal or metal.
A metal tool consisting of a square rod with a pointed tip at one end, and a striking head at the other end. Used to drive an assembling piece (pin, rivet) out of its hole.
A metal tool consisting of a shank tapering to a round end. Used to pierce a hole in a piece of metal or to mark a piece where a hole will be drilled.

A machine-tool made of metal consisting of a frame attached to a vertical wooden pillar, and equipped with a spindle, a table, a gear and a mandrel. Used to mechanically bore holes in pieces of metal.
A metal tool consisting of a straight rod which tapers to a point or an inward hook at one end and is bent to form a loop handle at the other end. Used to stir the forge fire.
A metal tool consisting of two jaws, one having a matrix die and the other Used to clamp snaps, rivets or eyelets into leather.
A receptacle generally made of stone, metal, or wood, sculpted or shaped into a pattern, and equipped with risers. Used to contain molten metal and give it a shape while it solidifies.

A machine-tool made of metal, consisting of two wheels placed one on top of the other, a guide, a tightening lever and a crank handle, and mounted on a circular foot. Used to turn up the edges of a circular sheet, or to insert a metal wire.

A machine-tool made of metal, consisting of two cutter wheels placed one on top of the other, a guide, a tightening lever and a crank handle, and mounted on a circular foot. Used for turning up the edges of a metal piece in order to make a seam.
A metal tool consisting of a small bowl with a pouring lip and attached to a handle which ends with a ring. Used to carry and pour molten metal.
A metal tool consisting of a shank with a point at one end, and fitted into a wooden handle at the other end. Used for melting tin or lead to join pieces of metal for fine work.
A container made of hollowed-out horn with a loop on one side. Used to store a whetstone in a small amount of water.
A metal tool consisting of a triangular and sharp head and a square base with a shank protruding down from the centre. Inserted into an anvil eye and used with a hammer to cut cold or hot metal bars.

A tool consisting of a flat metal head with a straight, sharp peen, fitted into a wooden handle. Used to strike set tools, to hit, forge, cut or straighten out large pieces of metal, and to make iron tires.
A tool consisting of a metal head with two identical, flat, round faces, attached perpendicularly to a wooden handle. Used for striking large metal pieces.

A tool consisting of a metal head having, on one side, a wedge-shaped peen whose tapered tip’s axis is perpendicular to the length of the handle, and, on the other side, a flat face. Used for striking large metal pieces.
A tool consisting of a flat, square, metal head with a transversal peen, and attached to a wooden handle which is inserted into an eye. Used to strike the head of a rivet.

A tool consisting of a flat, square, metal head with a wedge-shaped peen, at right angles to a wooden handle to which it is attached, the handle being inserted into an eye. Used for striking pieces of red-hot metal in order to shape them.
A tool consisting of a flat, metal head with a round peen, attached to a wooden handle which is inserted into an eye. Used to flatten, curve, spread and straighten metal pieces.

A tool consisting of a roughly rectangular head, which flares out to form a thin, flat, rectangular, slightly concave face, mounted on a wooden handle. Used to give smoothness to the metal-work pieces and to even out metal surfaces.

A machine consisting of a circular, abrasive stone mounted on a rectangular wooden stand, with a rim, on four legs, and driven by a treadle mechanism. Used to sharpen tools or shape and polish pieces of metal through the revolving movement of the stone.
A tool consisting of a metal head, rounded on top, with a square peen, and perpendicularly attached to a wooden handle. Used with the bottom fuller to imprint a groove or light depression on metal.
A metal tool of circular cross-section, tapering towards a slight point, and covered with a series of teeth. Used to enlarge round or concave holes in a piece of metal.
A metal tool consisting of a flat bar of rectangular cross-section, covered with ridges, slightly tapering towards one end, with a tang at the other end. Used to polish rough surfaces of metal.
A metal tool consisting of a short rod with a rounded head at one end. Used to permanently join pieces or sheets of metal.

A tool consisting of a typically rectangular bar of metal with an opening at one end that may sometimes be adjusted to fit into the shank of a die. Used to hold and turn dies when threading pipes, rods, nuts, or bolts.
A metal tool consisting of two opposing short and thick blades with straight points extending from two short, curved arms. Used to cut sheet metal in straight or curved lines.
A metal tool consisting of two opposing semi-oval blades that cross and extend into two straight-levered handles bent to 90° at the end. Used for cutting sheet iron or sheet metal.
A round metal receptacle with a pouring spout, feet, and a loop handle fixed over the top. Used to contain metal which has been melted in a furnace or metal which will be melted at high temperatures.
A metal tool consisting of a head with a sharp, cutting edge and a straight peen, and an eye into which a wooden handle is fitted. Used to cut hot metal.
A metal piece consisting of a threaded rod with a flaring head at one end. Used with a nut for assembling two pieces of metal.

A metal tool consisting of a reservoir with a wooden handle at the side and on top of which are a burner and a pump. Used to heat surfaces to be soldered, quickly melt solders or pre-heat a piece before welding.

A tool, made of brass or other metal, consisting of a curved metal pipe with a burner at one end and a threaded socket at the other end for fitting into a propane cylinder. Used to heat metal or other objects for welding, soldering, removing paint, etc.
A tool consisting of two wooden boards connected one to the other by leather bindings (like a concertina). Used to blow air into the forge-fire.

A metal shaping tool of various sizes consisting of a base (bottom swage) and a separate top portion (top swage), each with a convex face and matching grooves to produce a variety of shapes (such as round, oval, square. Used for rounding, smoothing, drawing, bending or shaping metal that has been heated to a dark red and sandwiched between the two pieces with the base (bottom swage) typically fitted into the hardy hole of an anvil or the swage block.

A metal tool consisting of a rectangular, flat working surface which steps down at one end to a horn, and is equipped with a round or square eye, one or two beakhorn stakes, and a foot sometimes ending in a base. Used as a support when forging metal pieces.

A tool with a tapered rectangular or horn-shaped head which typically has a shaft extending downward on one side but may also extend downward from the centre of the head. Used for shaping sheet metal or for finer shaping and finishing any metal.
A tool with a roughly T-shaped head which has a small conical horn at both ends. Used as a form for bending metal.
Atool with a rectangular or square head. Used as a form to fashion the hind of a large bolt or rivet or for hammering over the rivets when joining the hoops.

A tool with either a T-shaped head with top part of the T being triangular in cross-section forming a wedge-shaped working surface. Used as a form to forge the cutting angle on the blade of a hatchet.

A tool with a T-shaped head which has a flat roughly rectangular working surface that tapers slightly at each end. A series of rounded grooves are cut width wise and are arranged parallel to each other from one end to the other. Used as a form for hand-creasing, wiring and forming small tubes.
A metal tool consisting of a roughly T-shaped head with a narrow conical horn at one end and a triangular surface at the opposite end. Used as a form for shaping rings.
A metal tool with a T-shaped head which tapers to a roughly conical horn on both sides. Inserted in a wooden block or in the eye of an anvil, and used to form small cylindrical or conical pieces.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for working with natural stone or with aggregate materials such as concrete, mortar, brick, or plaster.  These aggregate materials can be of natural or manufactured origin.
