They differ from materials related to Glass, Plastics & Clayworking T&E because they lack homogeneity and the need for complex processing.
A tool consisting of a triangular metal blade with round edges, attached perpendicularly to a wooden handle raised up at a 90° angle from the blade. Used to apply or smooth mortar or plaster.
A tool consisting of a rectangular metal blade attached to a wooden handle raised up at a 90° angle from the blade. Used for applying mortar on bricks.
A tool consisting of a quadrangular metal blade perpendiculary attached to a wooden handle raised up at a 30-90° angle from the blade. Used for pointing up joints or removing old mortar from a wall.
A wooden or metal rectangular receptacle with a flat bottom and a handle at both ends. Used to hold mortar for mixing by hand.
A wooden instrument consisting of a V-shaped trough and a shoulder pad, and attached to a long handle. Used to carry bricks or mortar to the mortar board.
A tool consisting of a rectangular tray attached perpendicularly to a wooden handle. Used to carry plaster or mortar.
A metal implement consisting of a ruler with a mobile arm perpendicularly attached to it by means of a tightening-screw. Used to measure angles on stone blocks.
A metal tool consisting of a thin square blade extending from a handle. Used for spreading and smoothing plaster or mortar on a surface.
A tool consisting of an iron head tapering to a vertical cutting blade on both ends, attached to a wooden handle. Used for cutting, trimming and dressing brick or stone.

A tool onsisting. The shaft has either several notches along both sides, beginning midway and ending at a rounded tip, or a round or squarish head with one notch on either side of it. There may sometimes be a hook or a loop at the end of the handle for hanging. Used for removing slate and prying up nails from roofs.
A rasp consisting of one or more rows of jagged teeth fastened along the underside of an iron or wooden arched handle. Used to smooth the rough surface of a stone.
A metal tool consisting of a pointed cone at one end and a rectangular striking head at the other. Used to split or cut stone.
A tool consisting of a two-point metal head attached perpendicularly to a wooden handle. Used to trim or smooth out the surfaces of a stone block.
A tool consisting of an iron with two blades perpendicularly inserted into a wooden head attached to a handle. Used to dress millstones and to give them a corrugated surface.
A wooden tool consisting of a cylindrical head attached perpendicularly to a handle. Used to strike some tools (chisels, drills, pitching tools) when working stone.
A metal tool consisting of a curved-end rod with a perpendicular handle. Used to smooth out mortar joints between bricks and stones.

A tool consisting of a metal head with a flat face at one end and a long, curved point at the other, attached perpendicularly to a wooden handle which is inserted into an eye. Used to cut brick and to set it into the mortar.

A tool consisting of a metal head with a flat face at one end and a straight cutting peen at the other, attached perpendicularly to a wooden handle. Used to rough out and shape the surface of a stone block.
A metal tool consisting of an octogonal rod with a point at one end, and a round striking head at the other. Used to bore holes in stone.
A metal tool consisting of a rod with a cutting edge at one end and a striking head at the other end. Used to mark, rough or split a free stone.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for processing materials that are animal in origin.  This class includes tools and equipment for processing furs or hides, for preparing leather, for fabricating leather products, for working shell, horn, bone, or ivory, and for making things from quills or feathers.  This class also includes objects for processing materials that are the products of insects or bacteria.

A tool consisting of a metal one or two interchangeable metal wheels with serrated edges, and a curved or bent forked shank on which the wheel is mounted and secured by a thumbscrew. The shank is set in a handle,usually made of turned wood. Used to mark leather for even stitching and to assist awls or needles in piercing leather.

A triangular, hand-carved solid wooden stretching frame with round edges, and usually with a small hole in one of the corners of the base through which a wire is attached for hanging. Used to stretch and dry uncut pelts by pulling them down over the frame.
A tool consisting of a solid iron bar, oval in cross-section, with one flat striking end and one end slightly jagged. Used to set rivets, snaps and other fasteners.
A wooden tool which has deep concave grooves or square notches at one or both ends. Used by to soften right - angle cuts into smooth edges by rubbing the groove of the tool against the leather edge.
A tool consisting of a rod with a striking head at one end and a concave groove or small hole at the other which is designed to fit over a rivet head. Used to set rivets without marking them.
A tool consisting of a bone with a Y-shaped antler or handle. Used by Indigenous peoples to scrape hides.

A metal tool consisting of a straight striking handle and a head which has varying shapes in cross section, such as flat or curved, and which has a serrated cutting edge. Used to cut shapes with scalloped edges for ornamentation in leather.

A metal tool with a straight striking handle which either has a continuous taper or tapers only near the point, which may come in various cross-sections, such as circular, semi-circular, and flat. Used to pierce rough holes in leather where clean cut holes are not important.
A metal tool consisting of a straight striking handle and a tapered flat chisel-like blade. Used to punch flat slits in leather.

A metal tool consisting of a jaw two metal pivoted limbs, forming a pair of jaws and a pair of handles arranged as levers. One jaw is fitted with an interchangeable metal nipple. The other has an anvil pad made of a softer metal. Used to punch holes in leather.

A metal tool consisting of a straight striking handle and a tapering head with a chisel-shaped blade on one side and a more or less conical blade on the other. The conical blade varies in shape in cross-section from circular to tear-shaped. Used to cut a circular or tear-shaped button hole with a slit to one side.
A metal tool consisting of two cutting jaws extending from two articulated arms. Used to remove or cut small nails that are used to make a sole.

A metal tool consisting of iron pliers with downturned, serrated jaws and a square or round anvil, which serves as a fulcrum, projecting from the lower jaw. Used to pull leather over a last in order to tack it in place.

A plain protecting thimble with a shallow pear-shaped honeycombed well which extends into a thin round neck which may be either straight or cranked. Used for driving collar or harness needles through leather.
A tool consisting of a slender rod, straight or curved, with a diamond-shaped point at one end and a head with an eye at the other. Used to pass the thread for blind stitches.
A needle with a blunt point. Used to pass thread in order to butt two pieces of leather together.
A needle which is round in cross-section at the top, but three sided towards the point. Used to stitch soft leathers, suedes and furs, without the use of an awl.

A machine consisting of a metal frame equipped with a roller, a cutting blade and a thumb screw. Used to shave or thin leather by drawing it through the roller and against the blade, or between the back of the block and the blade.

A punch consisting of steel strips forged into popular shapes. The lower edge is bevelled and sharpened on the outside, but the upper edge may also be sharpened in order to avoid the need for separate left and right dies. Used to cut out common leather shapes. The leather to be cut is laid out on a hard surface, and a hand or power press forces the die through the leather. Some are designed to be driven with a hammer.

A wooden molding form in the shape of the human foot and ranging as widely in size. A leather or metal patch is often attached in order to modify the shape according to fashion or physical change. It often has a detachable instep and a hole through the heel for the last hook. Used for making and repairing shoes, boots and socks.
A metal tool consisting of a stem attached to a base. Used to support a last while it is worked upon.

A stuffing toolconsisting of a round or flat, flexible iron rod attached by a brass ferrule to a turned wood handle. The tip or the rod is flat, may be curved, and may have teeth or a slotted eye. Used by harness makers and saddlers to stuff flock into cart saddle panels or to stuff the cantle and other parts of riding saddles.
A tool consisting of a metal rod curved at one end and attached perpendicularly to a wooden handle at the other end. Used for pulling out the last from a finished or partly finished shoe.

A light hammer with a long, usually strapped head consisting of a round face and a cross pein which tapers to a narrow edge. A claw is occasionally provided at either the end of the handle or the side of the pein. Used by saddlers to hammer tacks into saddle trees, either by using the round face or, in otherwise inaccessible areas, the tapered edge of the pein.

A tool consisting of a solid forged steel head with a convex mushroom-shaped face and a slightly downturned cross pein. The handle is usually wooden. Used for driving nails, shaping damp leather or levelling off seams.

A chisel with a trough-shaped blade which usually has a concave cutting edge, ranging from 2 cm to 5 cm wide. The blade is often attached to a curved metal shank which is set in a handle usually made of turned wood. Used by all types of leatherworkers to cut channels or grooves in leather for decoration or for folding.

A tool shaped pin with a sharp point set through a short metal shaft and attached to a turned wood handle. A tiny hole above the pin point feeds through the cut line of leather. Used to cut a groove in the grain side of leather. Holes are punched and stitches sewn in this groove in order to protect the seam from wear.
A tool consisting of a smooth iron attached to a wooden handle. Used to give a lustre to the surface of leather.

A metal or wooden tool consisting of an adjustable sliding ruled beam attached to removable metal blade attached to a ruled beam made of either wood or metal, which slides through a slot in the side of the handle. A thumbscrew holds the beam in position. Used to cut even strips in leather at adjustable widths.

A instrument with a wide, straight, tapered, blade which typically has a circular cross-section and is set in a handle usually made of turned wood. Used to enlarge holes. Also used to separate thongs for braiding leather whips.

A tool consisting of a metal blade shave plane of many designs, such as: (1) A sharpened rectangular steel blade with two tangs, one on either side, that are set into the sides of a two-handled wooden stock. The blade may be adjusted by wing nuts or simply by pushing the blade tangs further back into the stock. (2) A long rectangular steel blade set against an elliptical steel plate and attached at each end to a wooden handle by a brass ferrule. Used to thin, trim, round and smooth traces, backbands and other straps after stitching.

A tool consisting of a trough-shaped head which has a straight cutting edge. The head is attached to a curved metal shank , which is set in a handle, usually made of turned wood. Used to sewn together, their combined thickness is approximately equivalent to the thickness of one unshaved piece of leather.
A tool usually consisting of a sharp-edged metal blade set in line with a wooden handle by means of a brass ferrule or rivet. Used to cut, thin or skive leather.
A tool consisting of a round head, equipped with a blade and a guide, and attached to a wooden handle. Used to remove the excess of leather around the heel seat.
A tool consisting of a rectangular blade fixed to a wooden handle. Used to cut leather and wax thread.
A knife with a square, broad, round or tapered blade. Used in a pushing motion to thin the edges of leather pieces in order to provide a close non-binding fit whenever leathers are joined.
A knife with a sharply curved, hook blade sharpened usually only along the outside edge. Used to cut holes for buckle tongues, and other circular shapes in leather.

A tool consisting of a double-edged rectangular blade with handles at both ends. One handle is in line with the blade, and the other is at a right angle to it. Useds to level and shave leather to a desired thickness.
A tool consisting of a flat circular steel blade, which is mounted on a curved forked metal shank, that is set in a handle usually made of turned wood. Used for cutting of thin leather.
A tool consisting of a flat metal shank flaring to a V-shaped blade, and fixed to a wooden handle. Used to remove the sharp angles and round off the edges of a thick leather piece.

A creasing tool with a blunt blade or blades made of steel, wood or bone, usually having a curved shank set in a handle made of turned wood. It varies in length, width and the shape of the head, depending on the type. Used to produce creases for decoration, for channels for stitches, or for folding.

A creaser with a shank that tapers to a split triangular head. A thumbscrew on the head adjusts the width of the split. Used to make creases equidistant for the edge of leather at adjustable widths for sewing and decoration.
A creaser with a shank that tapers to a flanged and grooved head, and is set in a handle. Used to make creases equidistant from the edge of leather for sewing and decoration.
A holding device consisting of two large springy wooden convex jaws attached by screws or hinges. Used to keep the work firmly in place for stitching.
A metal tool consisting of an iron equipped with a row of short and flat teeth, extending from a short rectangular handle with a head. Used for marking the lines preparatory to stitching.

A groover consisting of a split steel head and shank and a handle usually made of turned wood. The head has a blade-mount and a fence. A metal blade is attached to the mount by one screw. Used to cut closable slits for concealing or protecting stitching.

A storage wrap consisting of a leather rectangular backing piece with a leather strap sewn longitudinally at spaced intervals onto the backing to produce loops. Used to hold and store leather punches.
A flexible stitching implement consisting of a single hog's bristle. Used to draw thread through curved holes made by an sewing awl which rigid needles are unable to navigate.

A wooden work station with a flat surface which has a metal setting for a collar vice at one end and is supported by two to four legs usually bridged by a wooden cross-bar. The surface is often rectangular but may have a roughly oval end under the collar vice setting. Used to support a collar vice and to provide a surface for tools for making horse collars.

A wooden work station consisting of a table and seat usually joined but may be separate. The table is organised into compartments and sometimes has drawers. The attached table and seat is set low to the ground on four short legs. The separate table and seat each have four short legs. Used by cobblers as a working area and as a storage table for tools.
A tool consisting of a short pointed metal blade, either curved or straight, fixed to a wooden haft. Used for piercing and marking leather and sometimes used for stitching.

A tool consisting of a curved or sometimes S-shaped metal blade, which is tapered towards the point and has a flat oval cross-section. Used to pierce curved oval holes in leather for sewing with a sewing bristle.
A tool consisting of a straigth slender metal blade set in a wooden haft. Used for piercing a hole in thin leather to allow the smooth passage of the needle and sewing thread.

A tool consisting of a straight slender metal blade, which is tapered towards a sharp point and has a circular cross-section. It is set in a short stubby handle. Used to make lines or holes in leather.
A tool consisting of a metal blade with a diamond-shaped point inserted into a round wooden handle. Used for making holes in leather for easy lacing with leather threads.
A tool consisting of a short metal blade, curved and stubby, fixed to a wooden haft with a round end. Used to bore holes in a sole to prepare for the insertion of wooden shoe peg.

An awl with a straight steel blade, tapered towards the point with a diamond-shaped cross-section. It is set in a palm-sized handle. Used for making diamond-shaped holes, which, having corners, enables the stitching to set better.
A tool consisting of a straight tapered blade with a circular cross-section. It is set in a handle of varying designs. Used for making and enlarging holes in leather.
A tool consisting of a long metal blade with an eye at its point, set in a wooden haft. Used to pass a thread or leather thong through thick leather.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for fabricating objects from homogenous, complex compounds, such as glass, clay, rubber, synthetic resins, plastics, or waxes.  This class also includes the tools, equipment, and supplies used for producing such homogenous, complex compounds.  These compounds differ from other materials because they generally require elaborate processing at some point during their use.  As compounds, they differ from other processed materials such as leather because they are not discrete units; they differ from aggregate materials such as masonry because of their homogeneity and their need for elaborate processing.

A tool consisting of a wooden rod which tapers to a point or sharpened tip at one end; equipped with a loop of wire or a strip of metal at the other end. Used to work clay, particularly by scooping out the centre of a block.
A flat-bottomed, round metal receptacle with a metal handle on the side; equipped with a lid. Used to contain matter to be melted.
A flat, thin, often diamond-shaped piece of metal. Used to hold a pane of glass in a window frame as the putty is setting.

A metal receptacle consisting of one or more tapered tubes closed at one end joined at the top to a perforated tray and a base at the bottom; often equipped with handles. Used to hold liquid tallow or wax inserted with a wick, in order to give it a shape as the candle sets.

A metal instrument consisting of a half-round receptacle joined to a rectangular, wedge-shaped trough with a series of nozzles on the side; equipped with a handle. Used to pour liquid wax or tallow into several tubes of a candle mold at the same time.

A metal tool consisting of a notched head equipped with a hardened steel cutting wheel at one end and a guide wheel at the other; fixed to a handle with a knob at the end. Used to score sheet glass, in order to facilitate breaking it in a straight line.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the management and harvesting of forests. This class includes objects used for cutting, handling, or processing timber or for harvesting non-food forest crops such as bark or rubber. This class does not include equipment for cartage, which is classified under Transportation Objects, or equipment for manufacturing products from wood, which is classified under Woodworking T&E or Papermaking T&E.
An oblong receptacle consisting of a hollowed-out plank or split log. Set in the snow at the foot of a sugar maple tree, used to collect the sap as it falls from the spout.
An implement consisting of a semi-circular blade fixed to a long wooden pole handle. Used to harvest the tree bark needed for tanning skins.

An implement consisting of a thin, trapezoidal piece generally of beveled whalebone, with an opening at the top. Used to crush, separate and soften cedar bark fibres, in order to render them more pliable.
A tool consisting of a one or more sharp blades or pointed tines extending from a single, curved tang attached to a wooden handle. Used to score lines lengthwise on a log in preparation for squaring.
An oblong, rectangular, bone implement with sharp concave cutting edges at each end. Used for scraping sap from the inner layer of jack pine bark.
A tool consisting of a stationary, wide, heavy, serrated blade, often wider in the middle, with a wooden handle at each end. Used by two sawyers to cut down trees or square larger diameter trees.

A tool consisting of a stationary, serrated blade strung across an H-shaped frame held tight by a tension cord; equipped with a handle at one end. Used by one or more people to cut logs into proper lengths.
A metal or wooden implement consisting of a round or squared yardstick with a hook or stop at one end and sometimes a loop handle at the other end. Used to determine the cubic volume of a cord wood.

A piece of metal with a pointed tip or sharp edges at one end and an eyelet at the other; sometimes equipped with one or more rings. Used in conjunction with a chain to bind log rafts together or to shackle two snake rafts in line.
An implement consisting of a metal head with a pointed tip at the end and a hooked spike in the middle, fixed to a wooden pole. Used for handling logs during a drive.
A metal device consisting of two inward curving, scissored S-hooks linked at the ends by a chain or a curved metal handle. Used for handling logs.
An implement consisting of a metal head with a pointed tip at one end, fixed perpendicularly to a wooden haft at the other end. Used for handling logs.
A tool consisting of a pointed metal hook or spur attached to a collar that firmly clasps a sharply tipped wooden pole. Used to handle logs.
A tool consisting of a pointed metal hook or hooked arm attached by a pivot or swivelling clasp to the end of a wooden pole. Used to handle logs.
A metal device consisting of a sharpened hook equipped with a ring. Used in conjunction with a pole pike; for handling logs.
A metal device consisting of a grab hook linked by a length of chain to a slip hook. Used to haul logs.

A device consisting of single spike extending perpendicularly from a metal rod with either another right-angle spike or a spurred, pivoting arm at the other end. Used to bind two logs together in order to form a raft.
A tool consisting of a metal head with a raised marking stamp (numbers or letters) attached perpendicularly to a wooden handle. Used to stamp the owner's mark on a log.

A metal instrument consisting of a pair of matching, inward facing arms, one fixed, the other sliding, both attached perpendicularly to graduated scale. Used to measure the diameter of a log or a piece of sawn timber, in order to take an inventory of cubic volume.
An implement consisting of a metal head with a heavy sharp blade at one end, attached perpendicularly to a wooden handle at the other end. Used to cut down and limb smaller trees.

A tool consisting of a sharp tipped, helical screw extending from a long shank with a brace at the end equipped with a pair of free spinning handles, one wrapped around the middle of the brace, the at the end. Used to bore holes in logs in order to pin rafts together in preparation for driving them downriver.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the presentation, serving, or consumption of food or beverages by humans.
Objects originally created as containers in or on which food or beverage is presented or from which food or beverage is served but not directly consumed.
An often squat, potbellied or truncated conical, metal or ceramic receptacle equipped with a spout, a handle and a lid. Used to contain tea is it is steeped and served.
A round metal or ceramic receptacle equipped with a spout, an often right-angle handle, a lid. Used to contain and evenly blend a hot chocolate mixture as it is prepared and served.

A round, gourd-shaped, glass, metal or ceramic receptacle with a wide mouth and flat bottom; often equipped with a spout and a handle and sometimes a lid. Used to hold and pour liquids to be served during a meal.
An often glass, metal or ceramic pitcher. Used to serve water and other liquids during a meal.
A glass, metal or ceramic pitcher; sometimes with a base. Used to hold milk or cream to be served with tea during a meal.

A round, gourd-shaped, flat-bottomed metal receptacle; equipped with a spout, a handle and often a lid with a thumb lever. Used to hold and pour liquids such as wine or cider as they are being served.
A bulb-shaped, narrow-necked glass receptacle with a flaring lip; equipped with a stopper and sometimes a handle. Used to hold alcoholic beverages.
A potbellied or truncated conical, round metal or ceramic receptacle equipped with a spout, a handle and often a lid. Used to contain coffee as it is brewed and served.
A bulb-shaped, narrow-necked glass receptacle, often with a flaring lip. Used to hold liquids (water, juice, etc.) to be served during a meal.

A glass bottle, often covered in wickerwork or meshed wire, containing carbonated water under pressure. It has a screw-on metal lid equipped with a lever, which is attached to a tube inside the bottle for the liquid to pass through. Used to serve carbonated water directly into drinking glasses.
An elongated, round, metal or glass receptacle; equipped with an often round-topped perforated lid. Used to contain and sprinkle powdered sugar to be consumed at a meal.

An elongated, ceramic, metal or glass receptacle; equipped with an often round-topped perforated lid. Often accompanies a saltshaker. Used to contain and sprinkle ground pepper to be consumed at a meal.

An elongated, ceramic, metal or glass receptacle; equipped with an often round-topped perforated lid. Often accompanies a pepper shaker. Used to contain and sprinkle ground pepper to be consumed at a meal.

An often wooden or metal apparatus consisting of cylindrical chamber set over a base equipped with a grinding mechanism turned by a central rod connected to the crank-handle or finial knob on the top.  Used to grind peppercorns into ground pepper.

A deep, oval, round or flat-bottomed, metal, ceramic or glass receptacle; equipped with a hinged lid, sometimes notched for a mustard spoon which may accompany it. Used to hold and serve liquid mustard during a meal.
A glass jar, usually cylindrical with a flat bottom and that has a flat stopper or lid on top. Used to preserve, store and serve pickles.

An often round or oval, glass, ceramic or metal receptacle consisting of a round-bottomed bowl; sometimes set on a base and equipped with a lid. Sometimes accompanied with a small spoon, used to hold salt for seasoning food at the table.

A container usually made of glass, earthenware or silverplate. It usually has a stopper and often has a pouring lip or spout and a handle. Used to hold and serve liquid condiments, such as oil, vinegar or lemon juice, at the table.
A round, flat-bottomed metal receptacle with often perforated, patterned sides. Used to hold a carafe in order to protect the table or tablecloth from condensation.

A deep, often round or oval, metal or ceramic receptacle with a round bottom; often equipped with handles and a base, sometimes with a notched rim, ladle and a stand. Used to hold the soup or stew to be served during a meal.
A flat, often wooden or metal platter with a more or less raised rim; sometimes equipped with handles and feet. Used to hold and carry receptacles, utensils or food items.
A flat-bottomed, often oval, glass, ceramic or metal vessel, sometimes equipped with handles. Used to hold bread to be served during a meal.

A ceramic, glass or metal container consisting of a flat-bottomed tray or wire frame, often with raised sides; equipped with several partitions and centrally fixed handle. Used to hold vials of oil, vinager and vinagrette as it is being served.
A plate mounted on a pedestal; sometimes with raised edges. Used to hold, display and serve a dessert or fruit.

An ornately wrought ceramic, glass or metal centrepiece consisting of a set of branching or upright decorative elements (flowers, fruit, animals, figurines etc.), as well as a receptacle (bowl, vase, etc. sometimes equipped with a functional component (saltshaker, cruet bottle, etc.). Used to decorate the centre of a table.

A metal framework consisting of a series of evenly-spaced, upright arched loops fixed to a base; equipped with feet and a handle. Used to hold several slices of toasted bread upright, in order to keep them free of condensation.
A deep, round or oblong metal or ceramic receptacle equipped with handles, often a spout and sometimes a base, a lid and a stand. Used to hold the sauce to be served with an entrée.
A ceramic, round or oval vessel with a, flat-bottomed depression in the centre and slightly raised rim. Used to hold food to be served during a meal.
An often round or rectangular plate, sometimes equipped with handles. Used to hold food to be served during a meal.
A flat-bottomed, ceramic dish; sometimes set on a base and equipped with a lid and handles. Used to hold vegetables dishes to be served during a meal.
An oval, glass or ceramic dish embellished with a cut or enamelled pattern. Used to hold pickles or relish.

An often rectangular or round, glass or ceramic plate with a slightly raised rim; equipped with a box- or dome-shaped cover with a knob or handle on top. Used to hold cheese to be served during a meal in order to keep it moist.
A lidless bonbon dish. Used to hold and serve candy and sweetmeats.
An often round, metal, ceramic or glass bowl set on a base; equipped with a lid with a knob on top.  Used to hold and serve sweets and nuts.
A metal, ceramic or glass receptacle consisting of a round or rectangular plate with a more or less raised rim; equipped with an often domed cover with a knob on top. Used to hold butter.
A dish of whiteware or glass, either round with curved sides tapering towards a flat bottom, sometimes stands on a pedestal. Used to serve fruit or dessert.

A metal, ceramic or glass receptacle consisting of a dish with a more or less raised, sloping sides set on a pedeftal; sometimes equipped with a cover with a knob on top. Used hold fruit or a dessert as it is being served.
A flat-bottomed, glass, metal or ceramic bowl; equipped with a lid and sometimes handles. Used to hold sugar (granules or cubes) to be consumed durng a meal.
A round or oval receptacle of wood, metal, ceramic, metal or glass, resting on a base, and having a handle. Used to hold fruit.
A flat-bottomed, glass, metal or ceramic receptacle with sloped sides often of openwork; sometimes set on a base and equipped with handles. Used to hold and serve solid food items (fruit and cakes).
An often flat-bottomed woven wicker receptacle with sloping sides and a narrow lip. Used to hold bread as it is being served.
Objects originally created as implements for the serving of food or beverages.  This sub-class does not include tools used for food preparation or consumption.
A metal utensil consisting of two claws or grasping tips extending from a pair of shanks joined by an open loop of sprung metal. Used to grasp a piece/ cube of sugar.
A spoon of about 7 centimeters (3 inches) in length with an often round shallow bowl. Kept with a saltcellar, used to scoop out and serve table salt.
A horn, bone, wooden or metal spoon of about 15 centimeters (6 inches) in length with an often deep round bowl. Sometimes kept with the mustard pot, used to scoop out and serve mustard paste.

A metal instrument consisting of two, wide, short, slightly round-tipped scissored blades with a pair of handles terminating in finger and thumb holes. Used to cut the stemps of a bunch of grapes to be served at the table.
A metal utensil consisting of a wide, oval, openwork blade with a trailing point at one end; attached to a handle. Used to divide a fillet of fish into portion and to serve them.
A metal utensil consisting of a wide, oblong, triangular blade extending from an often slightly curved handle. Used to cut and to serve a piece of pie.
A wooden implement consisting of a narrow head with a flat-nosed blade with shallow sides; attached to a handle. Used to sprinkle salt on fish.

A metal utensil consisting of a semi-spherical bowl extending from a metal or wooden handle, sometimes equipped with a scraper moved in a sweeping motion by a button or lever-operated mechanism. Used to spoon out and shape ice cream or sorbet.
A metal utensil consisting of a wide, round-tipped, unsharpened blade attached to a handle. Used to cut a portion from a piece of cheese.

An often ceramic or metal utensil consisting of a hemispherical bowl extending from a long, curved handle; sometimes equipped with a spout on the lip of the bowl. Used to scoop up liquids in order to serve them.

A wooden or metal utensil consisting of a more or less deep, often flat-bottomed bowl with straight or sloped sides attached to a long handle sometimes equipped with a wooden grip and a hanging device. Used to scoop up water to be drunk or used to prepare food.
A metal knife with a long, thin spined, often straight sharp blade with a trailing or triangular-shaped point. Used to cut off a slice of meat as it is being served.
A metal utensil consisting of a wide, round-tipped, unsharpened blade attached to a handle Used to cut and serve a slice of cake.
A metal knife with a wide, flat unsharpened blade; often equipped with a trailing or clipped point. Used to cut off portions of butter and to spread it.
A knife with a long serrated blade and often a wooden handle. Used to slice bread.

A metal tool consisting of head with a thin half moon-shaped blade on one end and a flat or rounded peen on the other, the whole, fixed to a wooden or metal handle. Used to break a sugarloaf into smaller pieces and to crush them fine granules.
A metal fork with two or three, closely spaced tines with barbs on the ends. Used to spear pickles in order to serve them from an hors d'oeuvre platter.
A fork with a head that measures approximately 5 cm wide and that has 5 tines. Used to serve fish.
A metal fork with two or three long, sharp, tines; sometimes equipped with a hand guard attached to the tine just below the handle. Used to hold meat as it is carved with a carving knife.

Groupings of objects originally created for the presentation, serving, or consumption of food or beverages.  Note: Other terms also may be used to represent specific set components from other Food Service T&E sub-classes.
A matching pair or assortment consisting of a carving knife and a carving fork;  sometimes accompanied with a sharpening steel. Used to cut up a piece of meat.

A matching set, usually of silver or whiteware,  consisting of a coffeepot, a sugar bowl, a cream pitcher and often a serving tray. It sometimes includes coffee cups and saucers. Used for serving coffee.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to facilitate the use of food service vessels, utensils, or related articles.  This sub-class includes food waste containers, dining table coverings, and containers for food service objects.

A rectangular, often metal or wooden container; often divided into two compartments by a partition with a handle cutout in the middle. Used to hold knives and forks and keep them separate and ready for setting a table.

An piece of glassware consisting of an often cylindrical, round-bottomed receptacle embellished with a decoration and sometimes set on a stem and base and equipped with handles. Used to hold teaspoons.
An often metal, cylindrical band, sometimes embellished with a decoration. Used to keep a napkin rolled up at a table setting.
A round, flat-bottomed, shallow, metal receptacle with a flared lip; sometimes equipped with side handles and feet. Used to hold a dish of hot food in order to protect the table or tablecloth.

An often ceramic, glass or metal stand consisting of a horizontal bar with either knobbed or geometrically shaped finials. Used to support the blade of a knife in order to avoid soiling the tablecloth.
An often wicker or metal framework consisting of several rings or round plates fastened to a set of uprights one above the other at regular intervals. Used to hold several pie pans.

A round, perforated ceramic plate with a drain hole in the centre and sometimes equipped with feet or a base. Set over a larger dish, used to hold meat in order to drain any surplus juices or liquids away.

An often round or rectangular piece of patterned or plain cotton, silk or linen cloth; sometimes embellished with lace, embroidery or trim. Used to cover a table in order to protect it from spills and marking during a meal.

A square or rectangular piece of woven fabric; often embellished with a pattern or embroidery, as well as with fringe or lace around the edges, sometimes monogrammed. Folded or rolled and inserted into a napkin ring, used to wipe the mouth or fingers during a meal.
A thin, often rectangular, engraved piece of metal or ceramic equipped with a chain loop. Used to identify the contents of the decanter to which it is attached.
An often flat-bottomed, round, ceramic, glass or metal receptacle with a flared lip, sometimes set on a base. Used to hold toothpicks.
A metal stand consisting of an often decoratively fashioned upright loop or clip set on a base. Used to hold a name card in order to indicate table seating arrangements.

An often round, glass, wooden or metal receptacle with a flat bottom; equipped with handles and sometimes a pedestal base. Filled with ice or cold water, used to chill wine and keep it cold and ready for service.
A ceramic dish equipped with handles. Used to contain bones.
A flat-bottomed, often metal container with a lid; equipped with a handle and sometimes lid fasteners. Used to contain a meal taken outside the home.

A cylindrical flask consisting of double-walled receptacle with a vacuum in the space between the inner and outer walls; equipped with an inner lid and an outer screw cap that can serve as a drinking cup. Used to hold liquids and keep them at a desired temperature.

An often flat-bottomed, rectangular, wicker or straw container equipped with a hinged lid, closure straps, a handle and sometimes inner compartements and accessories (crockery, cutlery, etc.). Used to contain the necessary crockery and cutlery and food items for an outdoor meal.
A round-bottomed, ceramic or glass bowl; sometimes equipped with one or more spouts along the edge of its flaired lip. Used to hold often perfumed water intended for rinsing the fingers after a meal.

Objects originally created as implements for consuming food or beverages.  This sub-class includes tools intended for individual place settings.  It does not include utensils designed for the serving of food or beverages, which are listed in Serving Utensils.
A metal utensil consisting of a shallow, round or oval bowl extending from a flat-ended handle, sometimes embellished with a decoration. Used to scoop food out of a receptacle.
A spoon of about 10 centimeters (4 inches) in length. Used to stir hot tea in a cup.
A spoon with a deep, sometimes rounded bowl measuring about 20 centimeters (8 inches) in length. Used to scoop up and convey a portion of soup or stew to the mouth.
A utensil consisting of a elongated, narrrow bowl extending from a slender handle often with a channel at the end. Sometimes kept with hunting cutlery, used to scoop marrow out of a bone.
A spoon with an often triangular bowl that tapers to a sharp edge sometimes equipped with a set of serrated teeth. Used to separate a grapefruit segment from the pith and to convey it to the mouth.
A spoon measuring about 10 to 12 centimeters (4 to 5 inches) in length. Used to convey a portion of a dessert to the mouth.
A spoon measuring about 14 centimeters (5.5 inches) in length. Used to stir hot coffee in a cup.
An implement consisting of an often sharp, long metal blade; equipped with a heel and attached to a handle. Used to cut food and to spear it as it is being consumed.
A metal knife with a slightly notched, clipped point. Used to cut fish and remove any remaining bones as it is being consumed.

A knife consisting of an unsharpened, 23 centimeters (9 inches), often round-tipped metal blade attached to a handle. Used with a fork to cut and manipulate portions of food as they are being consumed
A metal knife with an unsharpened, 18 centimeters (7 inches) round-tipped blade. Used to cut a dessert as it is being served.

A utensil consisting of two sharp tines inserted into a handle, usually fashioned in the shape of an ear of corn. Used in pairs to grasp each end of a cob of corn in order to facilitate eating the kernels.

A metal fork with three or four tines, sometimes with triangular notch on the inner surface near the tang or with wider outer tines.  Used to spear or scoop up a portion of salad and convey it to the mouth.
A metal fork with three, short, outward curving tines with a blade-like outer edge. Used to separate oyster or mollusk meat from the shell and convey it to the mouth.
A fork approximately 18 centimeters long which is similar in shape to but smaller than a dinner fork. Used to eat food served at a luncheon meal.
A fork, approximately 20cm in length, with wide tines to lift fish away from bones. Used with a fish knife to eat fish.
A metal, 20cm (8 inches) fork with two to four long, slender tines extending from a curved tang. Used convey a portion of food from the dinner plate to the mouth.
A 14cm (5.5 inches) metal fork with three or four long slender tines. Used to convey a portion of dessert to the mouth.
A fork approximately 16 centimeters long joined to a tang extending from a metal handle. Used with a fruit knife for eating whole fruit.
A utensil consisting of a slender, slightly curved, wooden rod finely tapered at one end. Used in pairs to pick up morcels of food in order to convey them to the mouth.

Objects originally created as receptacles from which food is directly consumed.  This sub-class includes containers intended for individual place settings.  It does not include drinking vessels or vessels designed for the presentation and serving of food, which are listed in Serving Vessels.

A round, ceramic plate measuring anywhere from 5.5 to 6 inches with an inner concentric ring or depression in the middle. Used for holding a coffee cup or a teacup in order to collect any liquids that might spill as well as a coffee spoon or a teaspoon.
A deep, round-bottomed, ceramic or metal bowl equipped with one or more side handles and sometimes a lid. Used to hold hot food as it is being consumed.
An often round, wood, metal, glass or ceramic vessel with a slightly recessed, flat bottomed depression in the centre and sometimes a raised rim. Used to hold food as it is consumed during a meal.
A plate with a flat-bottomed depression in the middle and sloping sides; sometimes with a raised rim. Used to hold soup or stew as it is consumed.
A round, ceramic plate measuring anywhere from 20 to 22 centimeters (8 to 8.5 inches). Used to serve salad (as an entrée or hors d'oeuvre) as it is consumed.
An often round ceramic plate measuring anywhere from 20 to 24 centimeters (8 to 9.5 inches). Used to hold food as it is consumed at a midday lunch.
A plate measuring anywhere from 23 to 27 centimeters (9 to 11 inches). Used to hold food as it is consumed during the main course of the main meal of the day.
A plate measuring anywhere from 18 centimeters (7 inches), sometimes decorated with a pattern. Used to hold desserts as they are consumed during the final course of a meal.
An ceramic or glass plate with a shallow flat-bottomed depression in the middle and a sloping rim. Used in conjunction with a cup as a coaster and to hold hot liquids in order to cool them.
A metal or ceramic plate measuring anywhere from 10 to 20 centimeters (4 to 7.75 inches); often round and decorated with a pattern. Used to hold bread and better.
A deep, round-bottomed, ceramic or glass receptacle, often set on a footed base. Used to hold a soft-boiled egg, in order to facilitate eating it.
A glass, wooden or ceramic receptacle with sloping sides; often embellished with a decorative pattern, sometimes set on a base. Used to hold salad as it is prepared and served.

Objects originally created as receptacles from which beverages are directly consumed.  This sub-class includes containers intended for individual place settings.  It does not include eating vessels or vessels designed for the presentation and serving of beverages, which are listed in Serving Vessels.
A glass, ceramic large, cylindrical drinking vessel with one or sometimes two applied handles. Used for drinking liquids or liquid foods such as soup.
A flat-bottomed, cylindrical, metal receptacle; equipped with a handle and sometimes with a glass bottom and a hinged lid with a thumb lever. Used to hold beer.
A curved, semi-conical receptacle fashioned from an animal's horn. Used to hold liquids (water, wine, etc.).
A cylindrical, wide-mouthed, glass receptacle; sometimes with a stem and base. Used to hold liquids as they are being consumed.
A flat-bottomed, cylindrical, often ceramic, metal or glass receptacle; often equipped with a handle. Used to hold liquids as they are being consumed.
An often round-bottomed, ceramic cup with tapered sides; often equipped with a handle and sometimes a base. Often accompanied by a saucer.  Used to hold tea as it is consumed.
A glass with a stem, foot and a shallow circular bowl. Used to hold desserts as they are consumed during the final course of a meal.

A metal or ceramic cup with a flat piece with a hole in the centre fixed horizontally over one side of the rim; equipped with a handle. Used to hold liquids and to keep a man's mustache dry as he drinks.
A metal or ceramic cup with a raised lip or a half-covered mouth above the spout or covered completely with a lid; equipped with a handle. Used to hold liquids as they are being served to invalids.
A glass or ceramic cup, equipped with a handle and sometimes a base. Often accompanied by a saucer.  Used to hold coffee as it is being consumed.

A small, usually round or oval, rigid container of wood, iron, glass, or earthenware with a spout for dispensing liquids, as well as a cork closure and a strap for carrying. Used to carry drinking water and other liquids while travelling. Also used as a receptacle from which to drink.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the processing, storage, and preparation of food or beverages for human consumption.  This class does not include tools for gathering, production, or management of food materials that are listed in Agricultural T&E or Animal Husbandry T&E.

Objects originally created specifically to keep food or beverages, either as pieces of furniture such as cabinets, as appliances such as refrigerators, or as containers such as casks and tea caddies.  This sub-class also includes container accessories such as bungs, stoppers, and stands.  It does not include shipping containers, product packages, general cabinetry, or storage items used for kitchenware or the serving of food.
A wooden, flat-bottomed, truncated conical receptacle bound with wooden or metal hoops, often with a drainage hole and bung in the bottom. Used to contain fish in order to pickle them.
A rack consisting of two wooden X-shaped supports held together by a horizontal crossbar. Used to hold a rum cask on its side in a slightly inclined position.

An apparatus consisting of a metal box divided into multiple compartments equipped with shelves, drawers, one or more doors, a cooling system and sometimes a freezing compartment. Used to keep food items cool or frozen.
A wooden structure consisting of a rectangular frame with feet equipped with a groove at each end. Used to hold a bottle of wine in a slightly inclined horizontal position for service.
A flat-bottomed, bulb-shaped, often earthenware receptacle with a narrow neck; sometimes equipped with a spout, a handle and a stopper. Used to hold and transport liquids.
A deep, round, flat-bottomed, glass or ceramic receptacle, with curved or straight sides and sometimes equipped with handles and a lid. Used to hold food in order to keep it fresh and free of vermin.
A porcelain or ceramic jar, that has a globular body which tapers slightly towards the base and that has a dome-shaped cover. Used to hold spices, tea, and the like.

An often deep, wide-mouthed, ceramic or metal receptacle equipped with a friction fit lid, sometimes a handle, base and decorative embellishment. Used to store cookies and small cakes and keep them fresh.
A cylindrical wooden receptacle bound with metal or wooden hoops; equipped with a lid and handle. Used to preserve fats, especially butter.
A metal utensil consisting of a cylindrical receptacle equipped with a perforated cover and with a handle. Used to contain and sprinkle a powdered or granular substance over a food preparation.
A flat-bottomed, cylindrical ceramic receptacle with a rolled lip, equipped with a crock lid, and sometimes handles. Used to hold foodstuffs.

A cylindrical wooden receptacle consisting of curved staves bound at each end by wooden or metal hoops to a pair of disk-shaped heads; equipped with a bung hole and bung set in the middle of a stave and a tap at the head end. Used to contain alcoholic liquids, particularly spirits.
A round or square, often metal or ceramic container; equipped with a lid and sometimes embellished with a decorative pattern or inscription. Used to store drygoods.
A rectangular, often wooden container divided into two or more compartments; equipped with a lid and often a lock. Used to keep tea leaves dry.

A wooden cabinet divided into two main parts: a set of metal-lined ice chambers and a storage area. The whole is equipped with a set of doors with closures on the front and a set of screened air vents on the side. Used to store food and keep it cool.

An often round, metal or wooden container divided into shallow separate sub-compartments or filled with individual containers set side by side or one over the other; equipped with a lid. Used to keep spices dry and free of vermin.
A wooden container, sometimes equipped with a hinged cover. Used to keep salt dry.
A round, flat-bottomed, bentwood container; equipped with a lid. Used to hold cheese in order to store it and keep it moist.
A round, square or rectangular metal container equipped with a lid, often handles, sometimes embellished with decorative pattern or inscription. Used to store cake and keep it fresh.

A square or rectangular, wooden or metal container equipped with a hinged lid or roll-top, often a set of lateral handles and sometimes embellished with a decorative pattern or inscription. Used to store bread and keep it fresh.
A flat-bottomed, round or truncated conical, wicker container equipped with handles. Used to store dry food ingredients.

Objects originally created to manufacture food products from animals, animal products, grains, vegetables, fruits, or other plant materials.  This sub-class includes tools, equipment, and supplies used in such activities as milling, butchering, cheesemaking, and rendering which are often, but not always, handled outside of the home kitchen.
An implement consisting of a wooden tube with a tapered end, and sometimes equipped with a metal hook. Inserted into the tap hole of a sugar maple in order to channel the sap into a sap bucket.

An often flat, rectangular piece of wood with various shapes hollowed out of it; sometimes made from more than one piece of wood pinned together with dowels. Used to give maple sugar taffy a particular shape.

A flat-bottomed, often cylindrical receptacle consisting of wooden staves tightly bound with metal hoops around a plank bottom, and sometimes equipped with a spout and a handle or hook. Hung on a sap spout, used to collect and carry sugar maple sap.

A wooden utensil consisting of a pair of wooden sticks, fastened together at the flat end with a peg secured with a nail or a leather strap, each stick tapering to a set of rod-shaped handles. Used to extract hot lard out of cooked porkfat by squeezing it in a tightly wrapped cloth.

An apparatus consisting of a crankshaft operated upper runner stone with a grain receiving hole in the centre and curved furrows scored on the underside; a rynd and mace head; and a stationary bedstone. The whole sits in a shallow cylindrical shaped base equipped with a side hole and a frame supporting the crankshaft. Used to grind grain into flour.

A wooden or metal device consisting of a flanged cylindrical chamber fitted with a plunger operated by a lever mechanism or a hand-held knob; sometimes equipped with a bottleneck clamp. Used to insert a cork into a bottleneck.
A metal device consisting of a pair of crimping jaws with an adjusting screw on each side, the whole extending from scissored handles. Used to crimp a metal capsule over a bottle cork.

A wooden device consisting of a grooved roller with free-spinning handles at each end, sometimes used in conjunction with a wooden tray. Used to extract excess buttermilk and moisture from the butter.

An instrument consisting of an alcohol or mecury-filled, sealed glass tube equipped with a temperature gauge and set into a metal plate with a knob on the end. Set into a milk solution, used to measure its temperature.
A truncated conical metal receptacle with a flat bottom fitted with a filter and set on a base, sometimes equipped with handles. Used to strain fresh milk in order to remove debris.
A metal skimmer consisting of a round, perforated plate with a half-round or loop-shaped tab for a handle. Used to remove cream that has risen to the surface of milk.

A metal device consisting of a cylindrical receptacle equipped with a measuring gauge, a faucet, a handle and a lid. Used to contain whole milk so as to allow milkfat to separate from the milk, thereby obtaining cream.

A wooden apparatus consisting of a crank driven screw press set on a frame over a perforated wooden or metal receptacle with a flat base equipped with a gutter and feet. Used to pack cheese curd tightly, thereby extracting excess moisture.
A shallow, flat-bottomed recipient of glass or metal with flaring shoulders. Used to hold fresh milk to allow the cream to rise to the top.
A cylindrical, flat-bottomed wooden or metal container, equipped with a moveable handle. Used to collect milk while milking.
A perforated, square or round metal or wooden mold. Used to give curd cheese a particular shape as it ripens into cheese.
A metal device consisting of a cylindrical receptacle; equipped with a lid and a faucet and set on a perforated firebox with feet. Used to contain liquids (often milk) to be heated.

An apparatus consisting of: a rectangular, guillotine-style metal blade equipped with a wooden handle; a pivoting tripod; a round base equipped with a wooden turnstyle cutting block and sometimes measuring stops. Used to slice wedges from a wheel of cheese.
A cylindrical, narrow-necked, flat bottomed metal receptacle equipped with a handle and lid. Used to contain 32 litres of milk.
A cylindrical, narrow-necked, flat-bottomed metal receptacle with a capacity of less than 5 litres; equipped with a handle and lid. Used to contain and carry cream.
A shallow, flat-bottomed, glass or metal receptacle with sloped sides. Used to contain milk in order to allow cream to rise to the top.

An often cylindrical glass, wide-mouthed receptacle with a glass or metal lid held in place by a threaded metal ring or a wire bail closure. Once sterilized, used to contain food in order to preserve it.
A tool consisting of a slightly concave metal disk fixed to a wooden handle. Used to remove bristles from the skin of a pig.

A utensil consisting of a straight, fine-toothed, serrated metal blade fastened at both ends to a C-shaped frame with a wooden handle attached to one end. Used to cut through the bones or joints of a piece of meat.
A wide bladed knife with a drop point and a handle. Used to cut an animal’s jugular vein.
A knife with a wide, sharp, upward-curving blade equipped with a trailing point and a handle. Used to remove subcutaneous tissue from an animal’s carcass.
A metal device consisting of a series of hooks attached to a central rod or ring equipped with a hanging device. Used to hang several pieces of meat.

A slightly curved, bow-shaped wooden rod equipped with notches in the ends and a hanging device in the middle. Used to hoist up a slaughtered animal and keep its hind legs spread apart in order to facilitate carving it up.
A metal implement consisting of a thick head extending from a handle with a throat and a grip at the end. Used to quarter an animal.

A glass instrument or dropper consisting of a tube with a narrow nozzle at one end and a narrow opening with handles on each side at the other end; sometimes inscribed with a measuring guage along its length. Used to withdraw a small quantity of an alcoholic liquid from an (unbreached or untapped) cask in order taste test it.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for mixing, chopping, grinding, decorating, separating, shaping, extracting, or measuring food or beverages.  This sub-class also includes hearth equipment, devices for cooking and drying, and other miscellaneous tools.  It does not include cooking vessels, food storage equipment, or equipment for processing plants or animals into food products.

A typically round, enclosed dish with a hollow centre. It usually has two handles on opposite sides and has either a hole in the rim or a spout with a cap for pouring hot water into the centre. It may have a dome cover. Filled with hot water, used to keep food hot and ready to serve.
An often round metal apparatusn consisting of a receptacle with handle(s) set on an openwork base equipped with feet and a firebox. Used to hold a receptacle to be heated.
A metal rod with a pointed, sometimes flattened tip at one end and a ring or pulley wheel at the other. Used for holding meat to be roasted.
A metal utensil consisting of a perforated cylindrical receptacle equipped with a perforated lid and a long handle. Used to hold chestnuts to be roasted.

A metal apparatus often consisting of a chain or a rod equipped with a device for vertically adjusting the position of the hook or a ring attached its end. Suspended over the hearth, used to hang a receptacle equipped with a bail handle over a fire.
A rectangular free-standing metal framework with two tiers of horizontal bars, equipped with feet and sometimes a hanging device. Used to hold apples to be roasted.

An apparatus consisting of a wire hook or loop suspended from a metal knob or stub turned by a clockwork mechanism encased in a metal cylinder or framework extending from a rod with a hanging loop on the end. Often equipped with a meat hook, used to rotate one or more pieces of meat over a fire.
A metal utensil consisting of two or three sturdy prongs extending from a handle. Used to spear pieces of meat and hold them over a fire in order to roast them.
A metal framework consisting of a swinging horizontal arm often curved at one end; attached perpendicularly to an upright. Fixed in a fireplace, used to hang a trammel.

A metal utensil consisting of a perforated, funnel-shaped receptacle sometimes equipped with a collar or base and a handle. Used to puree food by straining out solids in order to let liquids pass through.
A utensil consisting of a metal strainer with a long handle. Used to strain gravy of lumps and food particles.

A metal utensil consisting of a wide, shallow perforated bowl extending from a long handle, which sometimes has a hook on the end. Used to remove foam and other undesirable substances floating on the surface of a liquid or to remove food from a liquid cooking medium.

A utensil consisting of a metal recipient with a flat, wire mesh bottom equipped with a wire stirrer which is operated by a crank handle. Used to remove impurities from flour and give it a more uniform and refined consistency.
A receptacle consisting of a flat metal screen set into the bottom of a round, often wooden hoop. Used to sift dry ingredients.

A ceramic or metal utensil consisting of a shallow receptacle with a hollow in the middle separated from the outer rim by two semi-circular slots; equipped with a handle. Used to hold the yolk of an egg as it is separated from the white.
A utensil consisting of a metal or plastic perforated recipient, generally equipped a handle. Used to strain food cooked in water or to hold food to be crushed after cooking.
A utensil consisting of a set of U-shaped, wicker, wooden or metal filaments inserted by their ends into a handle of wood or metal. Used to whip food ingredients into a mixture.
An iron rod with a squared tip at one end and a round knob or wrought finial at the other. Used to stir and heat hot punch and to keep it warm.

A horn, wooden or metal utensil consisting of a round or oval bowl extending from a flat-ended handle, sometimes with a hole or a hanging hook on the end. Used to transfer food ingredients from one place to another or to stir a food preparation.
A wooden implement consisting of a flat, oblong blade extending from a shaft with somtimes a knob at the end. Used to stir large quantities of liquid food ingredients.

A metal device consisting of a dough hook and crank handle set into the centre of the lid of a truncated conical receptacle equipped with handles. Used to knead the various bread making ingredients together in order to make dough.
A metal device composed of one or two intermeshing whisks powered by a crank or a mechanism often exquipped with a handle. Set into a bowl, used to beat liquid eggs or to whip liquids into a froth.
An often metal utensil consisting of a solid or perforated, thin, round, oblong, oval or rectangular plate extending from a rod sometimes equipped with a handle at the end. Used to handle food.
A wooden utensil consisting of an open-ended receptacle attached to a handle. Used to transfer loose foodstuffs from one container or receptacle to another.
A wooden or metal implement consisting of a round or rectangular paddle attached to a long handle sometimes equipped with a hanging loop on the end. Used to slide baked goods into and out of an oven.
A metal utensil consisting of a pair of curved, spring steel arms extending a hinged mechanism. Used to grasp the sides of a hot pie pan, in order to carry it without burning the hands.
A utensil consisting of a metal hemispherical bowl extending from a wooden handle; sometimes equipped with a hanging device. Used to to spoon out liquids.
A club-shaped instrument of wood, porcelain, metal or stone. Used to grind food ingredients in a mortar.

A round-bottomed, metal, porcelain, wood or stone receptacle with thick, circular, tapered sides, sometimes equipped with a spout. Used to hold substances to be ground into a powder or paste by the pounding action of a pestle.
A metal device consisting of a hopper, with a lid and a crank handle operated grinding mechanism; equipped with a clamping device. Used to grind spices finely.

An apparatus consisting of a hopper with a crank handle operated grinding mechanism at the bottom, the whole fixed to a lidded receptacle or a base equipped with a clamping device. Used to grind nuts finely.
An apparatus consisting of a metal hopper with a crank-handle operated grinding mechanism in the center, set over a receptacle equipped with a drawer. Used to grind coffee beans.

A metal apparatus consisting of a hopper; an open-ended cylinder equipped with crank-operated screw conveyor, a rotating knife and a perforated end plate; the whole is set on a mounting frame fitted with a table clamp. Used to mince meat finely.

A metal utensil consisting of a flat-headed plunger set into a frame equipped with a truncated cone at the plunger head end and a pair of gripping rings at the handle end. Used to pit a stone fruit without damaging it.
A metal device consisting of a feeding funnel and hopper, a rubber roller and a toothed wheel mechanism which is operated by a crank handle, and a clamp. Used to remove seeds from raisins.
A metal instrument consisting of a slender rod with a slightly curved end. Used to separate the shell of a cracked nut or to remove the meat from the shell.
A metal device consisting of either two curved, serrated jaws extending from the ends of a pair of scissored handles. Used to crack the shell of a nut.
A metal utensil consisting of a pair curved jaws, one smooth, the other toothed, extending from a pair of shanks joined by a pivot. Used to crush a lemon cut in half, in order to extract the juice.
A glass utensil consisting of a ribbed blunt cone set in the center of a shallow bowl, sometimes equipped with a spout and a handle. Used to extract and collect juice from citrus fruit.

An aparatus consisting of an auger turned by a crank handle-operated mechanism set into a conical receptacle with a feed hole on the upper surface of one end and a drain hole and filter at the other. Used to extract juice from fruit.

A metal utensil consisting of a plunger inserted into a cylinder equipped with a nozzle at one end and a pair of gripping rings at the plunger handle end. Used to contain and pipe icing onto a pastry or cake in order to decorate it.

A wooden device consisting of a deep, rectangular bottomless container equipped with a crossbar guide and patterned plunger with handle. Used to give a pat of butter a shape and to embellish it with a pattern.

A utensil consisting of a round, rotating blade with indentations attached to a metal or wooden handle sometimes, equipped with a patterned edge for making cutouts. Used to cut rolled pastry dough and embellish it with a pattern.
A metal apparatus consisting of a circular blade attached to an axle turned by a crank handle-operated mechanism set on a mounting frame or base. Used to slice meat.

A utensil composed of a movable metal frame equipped with multiple sharp wires, the whole attached to a plastic or metal base with an oval-shaped depression hollowed out of it. Used to slice hard-boiled eggs.
A metal utensil consisting of a wire attached at both ends to an often C-shaped frame equipped with a handle. Used to cut firm cheeses.
An implement consisting of a metal blade with a series of teeth on one end, attached to a wooden handle at the other end. Used to shave chips off a block of ice.
An implement consisting of a sharp pointed metal rod inserted into a wooden handle. Used to break pieces off a block of ice.
A utensil consisting of a sharp, demi-spherical blade with a sharp, central slit and sometimes ridged edges attached to a handle. Used to peel vegetables.

A device consisting of a synchronized moving blade and rotating skewer mechanism powered by a crank-operated set of gears; the whole is set on a plank or a mounting frame fitted with a table clamp. Used to peel fruit.
An implement consisting of a sharp blade attached to a handle. Used to cut foodstuffs.
A utensil consisting of a narrow blade with a sharp point, attached to a wooden handle. Used to peel vegetable and fruit.
A knife with a short, thick, round-tipped blade equipped with a metal guard and a short wooden handle. Used to open an oyster.
A knife with a fine narrow blade with a slender trailing point and a handle. Used to remove the bones from a fish.
A utensil consisting of a short metal blade, curved and sharp, and attached perpendicularly to a wooden handle. Used to chop herbs and condiments with an alternative movement in a bowl.
A knife with a long, wide, straight blade, a fine cutting edge, a straight point and a handle. Used to chop and mince food.
A knife with a wide, thick, sharp blade with a trailing point and a wooden handle. Used to carve up large pieces of meat.
A knife with a sharp slender blade, a straight point, a thin spine and a handle. Used to remove meat from the bone.
A utensil consisting of a wide, straight blade with a thick spine and a wooden handle. Used to cut and carve up large pieces of meat.

A utensil consisting of a flat or curved piece of sheet metal with abrasive, raised cutting slots or holes, often equipped with a handle, sometimes shaped into a cylinder or rectangle. Used to reduce solid food into strips, crumbs or small pieces.

A utensil often consisting of a flat, rectangular piece of wood with raised edges on the upper surface; equipped with an angled slot inset with a metal blade in the middle and sometimes a handle at one end. Used to slice vegetables.

A metal utensil composed of two jaws ending in half moon-shaped blades extending from scissored shanks with handles on the ends, sometimes attached to a wooden mounting plate. Used to cut a block of sugar into smaller pieces.
blade along one edge and a wooden or rolled metal handle along the opposite edge. Used to cut, pick up and portion dough and to clean the kneading surface.
A metal implement consisting of a blade bent at a right angle extending from a handle. Used to clean off dough from a dough trough or to cut it into smaller portions.

A metal utensil consisting of an inner and an outer ring-shaped cutting blade fastened perpendicularly to a flat, ring-shaped metal plate often equipped with a handle. Used to cut out doughnuts from a piece of rolled out dough.
A metal utensil consisting of a sharp blade bent into a particular shape, often fixed to a handle. Used to cut a piece out by pressing the blade edge into the dough.
A metal utensil consisting of a sometimes pointed, tubular blade attached to a wooden or metal handle. Used to remove the core of a piece of fruit.

A utensil consisting of a wide rectangular or semi-circular blade fixed to a wooden T-handle or two perpendicularly attached end handles. Used to cut foodstuffs (meat, vegetables and herbs) into small pieces.

A device consisting of two glass bulbs connected by a narrow neck of glass with only one end filled with sand, the whole encased in a wooden frame. Used to measure cooking time according to the rate of the flow of sand from one bulb to the other.
An instrument consisting of an alcohol or mecury-filled, sealed glass tube equipped with a temperature gauge. Used to measure the temperature of a liquid.

A metal utensil in the shape of a cylindrical receptacle ending in a nozzle, often equipped with a hanging loop and sometimes lateral handles and wooden plunger. Used to stuff casings when making sausages or black or white pudding.
A metal spoon with a deep oval bowl and a long handle. Used to scoop up liquids in order to baste a cooking food preparation.
A flat, rectangular piece of marble. Used to cool a batch of confectionery.
A pointed wooden or metal rod, sometimes with a ring at one end. Used to hold pieces of food to be roasted.
A flat-bottomed, metal receptacle with high sides; sometimes equipped with handles. Used to contain and give a culinary preparation a particular shape as it cooks or solidifies.
An often round, ceramic or metal mold with decoratively embossed bottom and sides. Used to contain gelatine as it solidifies.
A rectangular, square or round wooden mold equipped with a sometimes patterned press fixed to a handle. Used to give butter a particular shape as well as to decorate it.
A wooden utensil consisiting of a rectangular paddle with grooves on one side. Used to shape butter it into a pat.
An implement consisting of a serrated blade with a trailing point or a coarse grater, attached to a wooden handle. Used to scrape the scales off fish.

A iron implement consisting of a disk attached to a long rod; sometimes equipped with a knob-shaped handle or hanging loop at the end. Heated in glowing coals and held over a food preparation to broil or brown it.
A wire or wicker mesh grid set on a raised, round or square base. Used to hold freshly baked goods for cooling.
A metal utensil consisting of a perforated metal receptacle with a handle equipped with a hinged lever and plunger mechanism attached to the rim. Used to crush fruits and vegtetables into puree.
A marble, porcelain, glass or wooden utensil consisting of a smooth cylinder, often equipped with a handle at each end. Used to flatten and roll out dough.

A device consisting of a straight blade and hook or a cutting wheel and knurled roller mechanism operated by a crank handle or electric motor; attached to a handle or a mounting frame. Used to open a preserving can.
A metal utensil consisting of a keyhole-shaped loop with tabs on the inner surface of the wide end or a flat bar with a hole or tab punched in one end. Used to remove the cap from a bottle.
A device consisting of a pointed metal helix, sometimes set inside a bell-shaped socket, attached perpendicularly to a wooden, metal or bone handle. Used to pull a cork out of the neck of a bottle.
An instrument consisting of a hollow, metal rod with a sharp tip at one end and one or more eyelets at the other. Used to thread strips of pork fat known as lardons into a piece of meat.
A spoon with an oval metal bowl inscribed with measurement markings; often equipped with a spout and a handle. Used to measure out precise quantities of liquids, in order to add it to a food mixture.

A utensil consisting of a glass, metal or plastic receptacle with sides inscribed with units of measure; equipped with a handle and often a spout along its lip. Used to contain a specified quantity of solid or liquid foodstuffs in order to measure it.
A utensil consisting of an openwork wire grid welded perpendicularly to a pair of metal rods inserted into a wooden handle. Used to render cooked vegetable solids into puree.
A utensil consisting of a cylindrical or rectangular, wooden or metal head equipped with pyramid-shaped teeth, attached to a wooden or metal handle. Used to tenderize raw cuts of meat.
A wooden or metal utensil consisting of either a solid or openwork head attached to a handle. Used to crush cooked foods (potatoes, apples, beans, etc.).
A wooden tool consisting of a flat, round head attached to a handle. Used to pack kraut in lacto-fermentation jars when making sauerkraut.
A utensil consisting of a bowl-shaped mesh recipient equipped with a handle. Used to hold loose tea in hot water.
A perforated metal receptacle consisting of two separable halves; equipped with a chain and hook. Used to hold tea leaves as they steep in hot water.
A funnel with a round receptacle and long narrow nozzle; sometimes with a partially fluted spout. Used to aerate wine as it is being poured.
A hollow ceramic device consisting of an often conical or bird-shaped base tapering to a vent at the top. Placed in the centre of the pie, used to let the heat and steam escape from under the crust.

An often wooden or metal utensil consisting of a conical receptacle with a nozzle of various lengths or mouth at the small end, sometimes equipped with a handle and a filter. Used to facilitate channeling liquids or fine-grained substances into a receptacle.
A tall, cylindrical container with a lid on top and a spigot at the base. It often has two handles on either side and is fitted with a filter on the inside. Used to hold, filter, and pour water.
A wooden rack consisting of several spikes radiating out from a central rod equipped with a hanging loop or hole. Used to hold bunches of herbs as they dry.
An often round or rectangular, wicker or wooden openwork grid set in a frame. Used to hold fruit as it dries or cheese as it drains.
A device consisiting of a rounded piece of wood equipped with several metal spikes, a cord and hanging hook. Used to hold ears of corn as they dry.
A metal device consisting of a grid, frame or openwork structure, often extending from a long handle. Used to hold one or more slices of bread in order to toast them.

A device consisting of a metal spit which may be equipped with a number of hooks, loops at one or both ends for hanging and a rotating mechanism. Used for holding meat to be cooked over an open flame or other heat source.
A device consisting of a cylindrical metal receptacle with sealable opening; attached to a long rod with a wooden handle at the end. Used to hold coffee beans to be roasted.
A metal utensil consisting of an often rectangular wire mesh container with a lid; attached to a rod with sometimes a handle at the end. Held over a fire, used to hold popcorn kernels.
A metal device consisting of a frame equipped with an openwork plate on top and a fuel tank or heating element and a footed base. Used to heat a receptacle filled with solid or liquid food.
A round glass or metal receptacle equipped with a spout, a handle and sometimes a filter. Used to hold coffee grounds and water to be made into coffee.

A metal device consisting of a pair of often rectangular, hinged plates cast with a patterned set of depressions on the inner surfaces and equipped with a handle on the edge of each plate. Used to contain the waffle batter and give it a particular shape as it cooks over a fire.
An oval or round, stone or metal plate with a low rim; sometimes equipped with a bail handle, feet or a long handle. Set directly over a fire, used to contain pancake batter as it fries.
A flat-bottomed, ceramic receptacle with curved sides; equipped with a lid. Used to contain food to be cooked slowly.

A metal appliance consisting of range with several burners set over an oven, sometimes equipped with a boiler, a storage drawer and set on a base. Fueled with wood, gas or electricity; used to cook food.
A metal device consisting of a grill or openwork plate set over one or more burners fixed to a fuel tank equipped with burner controls. Used to hold a receptacle in order to heat it.
A metal framework consisting of a rectangular, trapezoidal or round grate extending from a long handle, often equipped with feet. Used for holding food to be cooked over a fire.
A metal device consisting of a receptacle with feet; equipped with a handle and sometimes a grill and an ash pan. Filled with solid fuel, used to hold a receptacle in order to heat it.
A deep, flat-bottomed, hooped, truncated-conical, wooden receptacle equipped with a cover and a handle. Used to contain food preserved in multiple layers of salt.
A rectangular wooden container often set on a four-legged frame and equipped with a lid. Used to hold bread dough as it is kneaded and as it rises.

A metal apparatus consisting of a truncated conical or cylindrical receptacle fitted with a rotating cylindrical tumbler turned by the means of a crank-operated mechanism or an electric motor; the whole equipped with a bail handle and a lid. Used to make ice cream or sherbet.
A round, narrow rimmed bowl in metal, glass or ceramic with sloped sides. Used to hold ingredients to be combined.
An often round, wooden receptacle with curved sides. Used to hold food to be chopped.
A round or oblong wicker or wooden receptacle with low flared sides, sometimes fitted with a cloth cover. Used to hold bread dough as it rises and shape it into a loaf in preparation for baking.
A utensil consisting of an arrangement of stiffen fibres or bristles often attached to a handle. Used to scrub fruits and vegetables.

A utensil consisting of a bundle of long supple bristles bound together with a metal ferrule and fixed to a metal or wooden handle. Used to apply a thin layer of beaten egg, melted butter or glaze on pastries before baking.
A usually rectangular, smooth, flat piece of wood, sometimes equipped with a shallow groove around the edges and a handle. Used to hold food to be chopped, sliced or cut.
A thick, often round, flat-topped piece of wood set on a base. Used as a surface for cutting meat.
