Objects that facilitate the preparation of food or beverages but do not play an active role in food preparation.  This sub-class includes objects used specifically for the handling, maintenance, or storage of kitchenware.
An apparatus consisting of a metal lined box, equipped with a heater, set on legs, fitted with regularly spaced shelves and a door. Used to heat or keep dishes warm.
A metal stand consisting of a ring or openwork plate equipped with three or four feet and sometimes a handle. Used to hold a receptacle above burning coals in a fireplace in order to heat it.

An accessory generally made of ceramic, consisting of a receptacle, sometimes fitted with holes in it, and a handle often equipped with a hanging piece. It can also be decorated. Hung on the inside of the rim of a pot or place on a stove or counter top, used to hold utensils.
A wooden or metal supporting device often consisting of a frame or a plate equipped with hanging hooks or pegs. Used to suspend utensils for storage.
An oblong block of wood pierced through with regularly spaced slots. Fixed to a wall, used to store knives securely.
A hanging device consisting of two notched uprights, a shelf and two supporting brackets. Used to hold and store a set of spits.
An often square or round piece of thick fabric equipped with a hanging loop. Used to protect the hands when handling a hot utensil or container.
An open-ended tubular, plastic or fabric slip jacket. Pulled over a rolling pin, used to apply a pattern to pastry dough or to keep it from sticking to the roller.
A one-piece, metal screen dome equipped with a knob or ring-shaped handle. Placed over a dish, used to keep insects and debris off food.

An implement consisting of a pointed metal rod equipped with two helicoidal-shaped cutting spurs at one end and a perpendicularly attached wooden handle at the other end. Used to break up hardened sugar.

Objects originally created to serve as containers for baking, roasting, braising, broiling, steaming, boiling, or warming food.  This sub-class does not include devices that heat food, such as stoves, rice cookers, and waffle irons, which are listed in Food Preparation Equipment.
A cylindrical, flat-bottomed metal receptacle; equipped with a handle, often a lid and sometimes a spout. Used to hold food to be cooked or heated.
A deep, oblong, metal or ceramic receptacle equipped with handles, a lid and sometimes a removable, perforated insert. Used to contain fish to be steam cooked.
A metal utensil consisting of several cups set on a round tray set into a saucepan and covered with a lid. Used to hold eggs to be steam cooked.
A metal receptacle with a round bottom and low sides, a domed cover and a handle. Used to hold meat or poultry in order to cook it.
A flat-bottomed, shallow, round metal receptacle with sloped sides; equipped with a handle. Used to contain food ingredients to be fried.

A round, flat-bottomed metal receptacle whose height measures at least equal to its diameter; equipped with a lid, handles and sometimes feet. Used to hold large quantities of food to be boiled or cooked.
A wide-bodied, flat-bottomed and narrow-mouthed metal receptacle equipped with a spout, a handle and a lid. Used to contain water to be boiled.

A deep, round, flat or round-bottomed metal receptacle; equipped with a moveable handle, sometimes with feet and a lid. Used to contain large quantities of food to be cooked, usually over an open fire.

A ceramic, glass or metal utensil consisting of two flat-bottomed cylindrical receptacles with handles, set one inside the other, the upper one often perforated and sometimes covered with a lid. Set over a heat source, used to cook or reheat food.
A utensil consisting of a rectangular metal tray, which may be flat or with one or more raised sides. Used to hold cookie dough to be baked.
A round metal receptacle equipped with a hollow cone rising from the bottom. Used to to hold cake batter and ensure that it rises and bakes thoroughly. Also, used to make a ring shape cake.
A wide, round or oval, metal or ceramic receptacle with smooth, high sloping sides; sometimes equipped with a lid. Used to contain pudding batter as it is steam cooked.

A round, metal, glass or ceramic pan with shallow, sloping, wide-rimmed sides, plain or fluted sometimes embellished with a decoration. Used to contain and give a particular shape to a pie crust as it bakes.

A metal platter consisting of a series of often round, smooth, cup-shaped depressions set in a rectangular tray; sometimes equipped with handles. Used to contain and give muffin batter a particular shape as it bakes.
A flat-bottomed, often metal receptacle; sometimes with decoratively embossed sides. Used to contain and give cake batter a particular shape as it bakes.
A rectangular, often metal receptacle with high, smooth sides; sometimes equipped with handles and a cover. Used to contain and give bread dough a particular shape as it bakes.
A utensil consisting of a deep, flat-bottomed, circular or oval recipient, with flaired edges, usually without lugs, sometimes equipped with a lid. Used to hold food to be cooked or served.
A round, lidless, flat-bottomed, glass, ceramic or metal receptacle with straight sides. Used to hold individual portions of food to be cooked.
A round ceramic or metal receptacle equipped with side handles and a lid. Used to hold food to be cooked over a slow fire.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for capturing aquatic and terrestrial animals by any means other than weaponry.  This class does not include hunting and fishing weapons, which are listed in such Armament sub-classes as Armament Accessories, Edged Weapons, and Firearms.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for capturing terrestrial animals by any means other than weaponry.  This sub-class does not include objects used for the trapping of household pests.

A metal device consisting of toothed or straight-edged moveable jaws, a pan (trip plate), one or two swivels attached to one or two springs, a clamp, trap setting, and a trap chain. It comes in various sizes. Used to capture an animal (such as a bear or a beaver) and hold it by the limb.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for capturing aquatic animals by any means other than weaponry.  This sub-class includes objects used in the commercial or recreational catching or harvesting of fish, shellfish, or marine mammals such as whales.
A device consisting of a long, rectangular net equipped with floats and anchors. Used to capture fish (cod, salmon and herring).

A device consisting of a see-through, rectangular or half-cylinder metal or wooden framework, sometimes with a double bottom, equipped with funnel-shaped openings, a bait spike and an anchoring loop. Set on the sea bed, used to capture lobster.
A device consisting of a cylindrical or oval metal body with a hole punched in its center. Used to hold a net down on the river or sea bed.

A device consisting of conical, rectangular, oval or round solid metal body perforated with an eyelet at one end or the other. Tied to a line, used to facilitate casting, sinking the fishing line and stabilizing the hook and sometimes the float.

A device consisting of a a hollow composite, metal or wooden pole, sometimes assembled in two or three sections, equipped with metal rings regularly spaced along its length and a handle at one end. Often used in conjunction with a fishing reel, fishing line, and a fishhook to capture fish.
A device consisting of a drum or swivel of wood, plastic or metal, equipped with a braking mechanism and turned by a crank handle. Attached to a fishing rod, used to spool and reel out fishing line.

A plastic, wooden or metal device, often in the shape of a spoon, fish or insect, equipped with one or more hooks at one end and an eyelet at the other. Attached to a fishing line, used to trick a fish into being captured.
Device consisting of a shaft, often of metal, armed at the base with hooks in a crown-shaped array. Used to catch small fish or cephalopods by snagging their bodies rather than their mouths.
A length of cord, often of cotton, nylon or silk. Attached to a fishing rod, used to suspend fishing devices intended for capturing fish.

An instrument, which is tied to the fishing line, consisting of a hollow body, generally round or oval-shaped, made of animal hide, cork, glass, plastic or wood. Used to keep the bait at a desired depth and to indicate, by its movement, that a fish is biting.

A device, often of metal, consisting of a thin shank with a bend, point and barb at one end of the shaft and an eyelet at the other. Tied to the end of a fishing line, used to hold bait and snag fish by its flesh.
A metal or bone implement with a hole drilled through it. Skimmed over the surface of an ice fishing hole, used to clear away reforming ice.
A piece of sculpted wood, pointed at one end and flat at the other. Used to immobilize lobster claws.
A device consisting of an tightly or loosely woven open mesh fabric equipped with floats. Used to catch fish.
A device consisting of a long, rectangular net. Used in conjunction with wattles and poles, used to catch fish.
A receptacle consisting of a net pouch fastened to a wooden or metal frame equipped with a handle. Used to remove fish from the water.
A device consisting of a net equipped with a series of hooks attached at regular intervals and anchored to a buoy. Used to capture fish.
A tool consisting of a metal strip equipped with measuring notches. Used to measure the size of a lobster’s carapace.
A implement consisting of a metal hook attached to a long wooden handle. Used to pull a large fish out of the water.
A container, often of wicker with rounded corners, or of metal or wood, covered with a lid equipped with an opening, a fastening strap and a handle. Used for carrying fish.

A container composed of a cylindrical metal or wooden receptacle covered with a lid, equipped with a handle or a hanging cord and sometimes equipped with a removable strainer. Used to store live bait.
A plastic or metal container equipped with an often perforated lid. Used to hold live bait (grubs, worms).
An oval-shaped, woven wicker container, sometimes equipped with a handle. Used to hold oysters gathered along oyster-beds.
A blunt instrument consisting of a slightly tapered, cylindrical piece of wood with a wide head at one end and a handle at the other. Used to stun a large fish.
A wooden, cone-shaped float pierced through by a pole or a rope. Used to mark the location of one or more submerged lobster pots fishing area.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to fabricate objects out of minimally processed, fibrous plant material, including grass, straw, reeds, bark, splints, and twigs, or from fibrous animal material, including bristles and hair.  This class includes tools used for basket-making, broom-making, brush-making, thatching, and wigmaking.  It also includes tools, equipment, and supplies used for crafting similar products from synthetic fibers.  This class does not include tools used for working with textiles or processed wood.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the care, breeding, or study of animals.  This class includes instruments used in the practice of veterinary medicine, in the psychological study of animals, and in the care of animals, such as the tools a farrier uses to shoe animals.  This class does not include equipment used in processing animal products for human use (see Food Processing T&E or Leather, Horn, Shellworking T&E).  Also excluded are structures for housing animals and the tools of trades related to animal husbandry that are not used directly with animals, such as a farrier's metalworking tools.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the medical examination, diagnosis, or treatment of animals.  This sub-class includes objects used by animal doctors or others responsible for the care of animals.
An instrument consisting of a thin metal blade with a perpendicular cutting flange. Used for making incisions in the jugular vein of an animal for bloodletting.

A tool consisting of a metal plate with fine grade teeth covering one side and the edges, extending from the end of a metal shank attached to a wooden handle. Used to square up the edges of a horse's teeth.
A tool consisting of a pair of scissored handles, one side equipped with a half-moon shaped metal blade and the other with a cutting plate. Used to amputate the tail or part of the tail of an animal.
Objects originally created for the care and maintenance of household pets.
A strap, often of leather, equipped with a buckle, a metal ring and sometimes an identity tag. Fitted around the neck of an animal, used to adorn or restrain.
A flat-bottomed, wicker, metal wire, nylon fabric or fibreglass container with a hinged door and handles on the upper surface. Used to confine domestic animals to be transported.
A ceramic, plastic or metal container, usually circular in shape. Used to hold food or water intended for domestic pets.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to support the shoeing of horses and other animals.  This sub-class does not include general blacksmithing tools, which are listed in Metalworking T&E.
A tool consisting of an irregularly-shaped bent metal shaft with a chisel tip at one end and a wooden handle at the other. Used to trim the hoof horn prior to shoeing.
A tool consisting of a flat metal bar covered with two grades of coarse teeth and sometimes a handle. Used to shape the hoof wall and to level the surface to be shoed.

A metal tool consisting two jaws, one flat-headed and the other with a beveled cutting edge, extending from the ends of a pair of scissored handles. Used by the farrier to adjust the driving angle of shoe nails or to remove excess hoof horn.
A tool consisting of a curved tapered blade often attached to a wooden handle. Used to clean and trim hoof horn before shoeing.
An instrument consisting of a metal plate extending from a shaft attached to a wooden handle. Used to cauterize wounds.
A tool consisting of sharp blade extending into a metal handle or attached to a wooden handle. Used in conjunction with a mallet to cut off excess hoof horn during the shoeing process.
A tool consisting of a straight metal bar with a flat blade at one end and a sharp, pointed head at the other. Used in conjunction with a hammer to loosen nails when removing horseshoes.

A metal tool consisting of two outward-curving metal jaws with ridged teeth extending from the ends of a pair of scissored handles. Used to bend the shoe nail ends over, in order to clinch the shoe in place before filing the nail ends.
A metal or wooden tool consisting of a post attached perpendicularly to a rectangular base. Used to support the horse’s foot during the finishing stages of the shoeing process, such as hoof rasping.
A semi-circular metal plate with calks on the ends and perforated with nail-holes. Worn in pairs, used to protect an ox's hooves and to provide surer footing on slippery terrain.
A U-shaped strip of metal perforated with nail-holes and sometimes equipped with calks. Used to protect a horse's hooves and provide surer footing on slippery terrain.
A metal tool consisting of two curved cutting jaws extending from the ends of a pair of scissored handles. Used to remove, cut and bend over nail ends that protrude beyond the hoof wall.
A metal spike with a flat, flaring head. Used to fasten a shoe to an animal’s hoof wall.
A tool consisting of a metal head with a ball peen attached to a wooden handle. Used to forge and fit a horseshoe.
A tool consisting of a peen with a claw, attached perpendicularly to a wooden handle. Used to drive nails into the hoof horn, pound rivets together and remove poorly driven or twisted nails.

A device consisting of a wooden structure equipped with ropes or chains and straps connected to a winch. Used to immobilize large livestock in order to facilitate the carrying out of certain activities such as shoeing.
A rectangular wooden receptacle divided into compartments and equipped with a handle. Used to organize and transport the tools and nails necessary for shoeing.
Wooden container divided into compartments and often equipped with a handle. Used to organize and transport the nails for shoeing animals.
A metal or wood tool with a square head and a handle. Used to support a object to be riveted.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to promote the propagation of animals.
An ovoid piece of plaster, marble or plastic. Placed in nests or hen houses, used to induce hens to lay their eggs where desired.

A device consisting of a platform and a cover equipped with a heat source. Used to provide sufficient heat for raising chicks from the time they hatch until they are five or six weeks old (from birth until they are fledglings).

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the routine maintenance of animals.  This sub-class includes objects for feeding, grooming, identifying, training, or controlling animals.  It does not include objects used for the care of household pets or objects used for animal medical treatment.
Cement, wooden, glass or earthenware container, often circular. Set on the ground, used to contain water intended for farmyard animals.
Stone, metal or wooden container, usually oblong in shape, sometimes equipped with a tap. Set on the ground, used to contain water intended for animals.

A device consisting of a cylindrical metal container or compartment equipped with a lid with a tapered spout and a bellows. Used to blow smoke into the hive in order to keep bees from getting aggressive.
A straw container consisting of a cylindrical section and a dome-shaped roof with a hole. Used to house a beehive so as to encourage honey production.
A metal tool consisting of two sharp blades fixed to a pair of shanks joined by an open loop of sprung metal. Used to clip woolen fleece from sheep.
A tool consisting of two curved, pointed, scissored metal blades with a pair of handles terminating in finger and thumb holes. Used for trimming horse-hair off the fetlock.

A tool consisting of a metal hook attached to a wooden or metal handle with sometimes a hammer head with a pointed peen on the end. Used to remove debris (small stones and dirt) lodged in a horse's hoof.
A tool consisting of an upward curving metal piece with several wide teeth attached to a wooden handle. Used to untangle an animal's hair.

A tool consisting of several narrow metal or rubber bars with rows of short, fine teeth or serrated edges riveted parrallel to each other to two crossbars, sometimes with a row of course teeth on the back of the first bar, and attached to a short wooden handle. Used to loosen mud, sweat and dust from an animal's coat.
A device consisting of two serrated metal blades (stationary and cutting), operated by the scissoring action of two handles or by a motor. Used to clip an animal’s coat.
A tool consisting of an ensemble of supple animal or vegetable fibre bristles set perpendicularly into a flat wooden back sometimes equipped with a leather strap. Used to groom the coat of an animal.
An instrument consisting of a rope loop attached to the end of a wooden handle. Used to twist the upper lip of a horse to subdue it when it is receiving certain kinds of care.

A chain with a swivel and iron ring at one end and a toggle at the other, generally attached around the necl of an animal. Used to lead, restrain or tie an animal to a fence or post. Also used to hold an identification tag.
A wooden device, consisting of a collar with often a dowel to fasten it, and sometimes equipped a rod. Fitted around an animal’s neck, used to restrict its movements and to keep it from mating.
A rectangular piece of openwork fabric sometimes held in place with a surcingle and a closure in the front. Used to protect a horse from insects.
A device consisting of a dome-shaped, wooden, metal or leather framework linked to a set of fastening straps. Used to confine an animal’s snout in order to keep it from eating or biting.
A strap, often of leather, equipped with a hand grip at one end and a fastener at the other. Attached to an animal’s collar, used to tether or restrain it.

A metal instrument consisting of two ball-tipped, jaws extending from the ends of a folded spring or a pair of scissored handles with loops on the ends. Used to pinch the nasal septum of an animal in order to lead or subdue it.

A device consisting of two wooden bands with peg closures or leather straps with loop metal buckles attached to the ends of a wooden bar. Fastened to an animal's legs, used to restrict its movements and to keep it from kicking.
A metal or wooden stake with a movable loop attached to the blunt end. Driven into the ground, used to anchor a livestock tether.
A tool consisting of a deep-bowled, wooden or metal receptacle attached to a short wooden or metal handle. Used for taking up portions of dry fodder to feed livestock.
A wooden or metal trough or circular container. Set on the ground or suspended from the ceiling, used to supply feed to poultry.
A wooden, metal or concrete container, often narrow and rectangular in shape. Set on the ground, used to contain food intended for livestock.
A canvas and leather container equipped with a hanging strap. Fastened over the head of a tethered animal, used to contain its food ration.

A rectangular piece of fabric, often patterned, and sometimes held in place with a surcingle and a closure in the front. Placed over a horse’s back, used to protect it from sudden chills, insects and the elements.
A hollowed-out, flared metal device equipped with a clapper and a fastening ring. Hung around the neck of an animal, used to facilitate locating livestock in woodland or farm country.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for farming or gardening.  This class includes implements used in planting, tending, harvesting, and storing crops and in processing food for animals but not food for humans.  This class does not include tools and equipment used in caring for animals, in working with forest products, or in preparing fibers for textiles or other products from agricultural products.  It does not include agricultural structures, groundskeeping equipment, or objects that serve primarily as vehicles.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for managing or caring for crops, including objects used for fertilization, irrigation, pest control, or grafting.  This sub-class does not include weeding tools, which are listed in Cultivation Equipment.

A device consisting of a steel frame base, at the bottom of which is a threaded opening and to the top of which is attached a vertical nozzle consisting of either 2 or 3 short, horizontal arms with holes at each end or one perforated head centered on the top. Attached to a hose, used to spray water over a lawn or garden.
A device consisting of a cylindrical metal container equipped with a plunger-like insert and a nozzle. Used for spraying or misting plants with water, pesticides or fertilizer.
A device consisting of a tin cylindrical container attached to a pipe equipped with a nozzle at one end and a plunger at the other and a handle. Used for dispersing insecticide or fungicide on crops.
A fork with four or more long metal tines, slightly curved and pointed, fixed to a crossbar and attached to a wood handle, sometimes with a hand grip. Used for pitching or spreading manure.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for setting or sowing plants or seeds for crops.

A tool consisting of either a rounded or sharp, spear-like point or a bulbous, tapering iron head attached to a short wooden or metal handle sometimes equipped with a T- or D-shaped hand grip. Used for making holes in the ground to plant seeds or bulbs. Also used for transplanting.

A tool consisting of a long, narrow rectangular box, down the center of which is a row of holes often separated by wooden dividers, typically mounted on an axle with two wheels and handle bars. Used to dig furrows and sow seed.
A device consisting of a wooden or metal box, wicker basket or canvas bag, a short handle, a shoulder strap and sometimes a spreader plate. Used to carry and broadcast seeds while seeding.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for gathering or handling crops or other agricultural products.  This sub-class includes objects for picking, reaping, threshing, sifting, drying, bunching, binding, and loading crops.  Note: For a piece of equipment made for a specific crop, the name of the crop may be entered in a subject field, whether or not the crop is noted in the object term.

A device consisting of a wooden, box-like body containing a series of vibrating screens or sieves with square, round or slotted openings and a ventilator. Used to separate, sift and clean chaff from grains after the threshing.
A large shallow container, generally round, with a mesh or perforated wooden bottom. Used to separate chaff from grains after the threshing.

A tool consisting of a wide, shallow, generally semi-circular, flat-bottomed  container made of wicker, strips of wood or bark with two handles and sometimes a rounded edge. Used for separating grain from the chaff by agitation and fanning.

A wooden, animal or motor-powered machine consisting of a gearbox, a threshing drum equipped with a hollow cylinder fitted with paddles, a winnowing fan and a separator. Used to mechanically separate grain from the straw and the chaff.
A tool consisting of a broad blade with shallow curved sides, made of wood or metal attached to a long handle. Used to scoop up grain.
A tool consisting of a long, arched blade attached perpendicularly to a long snath equipped with two movable hand grips. Used to mow hay or to harvest cereal crops.

A tool consisting of a blade and a row of several long, arching wooden tines attached to a cross bar, fixed to a long wooden handle Used to simultaneously cut and gather hay or cereal crops into loose bundles or for laying out grain.

A tool consisting of a row of metal or wooden tines of varying lengths attached along a straight or fan-shaped crosspiece, and fastened at a right angle to a long wooden handle. Used to gather loose vegetation such as grass, hay or leaves and for smoothing the surface of the ground.
A rake with stout, wooden tines. Used for gathering loose, cut hay.
A tool consisting of a metal or wooden receptacle equipped with a row of tines and a handle. Used to gather berries by combing the plant.
An animal- or machine-drawn machine consisting of a toothed, shear-like cutting bar, an oval-shaped, wooden grassboard and sometimes a lever and a seat. Used to cut hay and cereal grains.
A tool consisting of a long, wide, slightly flaring and upward-curving blade with a pointed or straight-edged tip attached to a short wooden handle. Used for clearing brush or cutting vegetation.

A tool consisting of a long, triangular blade, sometimes with two or more teeth at the base of which are usually fixed two small, wooden hand grips, one at a right angle and the other at a perpendicular angle to the blade. Used to chop up fodder intended for livestock.
An implement consisting of a sharp or serrated crescent-shaped blade attached to a shaft equipped with a handle and sometimes a step. Used to cut or saw a stack or pile of hay into sections.
A tool consisting of a hooked, straight-edged or serrated blade attached to a short wooden handle. Used for cutting tall grass and harvesting cereal or forage crops.
An implement consisting of a row of three or more straight or curved tines, fastened at a right angle to a long wooden handle. Used to harvest potatoes.
A sickle with a wide curved blade, attached to a short wooden handle. Used to cut corn stocks and other cereal grains.
A tool consisting of a hook attached perpendicularly to a stout wooden or metal handle. Used to lift and move bales of hay or straw in the barn of the fields.
A fork with widely separated and curved metal or wood tines attached to a long handle. Used for pitching hay or straw.
A tool consisting of a wooden, metal or cloth receptacle equipped with a series of hooked tines along part of the rim attached to a long, wooden pole. Used to pick fruit from the plant.
A fork with three or four long metal or wood tines fixed to a crossbar and attached to a long handle. Used for fanning and moving sheaves of hay.

A fork in the shape of a paddle with tines which may be welded together at their tips by a crossbar with a cutting edge and attached to a long handle. Used for unearthing and transporting potatoes and other tubers.

A fork with one to three crossbars welded across the tines, sometimes equipped with two shorter tines attached at a perpendicular angle to the main tines and to a long handle. Used for pitching and turning alfalfa sheaves to aid in the drying process.
A tool consisting of a swingle attached to a long wooden handle or staff by a metal ring or a leather thong. Used for threshing or beating grain from the head of the stock.
A tool consisting of a stake equipped with a leather thumb or wrist strap. Used to remove grains of corn from the cob.
A device consisting of a wooden or metal drum containing a metal shaft (auger) and equipped with a spout at the top. Used to elevate grain to the top floor of a barn, mill or other building.

An oval, round or rectangular container made of wicker, strips of wood, bark or wire with one or more handles and sometimes a lid. Used for transporting or carrying cotton, picked fruit and vegetables or eggs.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for treating or preparing food for animals.  This sub-class does not include objects used for serving food to animals, which are listed in Animal Care Equipment or Pet Supplies.  It does not include feed structures such as silos, which are listed in Agricultural Structures.
A device consisting of a metal hopper equipped with flat or conical-shaped burrs and a funnel, a large metal wheel and a wooden handle. Used to crush, grind and shatter grains for animal feed.
A tool consisting of a toothed, metal drum set inside a rectangular wooden box equipped with a hopper and a metal crank. Used to chop root crops (beets, turnips) into fine pieces to feed livestock.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the preparation of land for planting or sowing.  This sub-class includes objects used in clearing, grading, digging, loosening, turning, or weeding soil.  These items may be used prior to planting or sowing or during the growing process.
A tool consisting of a slightly curved, forked blade and an iron loop fulcrum attached to a long wooden handle. Used for removing deep-rooted weeds.
A tool consisting of a rectangular-shaped, iron blade attached to a wooden handle. Used for cutting weeds with thick roots below the surface of the ground.
A combination hoe and garden rake attached perpendicularly to a short wooden handle. Used for breaking up the soil surface and for weeding.
A tool consisting of an oblong blade, flat or concave, attached to a short wooden handle. Used for transplanting and setting out seedlings and fledgling plants.

A sled, typically animal-drawn, consisting of a wooden platform and runners, equipped with iron ring bolts on the front of the runners, and a chain. Used to transport large stones and other heavy objects.

A tool consisting of a flat, trapezoidal blade attached to a wooden handle, often equipped with a hand grip. Used for cutting out and carrying blocks of peat from a river bank or a bog or for digging irrigation canals.
A tool consisting of a rectangular, large and generally flat blade attached to a wooden handle, often equipped with a hand grip. Used to turn over soil and to dig holes.

A tool consisting of a trapezoid, flat or concave rectangular blade, tapering to a straight or rounded tip and attached to a wooden handle, often equipped with a hand grip. Used to dig deep, narrow trenches to install drainage tiles, pipes and other underground utilities.
A tool consisting of an elongated, rectangular- or U-shaped blade, generally rounded at the tip, and attached to a wooden handle. Used for digging ditches when draining wet soil.

A tool consisting of a row of stout, pointed metal tines, attached perpendiculary to a wooden handle. Used to remove stones and roots or dead leaves and grass when levelling a piece of ground for planting.

A tool consisting of a metal hook or claw equipped with a chain that attaches to a wooden bar (whiffletree) and equipped with a long wooden handle. Hitched to a yoke or a tractor hitch, used to remove stumps from the ground.

An animal- or machine-drawn piece of equipment consisting of a wooden or metal beam equipped with a coulter, a share extending from a mouldboard, a pair of wooden handles and sometimes a forecarriage. Used to turn over the sod in order to loosen and aerate it in preparation for sowing.

An animal-drawn plow consisting of a moldboard, a triangular or oblong-shaped solid or slitted steel wing, attached to the base of the V-shaped shafts of the plow beam, either as an extension of the plowshare or as a separate fixture, and a pair of plow handles. Used to break the ground and turn over furrow in preparation for planting.

An animal- or machine-drawn plow, consisting of a wooden or metal beam, a share with two blades, two mouldboards usually without a coulter and a pair of wooden handles. Used to dig and maintain ditches or furrows in order to irrigate and drain cultivated land and peat bogs.

A tool consisting of a double-edged blade, broad and flat at one end, pointed and chisel-like at the other, attached to a stout, wooden handle. Used for loosening tough soil, unearthing small stones and for digging up roots.
A tool consisting of four to ten tines made of metal and slightly curved, attached to a long wooden handle. Used for handling manure.

A tool consisting of a flat, long, rectangular- or triangular-shaped blade, slightly curved, attached at an angle to a wooden handle. Used for cultivating or weeding or for making shallow trenches for sowing seeds.
A hoe. Used to harvest turnips and other rooted vegetables.
A hoe consisting of a rectangular beveled blade attached perpendicularly to a wooden handle. Used to break up the soil surface, to remove small stumps and roots or to unearth tubers.

A light weight hoe consisting of a rectangular-shaped blade attached perpendicularly to a wooden handle. Used for weeding, breaking soil, making furrows for seeding, tamping down soil and for working around plants in tight spaces.

A horse- or tractor-drawn tool consisting of a triangular, rectangular or trapezoidal wooden or metal frame to which are attached a series of backward-slanting, diamond-shaped spikes in cross-section, set at intervals along each of the frame's bars. Used to smooth and pulverize newly ploughed or rough soil.

An animal- or tractor-drawn machine consisting of a steel frame with one or two rows of sharp, concave steel disks, a hand-controlled lever and sometimes a seat.  Used to prepare the soil for seedbeds.
A tool consisting of three or more slightly curved metal or wooden tines attached to a wooden handle with a hand grip.  Used for piercing, pitching or digging various materials and produce.
A fork with four metal and flat tines attached to a long wooden handle with a hand grip. Used for turning and breaking up soil.

An animal-drawn tool usually consisting of several iron shares attached to a rectangular- or triangular-shaped wooden or metal frame, often equipped with cross bars, usually adjustable in width, with one or more draft wheels, and two long V-shaped handles. Used to break up soil and unearth weeds, particularly in crops growing in rows or on hillsides.
A tool consisting of three or more pointed, flat or round curved metal tines attached to a short or long wooden handle. Used to break up, aerate or mix soil or to weed a garden.
A tool consisting of several blades or a plowshare attached to a frame which is equipped with a wheel and two wooden handles. Used to break up, aerate and mix soil between rows of plants.
Objects originally created to serve the personal needs of an individual as clothing, adornment, body protection, or an aid in grooming.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to be used for grooming, hygiene, personal sanitation, or for enhancing one's appearance.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to assist people with personal sanitation and health preservation activities such as bathing, routine oral care, or birth control.  This sub-class does not include furniture or plumbing and drainage elements such as toilets or bathtubs.

A fairly shallow, concave, and usually circular vessel, with sloping or curving sides, made of ceramic or metal. Usually accompanied by a matching wash pitcher and placed on the washstand. Used to hold water for washing and personal hygiene.
A rectangular piece of cloth of varying dimensions that is generally made of thick cotton or other thick, absorbent material. Used for drying the face, the hands, or the entire body.

A small, square piece of cloth, usually made of cotton or other absorbent material, and sometimes sewn together at the top and at the sides to form a pouch for the hand. Used to wash the various parts of the body.
A small towel. Used for drying the face.

A container in the form of a funnel that is usually made of enamelled sheet metal or of ceramic, and that is closed at the wide, flat bottom end or a pail that is flared on one side and sometimes at the top. It usually has a handle  for carrying, and sometimes a small handle for emptying. Placed on the floor or held in the hand, used as a receptacle in which to urinate.

A container, usually of porcelain or metal, with a flared rim at the top, with a lid, and sometimes with a handle. It may be placed under the bed or in a chair designed to receive the pot. Used as a receptacle in which to urinate and defecate.

A shallow, circular or oval container that may have a spout at the rear for emptying, and a lid at the top to contain odours. It is made from a variety of materials. Often placed under a person confined to bed and used for urination and defecation.

A thin, tubular, and expandable sheath, either made of animal skin, such as sheep intestine, or of synthetic material, such as latex. It is open at one end and sometimes has a small narrow tip at the other end. Used to cover the penis during sexual intercourse in order to prevent conception or sexually transmitted diseases.

A container of earthenware, glass, porcelain, silver, or metal, with a wide spout at the lip and a handle on the opposite side. Usually accompanied by a matching washbasin and placed on the washstand. Used to hold and pour water for washing.

A small, oval cup, generally of metal, ceramic, or glass sometimes with a stem, a splayed foot, and one or two handles. It has a wide and curved inward rim in order to conform to the shape of the eye. Used to hold water or eyewash which is then applied to the eye.

A rectangular flat box with a long, narrow opening at the bottom and a hinged cover. It is generally made of tin or plastic and often has holes on the back for fastening to a wall. Used to hold paper towels and to dispense them through the opening.
Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to be used for the care, grooming, or removal of hair on the body, head, or face, except for eyelashes.

A small container made of bisque, glass, or some other material with a small hole at the top. Used to store the hairs which are lost when brushing so that they can later be made into hair extensions or used as stuffing in mementos.
A machine consisting of two hone rollers that are set inside a metal case which has a handle at the side or the top. Used to sharpen certain types of removable razor blades, such as safety blades.

A band of sometimes treated leather or canvas which is fitted with a handle at one end and a hook or a ring at the other for hanging. Also can consist of a handled strip of wood with leather covered and a hone on one side. Used to sharpen straight razor blades.
A fine grit rectangular stone that is made of schistous material. Used with water or oil to sharpen by friction a fixed-blade razor, such as a straight or cutthroat razor.
A box of varying shapes, generally made of metal, celluloid, cardboard, paper, or leather-covered wood. Used to store a razor.
A small, cylindrical brush consisting of a short wooden or ceramic handle with long bristles attached at the end. Used for lathering and spreading shaving soap on the face.

Objects used to enhance or care for the appearance of skin, nails, or eyelashes.  This sub-class includes cosmetics, manicure and pedicure tools, tattooing and skin piercing tools, and associated containers and accessories.  It does not include tools or supplies used for cleaning skin.
An instrument consisting of an oblong handle, often made of ivory, with one side padded and covered with soft leather, such as chamois. Used to rub and polish finger-nails and toe-nails.
A small container of various shapes and materials that is often fitted with a lid. Used to store cosmetics or ointments.

Objects originally created to be used by individuals as clothing care tools such as glove stretchers, as personal carrying or storage gear such as wallets or backpacks, as protective equipment such as umbrellas or goggles, as personal or physical aids such as canes or eyeglasses, or as personal smoking or drug equipment such as pipes.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created for the preparation, consumption, or personal storage of tobacco products or non-pharmaceutical drugs.  This sub-class does not include equipment used for the manufacture of tobacco products, which is listed in Other T&E for Materials.  It does not include household receptacles for tobacco, tobacco equipment, or tobacco waste that are listed in Containers for Smoking & Tobacco.
A small pouch, usually made of leather, sometimes of pig bladder, seal skin or cotton. It may have a drawstring or zipper closure. Used for storing, preserving, and carrying tobacco.
A variably-shaped metal plaque that has many closely-spaced perforations and that may have sliding shoulders or pivoting shutters and a handle. Used to shred a tobacco carrot into snuff.

A small device, usually made of steel and consisting of a moving blade which swivels past a small round hole. It usually has a small metal ring attached at one end for fastening to a key or watch chain. Used to cut off the end of a cigar before smoking it.

A small, oval, round, or rectangular box made of wood, metal, stone, or horn. It has a snug, often hinged or friction-fit lid. It is sometimes highly decorated. Used for holding, carrying, and preserving snuff. It is also worn on a person as jewelry.
A central, slender wire rod that is entirely covered with soft, often tufted cotton. Used to clean out the stem of a pipe in order to keep it free from obstructions.

An often rectangular, decoratively embellished case made of various materials. It may be subdivided into individual compartments and has either a friction-fit, sliding or hinged lid, which is secured with a fastener. Used to hold and preserve cigars to be carried on a person.

An oval, round, or rectangular, flat, shallow box made of various metals or wood. It usually has a hinged lid and sometimes a latch. It is hermetically sealed. Used to hold, store, and preserve smoking or chewing tobacco in a pocket.

A small, long, and rectangular bag, usually made of tanned hide, usually with a lace or a drawstring closure and fringed. At the bottom with rows and hangings down loosely. It is usually sewn with sinew and intricately decorated with beadwork and has a carrying sling. Used by Indigenous groups to carry a pipe, tobacco, and other related accessories. It sometimes has symbolical value in certain Indigenous cultures that use smoking pipes.

Objects originally created to assist individuals in housing or transporting personal items such as clothing, adornment, or personal accessories.  This sub-class includes handheld containers such as luggage and containers that are worn such as bandolier bags or tool belts.  It also includes clips, chains, and beads that are worn or carried to hold items.  This sub-class does not include containers that are listed in other classes with the specific objects for which they were made.

A large, rectangular, sturdy, heavy chest made of metal or wood. It may house hangers, drawers, and compartments, and may also have locking mechanisms. Used to transport clothes and personal belongings when moving or travelling. It is also used for storage.

A long, bulky, and large wooden chest; equipped with a heavy, hinged lid and sometimes a locking mechanism. It may have rope handles at the sides and sometimes is decorated with simple carvings and paintings. Used on board a ship as a seaman’s storage and carrying box personal and issued belongings.

A small, usually circular metal case (of copper or silver) with a hinged lid. It may also have a metal chain and house a spring-loaded plate to stack coins. Some types may also have a small compartment to hold stamps. Usually worn by men and attached to a watch chain. Used to hold loose coins.

A long, conical container or sheath made of a decorative material, such as silver plate or tin. It has a clip at the open end for attachment to a lapel buttonhole or a corsage. Used to hold a small bouquet of flowers.
A small, decorative ornament made of glass, metal, stone, or a combination of materials. It is fitted with a metal loop at the top for hanging. Used for decoration.
A clip consisting of a curved, thin piece of metal that is sometimes covered with leather. Carried in a pocket, used to hold folded paper money together.

A fastening device consisting of a thin metal chain that is sometimes made of gold or silver that includes a small hook or clasp (for the watch) at one end and a small rod or bar that slides into a button hole or belt loop at the other. Used to hold a watch and to keep it attached through the buttonhole of a vest or bodice. Also used as a fashion accessory.

A small, flat folding case, usually of leather, containing several compartments of varying sizes and sometimes with a snap or zipper closure. Used to carry paper money and coins. Also used to carry photographs, credit cards, keys, a driver’s licence, etc.

A large, portable bag or case made of leather, or some other sturdy material. It is found in various shapes and sizes, but is generally rectangular with one or two handles for carrying. The inside is usually lined and may be divided into compartments. It may also include a locking mechanism, two or four feet, and sometimes casters. Used for carrying clothes and other personal belongings while travelling.
A small, shallow, usually oval or round box made of wood, cardboard, glass, plastic or decorated porcelain. Used to store pills.
A small case of various materials and shapes, depending on the items that it is designed to hold. Used to hold and carry various personal items (such as sewing or toilet articles, etc.).

A wooden case equipped with a hinged lid and fitted with one or more drawers at the front and a looking mechanism. The drawer(s), as well as the interior are divided into compartments of various sizes. Used to store medicine and other medical supplies.

A small, rectangular, portable, often wooden or leather case equipped with a hinged lid and either a handle on top or two handles at the sides. The inside is often lined and divided into several compartments of varying sizes. It may also have a lift-out tray and a removable mirror on the inside. It sometimes includes a small, built-in drawer on the bottom and may have a locking mechanism. Used to carry and display toiletries or personal belongings, such as a manicure or shaving set, cosmetics, soap, toothbrushes, toothpaste, etc.

A carrying device consisting of a structure made of wooden lathes, metal strips or leather straps, often fastened at the top to a plank equipped with one or two leather, wood, or metal handles. Used for carrying various items (such as boxes, books, parasols, rolled clothing).

A deep box made of various materials and sometimes lined with paper, leather or fabric. It may be in various shapes (triangular, square, rectangular, etc.) and may be fitted with compartments, a lid and a handle for carrying. It may also have straps and fasteners or a locking mechanism. Used to hold hats for protection during travel and storage.

A round or oval and deep box made of several sheets of thin wood boards or pasteboard and that ise fitted with a lid. Often covered in decorative printed paper. Sometimes has a string handle for carrying. Used to store and carry clothing accessories, such as hats, handkerchiefs and gloves.

A belt consisting of a wide, thick strip, generally of leather, that has a buckle closure at the ends and several narrow, flap-closed pouches sewn along its length. The pouches are fastened with a zipper or snap buttons. Worn around the waist and used to carry and conceal money.
A large, pouch-shaped leather or canvas purse with a flat bottom. It usually has a shoulder strap or handles for carrying. Used to carry personal belongings or instruments of a professional.

A small, often oval, round or rectangular bag equipped with a handle and sometimes a shoulder strap; often made of leather, vinyl or various fabrics, may have various types of closures (such as snap, button, drawstring or zipper). It may also include pockets on the outside and compartments on the inside. Used to carry money and personal items.

A small, flat bag with an opening at the front and attached to a tape that ties around the waist under the skirt. Usually made of fabric, often decorated with stitchery, such as embroidery or patchwork. Often worn in pairs, one on each hip, and used to hold personal items.

A rectangular hide (usually buffalo) bag with a lace closure. It may also be folded and is usually decorated with hand-painted tribal designs or motifs. Used primarily by western plains Indigenous groups, such as the Blackfoot, Plains Cree, Sioux, etc., to store or carry personal belongings or foodstuffs, such as pemmican.

A canvas or leather bag equipped with one or more straps and a buckle and a button flap closure. Sometimes, it is rectangular or square in shape. Usually worn over one shoulder to carry supplies, such as food, clothing, etc.
A small rectangular cloth bag, usually made of soft fabric. It may have a short tie closure at the top. Used to store and carry a pair of shoes.

A cylindrical bag, usually made of canvas or of some other sturdy fabric. It usually has a rope-tie closure that forms a handle with a loop at one end. It may have navy identification markings. Used by sailors to carry and store clothes, personal belongings and also sewing supplies in order to repair sails.

A bag often made of canvas with two shoulder straps, a top flap, and some type of closure, such as a drawstring closure. Worn on the back to carry supplies or small objects, usually on hikes or marches.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to help individuals in performing day-to-day activities or to keep them safe or comfortable.  This sub-class includes devices that enhance personal vision, hearing, or mobility.  It does not include clothing or tools and equipment designed for specific activities.

A slender copper, brass, silver or ceramic or metal lined wood case into which a heated piece of metal is slipped. It may be spherical, cubic or rectangular. Usually carried in a muff or in a pocket. Used to preheat them and to keep the hands warm.

A portable warmer made from various materials and in various shapes and styles. The exterior is a pierced outer case, sometimes with a bail handle, and the interior is fitted with a smaller sheet iron box or container. Used to hold hot coals, hot bricks, or hot water in order to warm the feet while the person is sitting.

A light, portable shade consisting of waterproof fabric attached to a collapsible frame of thin metal, wood, or whalebone ribs radiating from the top of a metal, plastic, or wooden carrying stick or handle. It has a circular convex shape when open, and is usually opened and closed by means of a sliding catch. It may have a small strap with a snap closure to secure it in a closed position. Used as protection against the rain.
A small, light umbrella, often very decorative. It is not intended to be waterproof. Often used for protection against the sun, as well as for a woman's or girl's summer fashion accessory.

A small container of metal, or sometimes china, of various shapes, designed to hold a ball of aromatic spices or herbs. May also have a chain. Typically suspended from the neck or the waist, or attached to the finger by a ring and used to carry perfume or to guard against infection and noxious smells.

A small, portable knife with one or more blades of varying lengths that fold into a handle, which is usually made of wood, ivory, horn or bone. It may also be equipped with additional attachments, such as a can opener, a screwdriver, a nail file, etc., which also fold into the handle. Stored in the pocket, used for cutting small objects or food items.

A hook consisting of a curved piece of metal to which a wooden or metal handle is attached to one end. Used to pull a boot up onto the foot and leg. It is hooked into the boot strap and pulled upwards.

Eyeglasses consisting of two round lenses set in wide rims, often of metal; equipped with a safety band, often of elastic, that attaches to the ends of the temples and wraps around the head. Worn to protect the eyes when performing some work or activities and to protect the eyes from the elements, chemicals, and other irritants.

An optical device comprised of two glass lenses set into a frame with a nose piece in the centre and arms at the sides. The lenses may be plain, magnifying, convex, bifocal, clear or tinted, as well as round, oval or rectangular in shape. The frame is made of plastic, tortoise shell, or of metals, such as silver, gold or brass. The arms come in a variety of styles. Used to correct vision or to protect the eyes from the sun and other irritants.
A single round lens set in a metal frame with a metal loop soldered to its side. A ribbon may be attached to the loop. Used as a vision aid for one eye.

A small metal hook consisting of a long metal shaft to which a variably-shaped handle of metal, wood, or other material is attached. Used to draw small buttons through buttonholes, particularly on shoes, spats, or gloves.

Tools, equipment, and supplies originally created to assist in the minor care or routine maintenance of clothing.  This sub-class does not include laundry objects, which are listed in Maintenance T&E.

A foot-shaped stretching device consisting of a large, solid toe block connected to a smaller wooden or plastic heel block by a metal shaft that is often spring loaded and adjustable. Used to preserve the shape of footwear when not in use, and to prevent the leather from creasing.

A device consisting of two, long, thin pieces of wood or ivory that pivot near the centre on a hinge or spring mechanism, and that are flared at one end to create handles. Used to widen the fingers of a glove in order to make it easier to slip on the hand.

A small, often ornamental bag or pad, usually of silk, containing a perfumed substance, such as perfumed powder, scented cotton, or flower seeds. Used to scent clothes, lingerie, handkerchiefs, linen, etc. It is hung or laid among garments or other articles in chests, wardrobes, etc.

A brush with short bristles set into a wooden or metal base of various shapes that extends into a handle.  Used for polishing shoes and boots. Some types are used for daubing polish on leather shoes and boots while other types are used for cleaning and shining.

A variably-shaped brush with soft natural bristles set into a base of wood, metal, ivory, or other material; sometimes with a long handle often of the same material as the base. Used to brush dirt and surface stains from clothing.

A small brush with soft, often long bristles of camel hair, straw, or other natural fibres that are usually set into a round, elliptical, or curved base of wood, metal, ivory, or other material. It often has a long stem-like handle. Used to revive the pile of velvet and felt hats or to brush lint and dust from the hats.

An accessory consisting of a long, narrow, flat, slotted piece of wood, metal, or other material. The slot runs lengthwise halfway down the centre of the stick and may widen at one of its ends to a circular opening through which a button can be passed. Used to draw buttons up away from the clothing during the polishing process, so as not to soil the fabric.
Objects originally created as coverings for the human body.  This class includes all forms of garments and also accessories such as belts or cuff links.

Articles of clothing worn beneath main garments or protective wear to protect clothing from the body or the body from clothing or to shape or support parts of the body.  Underwear is the layer of clothing that is closest to the skin.

An underskirt that may be trimmed with lace and embroidered, quilted, or flounced and gored at the hem. It is usually a little shorter than the outer garments, and is held in at the waist by means of ribbons, lace, buttons, or elastic. Used to protect the lower half of the body from the cold, to protect the outer garments from soiling and to add fullness to a woman’s skirt.

A collarless, close fitting, and usually hip-length undergarment, generally of stretch material. It may be V-necked or round-necked and sometimes has a buttoned front opening. Worn over the torso, next to the skin, used to protect from the cold and the over-clothes from soiling.

An undergarment, closely-fitted or wide-leggeg, made of lightweight cloth and that may extend below the knee and that may be elaborately trimmed. Used to cover the lower part of the body next to the skin for warmth, modesty, and hygiene.

Long straight-legged drawers that usually extend beyond the skirt hem to just below the calf or ankle, which are often decorated with a frill or lace trim at the bottom of each leg. Worn by women and girls under a petitcoat to cover the lower body for warmth and modesty.

An under bodice worn under, over, or without a corset, made of lightweight material, with or without sleeves, front opening, and fitted at the waist with tie-drawn closure. Often trimmed with lace. Used to cover the upper body for warmth and modesty.

A dress length undergarment made of a thin, silky piece of fabric; sometimes equipped with shoulder straps and trimmed with lace of ribbons. Used by a woman next to the skin for modesty and warmth. It is typically worn under a dress and is used as a lining.

An undergarment consisting of a stiff structure or a padding whose shape allows it to fit over the breasts. It generally fastens at the back and may occasionally be adjustable at the front. Used to make the breasts appear larger, and to improve the bust line.

An undergarment of variable lengths, consisting of a petitcoat of stiffened cloth, such as net or tulle, distended with a framework of whalebone, metal, or cane hoops; or a series of graduated hoops (increasing in size from the waist downward) that is connected by ribbons or elastics. Used to add shape and fullness to a skirt or dress.

A close-fitting and supporting undergarment, often in two pieces made from strong fabric, such as coutil, Lastex, or linen stiffened with whalebone, metal, or similar material; extends from above or beneath the bust to or below the hips; generally tightens and fastens up the front by means of hooks, buttons, or laces. Some types have attached or detachable straps or garters, and some are trimmed with ribbons or lace. It was primarily worn over a chemise. Worn mainly by women, used to shape the figure by confining, and therefore slimming the waist. It is also used to uplift the bust, to round the hips, to flatten the buttocks and to maintain an upright posture.

Padding consisting of a flounced or stuffed cushion, or a framework made of rows of whalebone, featherbone, or metal wire or coils. It varies in length and is worn at the buttocks, over the petticoat, fastening at the waist by means of ties or by ribbons with hooks or buckles. Used to add shape and fullness to the back of the skirt.

A cloth band with two cups and, usually, shoulder straps. Typically fastened at the back or at the front by means of one or more hooks or ribbons. It may consist of the following: padding; light metal, bone, or plastic supports; elastic materials; and buckles to adjust the length of the shoulder straps. Used to support the bust and sometimes to give it an enhanced shape.

A one-piece or two-pieced knitted undergarment, generally of wool for the winter and of a lighter fabric for the summer, consisting of drawers combined with or sewed to an undershirt with usually a front button-closure and long sleeves. Worn by men and women, used to protect the body from the cold and the outwear from soiling caused by the body.

A shirt-like garment that has shoulder straps or sleeves of varying lengths, and that generally extends down to the hemline of the outer dress. It is often trimmed with embroidery and lace. Used by a woman for modesty and warmth. Worn directly over the skin or under a corset, also used to protect the outerwear from soiling caused by the body.
A fabric elastic band, or a belt which encircles the hips; equipped with four attached garters. Used to support the garters which, in turn, hold up the women's stockings.

Articles of clothing worn over main garments or in place of main garments for protection from extreme environmental conditions, dangerous conditions, or substances such as food or dust.  This sub-class does not include footwear, headwear, body armor, or sports equipment.

A knee-length, unfitted garment with a front or a back yoke or fullness in the chest and back, with long, cuffed sleeves. It may be pull-over or button-front style. It may be decorated with embroidery stitches. It is worn by artists, or men and women in various trades as a protective outer garment.

A loose-fitting, one-piece garment, consisting of pants and a shirt with or without long sleeves. It is usually made of heavy cotton. Worn by men and women in various trades, sometimes over clothing, when working in order to protect it from dirt, oil, etc.

A full-length overcoat that is unfitted, often double-breasted. It is made of light-weight fabric and colour. It is sometimes lined. The sleeves are cuffed or tabbed and the pockets may be full or consist of mere slits at the front. Worn as protection against dust when travelling in an open car.

Leather over-leggings that resemble pants without a seat. They are often widely flared and have decorated or fringed extensions on the outer length of each leg. Worn over pants as protection for the legs when horseback or bike riding.
A piece of cloth or impermeable material, often decorated, with ties or buttons for fastening around the neck. Used to protect the clothes of a baby or child from food and saliva during feeding.

A cloth garment that extends from the shoulders or the waistline. It typically consists of an open-back skirt attached to a bib depending of the type, usually fastened at the back. It may be sleeved and have pockets at the front. Used to protect clothing from dirt or damage related to one’s occupation. It is sometimes worn for decoration.

A leather apron that covers the chest and legs. It is often split at the waist to cover each leg separately. The skirt is tied or belted around the waist and legs, and the bib is tied around the neck. Used by a blacksmith to protect the body from injury and clothing from damage and stains.

Articles of clothing worn as outer layers over main garments, usually for warmth or weather protection.  This sub-class does not include articles of clothing worn for protection against extreme environmental conditions, dangerous conditions, food, or dust.  This sub-class does not include footwear or headwear.

A woman’s outdoor garment consisting of a long, usually rectangular and unstructured piece of woven fabric, fur, lace, etc. Used for warmth. It may be loosely draped over the shoulders and over a dress or a suit and also complete the attire.

An unstructured outer garment consisting of a piece of fabric of various sizes and shapes, (such as square, triangular, or circular). It is typically made of lace or woven wool, cotton, or silk and may be fringed. Worn mainly by women over a garment and over the shoulder for warmth and also to complete the attire.

An outdoor coat that is typically made of heavy or insulated fabric, fur or leather, and that is usually lined and sometimes interlined. Worn over a suit coat, jacket, dress, or other outer garments as protection from the elements and for warmth.

An outdoor coat that is usually loose-fitting double-breasted, and made of close-knit, heavy fabric (such as melton or notched pilot cloth). It typically extends to the hip area and has a collar with lapels. Used for protection against the elements. It can also be worn as part of work, recreational, casual or attire.

An outdoor coat that is partially-structured and that typically falls loosely from the neck, over the shoulders, and extends to at least the mid-thigh. It is sleeveless or may have arm slits serving as arm openings. It may fasten only at the neck or along the centre-front with decorative fasteners, and may comprise a hood, a collar and additional shoulder-capes. Worn usually by women over other clothes as protection from the elements.
An unfitted overcoat made of wool, such as étoffe du pays, melton, or blanket fabric, with button closure and sometimes with an attached pointed hood. Worn usually by men for warmth.

An unstructured sleeveless coat that falls loosely around the neck and over the shoulders. It covers the arms to at least the elbow but may extend to the floor, is typically single-breasted and usually fastens only at the neck. Sometimes includes a hood and arm slits. Worn by men and women over other clothes as protection from the elements.
A bag-like garment, fastened by buttons, a zipper, safety pins or ties, to which a hood and sometimes sleeves are attached. Used to cover and protect an infant from the cold, when outdoors.
Articles of clothing worn as normal indoor or temperate outdoor public wear to cover parts of the body, exclusive of accessories, footwear, and headwear.

A short, sleeveless, often collarless upper body garment, with front buttoning, generally worn over a shirt by men or over a blouse by women, or under a coat or jacket. Used as a fashion accessory and, customarily, as part of a three-piece suit. Worn also for warmth.

A matching set of separate garments, usually consisting of a jacket, a skirt or pants, and sometimes a vest. The pieces are usually made of the same fabric. Worn to cover the entire body, usually as formal or informal attire.

A suit consisting of a bodice or shirt with long sleeves, a jacket and an ankle-length skirt or pants and with the appropriate accessories such as neck stock, gloves, riding hat or cap and riding boots.  Worn for horseback riding, completes the attire.

A thigh-length or longer outer garment, in various styles, that is secured at the waist, which hangs freely below. Used to cover the body from the waist down. Worn with a blouse, sweater or jacket, completes the feminine attire.

A wraparound garment that hangs from the waist to the knees and is pleated at the back and sides. It is traditionally made of tartan wool and held together with a pin. Worn by men and women as part of the Scottish traditional dress and to distinguish the family clans.
Short pants that are typically knee-length or shorter. Worn to cover the thighs while playing sports, or as leisure apparel.

A long- or short-sleeved garment with a collar, sometimes detachable, and button-up front. It is generally made of lightweight fabric, such as cotton or silk. Worn by men on the upper part of the body to protect outer garments from direct contact with the body. Also completes an additional outer garment, such as pants.

A fitted or unfitted garment extending from the neck to the waist or hips. It is usually made of a lightweight fabric and includes a complete front, back, or shoulder closing. It may include sleeves and a collar. Worn indoors or outdoors by women to cover the upper body and to complete an additional outer garment, such as a skirt or pants.

An outer garment that extends from the waist to anywhere above the ankle, covering each leg separately. It is often characterised by a waistband which may be fitted with buttons for suspenders and with loops for a belt. Other common features include pockets, a buttoned or zippered front fly, and cuffs. Pants typically come in a variety of fabrics and leg forms.  Used to cover the lower body and completes an additional outer garment, such as a short or a blouse.

A cloth or leather covering for the lower leg that is usually buttoned or buckled on one side or under the shoe or boot and extends from the instep up to the ankle, calf, or knee. Worn for warmth and as a protective covering for the leg.

Knee-length fitted pants that may be fastened above or just below the knee with a lace, buttons or a buckle. Worn to cover the hips and thighs and worn with stockings, completes an additional outer garment.
Short, loose-fitting pants of which the fabric of each leg is gathered into a band which fastens below the knee. Worn by men or women to cover the hips and thighs, usually while playing sports.

A loose-fitting robe that is fashioned after the traditional Japanese costume, ankle-length or mid-calf length, with wide, often long sleeves. It fastens right over left with a wide sash. It is made of rectangles of brightly coloured fabric.  Worn at home for lounging.

A sleeved upper-body garment that varies in length. The sleeves also vary in length and may be cuffed. It is typically made of heavy fabric and may include a collar, lapels, pockets, and back vents at the centre or sides. Used to cover the upper body for protection. Worn by men or women as part of recreational, casual, or formal attire.

A fitted or unfitted jacket that is made of leather or cloth and that is usually sleeveless and often padded or stuffed and quilted. Worn by men as an outer garment to cover the upper body for protection against the elements, or from dirt. Also worn to complete an additional outer garment.

A long-sleeved, single or double-breasted fitted jacket that is typically thigh length, made of duck cloth. It is usually white or black in colour. Worn by a waiter, as part of service attire. May also be worn with an apron.

A jacket that is typically thigh length and is usually made of velvet or rich brocade. The edges of the lapels and the sleeves may often be decorated with braiding and decorative closures such as a belt or a rope. It commonly has a shawl collar and pockets. Worn by men and used as upper-body outer garment, typically worn after dinner.

A short, sleeveless and collarless jacket that is typically waist-length or shorter. The centre front edges are without buttons and do not always meet. It is often decorated with braiding, etc. Worn open over another upper-body garment to complete the attire.
A one-piece lightweight garment with short sleeves, gathered leg openings and buttons or snap closure. Worn by a young child during play.
A one-piece garment of lightweight material consisting of a usually close-fitting top, with or without sleeves, and long or short pants. Worn as casual clothing or formal wear.
A garment comprised of an attached or separate bodice, with or without sleeves, and a long or short skirt. Worn by women, children or infants. Used to cover the upper and lower body.

A loose-fitting lounging robe that is made of lightweight fabric, which reaches from the neck to the waist or hips and may have unfitted sleeves. It has a centre-front opening and usually a belt or rope for closure. Worn over the body or other clothing to protect it while combing one’s hair or applying powder or makeup.
An outer garment made of cloth or other materials, of various lengths, often with a collar and long sleeves which sometimes end in cuffs. Worn indoor or outdoor for warmth.
A single or double-breasted coat with several pockets. Used to cover the upper body over a shirt or a waistcoat and with matching pants completes a suit.

A fitted double-breasted coat, usually with a waistline seam and with a straight vertical centre-front edge from the neck to hemline, a flared, thigh- to knee-length skirt (sometimes with back vents or pleats), close-fitting lower sleeves ending with small cuffs. The double row of buttons usually extends the waistline. Worn as the man’s undress, business wear, as well as formal wear.

A fitted outdoor and indoor coat, with the front skirt sloping at varying angles away from the waistline and extending to the bend of the knee in the back. Worn for business, semi-formal, and recreational occasions.

The fitted garment for the torso or the bust, with many variations on the type of neckline, collar, sleeves, fasteners, and fabric. It may include a waistband. Worn by women to cover the upper body and to complete the attire with a skirt or pants.
Articles of clothing worn on the head for protection or cover.

A head covering consisting either of a piece of fabric which is worn around the head, or an already structured head wrap. It may be decorated with jewels, feathers, or brooches. Worn by women or men, used to cover the hair for fashion or as a distinctive accessory.

A head covering which usually also covers the neck and sometimes the shoulders. It is made of various fabrics and is constructed to be loose or close fitting. It may be stiffened with cane or whalebone inserted into channels, or attached to a coat and may also be worn over a bonnet. Used to protect the head or the headdress from the elements. It may also be used for fashion.

A metal or leather helmet bearing military marks or answering military norms and held in place by a chin strap. Used by members of the military as a uniform accessory and worn to protect the head from the elements.
An ornamental flat piece of transparent or opaque fabric of various shapes and sizes, draped over the head. Used by women to cover and protect the head and face. It is also used for concealment.

A square or triangular piece of fabric, often with a printed or woven design. It is usually folded and tied around the head or the neck. Used to protect the head and hair from the elements, to confine the hair, or as a fashion accessory. It is also used for modesty.

A narrow and thin band, made of soft cloth or leather, sometimes with decorative motifs, worn around the head, usually on the forehead. Worn as a fashion accessory or to keep the forehead and the ears warm. Also used to keep hair in place.

A structured head covering, made of various materials, usually with a crown and often with a brim. Sometimes decorated. Used for protection from the elements, as a fashion accessory, and for propriety.
A flat-crowned and flat-brimmed straw hat, trimmed with a ribbon band. Used as a fashion accessory during the summer or as sportswear. Used to protect the head from the sun.

A hat, of waterproof fabric or plastic, with a wide slanting brim to which ties are attached to the sides. Typically used by seamen and fishermen, used to protect the head and neck from the rain and water sprays.

A cocked felt hat with three corners that are formed by turning the flat brim up on three sides. It sometimes is decorated. Used to protect the head from the elements. Used as a man's fashion accessory.
A stiff felt hat with a dome-shaped crown and a narrow, upturned, rolled brim.  Used as a fashion accessory and to protect the head from the elements.

A stiff or soft hat, worn by women, made of felt, fabric or straw, generally decorated with flowers, ribbons or a veil, with the brim sometimes extending toward the front and the crown toward the back; the brim may also extends outward toward the face. It is tied under the chin. Used to protect the head from the elements, as a fashion accessory, and for propriety.

A fabric or straw bonnet with a wide brim and a ruffle flounce or curtain at the back to cover the neck. The brim is designed to extend out over the face. It is tied under the chin. Used to protect a woman’s or a young girl’s head, neck, and shoulders from the sun. Also used as a fashion accessory.

A bonnet, usually of a soft delicate fabric, such as lace, knitwear, and handkerchief linen, and sometimes with frills surrounding the brim. It is tied under the chin. Used to protect the head of infants from the cold or sun, or used for adornment.
A pouch-like net, sometimes decorated with stubs or pearls, that covers the hair. Used to keep the hair in place at night or during the day and also used as a fashion accessory.

A usually close-fitting head covering, typically of soft, supple material, such as felt, fur, or fabric. It is frequently brimless but, may include a visor or ear flaps. Used to protect the head, and sometimes the eyes and the ears, from the elements and for propriety.

A cylindrical, close-fitting, and brimless cap, made of fur or fabric, with a slightly larger and deeper crown, sometimes with upturned edges. It may sit lower on the head and may cover the top of the ears and part of the forehead. Worn by men and women, used as fashionable attire and as part of some national costumes.

A close-fitting cap, usually made of soft, light fabric, sometimes knitted or crocheted, and often tied under the chin. It may be trimmed with frills, embroidery, lace, etc. Used to cover the head of a man or a woman for warmth while sleeping.

A pillbox-shaped cap usually made of rich fabrics or felt, possibly richly decorated and trimmed with a pompom. Worn by men for casual dress at home and to keep head warm. Also used to prevent the hair from smelling like tobacco smoke.

A brimless, visorless cap with feathers, sometimes with a clan's badge and with ribbons which hangs as a short lappets. The centre crease runs from the front to the back.  Worn fore and aft on the head by men and women as part of the Scottish traditional dress.

A pillbox-shaped cap with a visor or peak in front. The crown often flares out to a flat top. Used to protect the head from the elements. It is also often used as part of a uniform for a mailman, a forester, a customs officer, etc.

A cap that fits loosely over the head and the hair and gathers or fastens closely around the head’s circumference. Lace or ruffles are often attached to the gathered part and hang down over the forehead, the ears, and the neck. Worn indoor by women, used to cover the head and keep the hairstyle intact, or hair culer hidden from view.
A wide round and flat cap, often decorated with a pompom, ribbon and cockade. Used to protect the head from the elements. Usually worn as part of the Scottish traditional dress.

A bonnet or cap that ties under the chin. It may include lappets and a stiff structure, such as wire, under the various fabrics and trimmings which form the head covering, according to the social condition or the fashion period.
