Worn by women, used to cover the head and hair while indoors as well as for propriety. It is also used as a fashion accessory.
Articles of clothing worn on the feet and/or lower legs for protection or cover.  This sub-class includes boots, shoes, and hosiery that may cover more than the feet or lower legs.

Footwear made of leather or cloth that does not extend beyond the ankle and incorporates in its construction a separate sole and an enclosed upper. It may be laced or buttoned or simply slipped on. Used to protect the foot from the elements. Also used in keeping with the fashion style.

Light, soft, and shaftless shoe, with or without a heel, that can be easily slipped on the foot. It is held to the foot by means of the upper, without the aid of fasteners. Used for comfort in a casual, usually indoor, setting.

Footwear with no shaft, made of a single piece of wood, hollowed out in the shape of a foot. The vamp reaches high on the top of the foot and is sometimes extended with a leather strap, secured by nails. Used to protect the foot in field of farm work.

A soft-soled shoe made by shaping a single piece of leather or hide around the foot and sewing it on top in various ways. It is usually decorated with various painted or beaded motifs or fringes and may have a lacing to fasten at the ankle.  Used to protect the foot and the ankle.
Footwear in the form of either a wooden-soled or wooden shoe; or a leather or fabric overshoe with leather sole. Used to protect the shoe or the foot by raising it over the mud.
A low rubber shoe. Worn over a shoe to protect it from the elements.

A cloth or leather leg covering reaching from the instep to the ankle, the mid-calf, or the knee. It is fastened on one side by buttons, laces or buckles and held in place by a strap under the shoe. Used to cover and protect the calf, the ankle, and the shoe.
A baby’s shoe that is usually knitted or crocheted, or made of soft leather. Used to protect a baby’s foot and to keep it warm.
Footwear, made of leather, rubber, fur, or synthetic fibres, with a shaft that rises at least over the ankle and sometimes up to the thigh. Used to protect the foot and leg from the elements.

A soft boot of sealskin or reindeer skin, with the fur left on and turned to the inside, and with a shaft reaching to the knee. It is an adaptation of North American Indigenous (Inuit) footwear. Used in winter to protect the foot and the calf while walking in the snow.

A heelless boot made from animal skin and consisting of a moccasin and an attached leg with a laced closure under the knee. It is an adaption of North American Indigenous footwear. Used by a trapper or a coureur des bois in the winter to protect the foot and the leg.

A leather boot with either a shaft extending past the ankle, generally to the mid-calf; or one with a square in front and cut away at the back to enable the knee to bend while on horseback. (It was adopted from a military style). Used to protect the foot and calf from cold and humidity.
A boot, made of leather or rubber, often reaching to the knee and with a rigid back to keep the foot in the proper position for riding. Used to protect the leg while riding a horse.
A boot reaching up to the thigh, typically made of waterproof cloth or rubber. Typically used by seamen and fishermen to protect the foot and leg from water.

Articles of clothing worn for sleeping, convalescing, bathing, or during dressing when partially dressed or without clothing underneath.  This sub-class includes garments intended for private wear at home.
A loose-fitting dress or shirt-like garment, with ot without sleeves, which usually falls below the knees and is usually trimmed in lace. Worn in bed to cover the body while sleeping.

A waist-length, unfitted and light weight robe, made of wool or lingerie. Worn by women over a nightgown to cover the upper body when sitting up in bed while reading, doing needlework or for added warmth while sleeping.
A formal robe that is loosely cut and is either buttoned or zippered at the front. Worn by women at home for lounging.
An informal robe, usually with long sleeves and a front opening. It is often belted and extends to the knees or lower. Worn before dressing or after undressing for lounging.

Articles of clothing worn on the hands, arms, or neck, and objects originally created for the securement, protection, or adornment of clothing.  This sub-class does not include objects used for the minor care of clothing, which are listed under Clothing Care Objects.

A detachable band of metal, leather, fur or fabric (such as crochet, knitting, or lacework), fastens to the sleeve cuffs. It is always made in pairs. Worn to keep the wrists and part of the hands warm. Also worn for decoration.

An often decorative and detachable wooden or metal button extending from a short shank fixed to a larger base that is usually disk-, pin-, or bar-shaped. Used to fasten a garment, a removable shirt collar or a cuff. Also used as adornment.

A strip of whalebone, celluloid or metal, or sometimes a band made of fabric in the shape of a collar.  Used to give stiffness and proper shape to a collar. It is inserted or sewn inside the collar or used as interlining.

A detachable, usually tubular piece of fabric that varies in form, length and material that attaches to the arm in various ways (ties, bands, elastics, etc.). Worn to cover the arm for decoration and warmth. It is also worn over the sleeve of another garment in order to protect it from wear.

A square, rectangular, or triangular band of fabric that is woven, knitted, crocheted, netted, etc. It is tied around the head and sometimes covers the neck and shoulders. Used to provide warmth. It is also used as a fashion accessory.
A band of warm fabric that usually has an attached closure. Worn around the neck to keep it warm in cold weather.
A woman’s triangular scarf, usually of sheer white fabric. Worn to cover the shoulders and fasten in the front of a bodice, it is used to fill in a low neckline, for decoration or to provide warmth.
A long, wide band of flexible material of various motifs. It is placed around the waist, the hips, or over one shoulder, and fastened with a loop, knot, or bow. Worn for ornamentation.
A fastener usually consisting of a metal shaft with a spiked tip and a plain or decorative head or a removable cap, and sometimes having a short chain. Used to adorn the lapel of a suit.

A fastener of varying size and shape, generally made of precious metal or other materials, usually decorated with motifs, jewels, dangling pendants, and with a hinged pin and clasp at the back to secure it to a garment. It sometimes also has a hook or a ring at the top for hanging from a chain as a pendant. Used as an adornment for garments or hats.
A lace or ribbon usually hung in pairs from the sides, or crown of women’s hats, bonnets, caps, or hoods. Used to adorn coverings or hairstyles.
A band of fabric, ribbon, leather, or cord, etc., encircling the crown immediately above the brim and sometimes finished with a bow or knot. Used to decorate a hat.

A band of various materials (such as silk, wool, linen, and leather) that may be decorated; it varies greatly in width, length, and arrangement. Worn around the base of a shirt collar with a knot, loop, or bow tied in front, to decorate the neck of a shirt or a blouse.
A neck wrap consisting of a long strip of fur, feathers, tulle, or lace. Worn by women around the neck and the shoulders as a fashionable evening accessory.

A neckcloth consisting of a wide piece of cloth that often incorporates a stiffening material or is made of leather and that may be decorated. It is fastened in the back of the neck with hooks and eyelets, laces, a buckle, a clip or buttons. Used as a fashion adornment to cover the neck area above a collar.
A square or strip of fabric of various sizes and motifs. Worn folded around the neck to provide warmth and sometimes for decoration.

A neckcloth with broad ends, typically tied loosely around the neck inside the open collar. The crossed ends are sometimes held in place by a decorative pin. Worn for casual wear as an alternative to a necktie.

A thick tubular or cylindrical hand covering that opens at both ends; sometimes padded. It is usually made of various fabrics or fur, sometimes matching the coat. Often includes a wrist loop or handle for carrying. Used as a fashionable accessory to keep the hands warm and to carry personal items.

A hand covering, usually made of leather, knitted wool, or cloth that consists of a small pouch for the thumb, and sometimes one for the index finger, and a separate, larger pouch for the other fingers. It is always made in pairs. Used to provide warmth and protection for the hands.

A crocheted, netted, knitted, or glove made of lace, silk, linen, cotton, wool or made of fine leather that covers only the base of the fingers. It extends above the wrist, and often to or above the elbow. It is always made in pairs. Used as a fashionable clothing adornment.
A decorative ruffle, a pleated frill, or other arrangement of lace and cloth, fastened at the base of the neck. Worn to decorate the front of a shirt, blouse, or dress bodice.

A hand covering with separate sections for each of the fingers, usually extending to the wrist or partway up the arm. Made of various materials, such as leather, wool, or cotton; it may have a snap, button, or other fastening. It is  made in pairs. Worn to protect the hands. Also worn as a clothing adornment.
A supportive strap consisting of a band or tie of wool, silk, leather, or other material worn over the sock or stocking, above or below the knee. Used to hold up socks or stockings.
A fabric insert, often starched, sometimes with a collar, pleats or ruffles. Worn under another garment and used to fill in the neckline of a dress, a jacket, or other garment.

A small arrangement of natural or artificial flowers, foliage, or other materials secured with a pin and attached to a garment (generally at the shoulder, the bosom, or the lapel of a coat). Wrist varieties have an attached wristband. Used as a decoration for garments or clothing accessories.

A band of stiff or soft cloth, celluloid, or fur that is designed to be worn over the neck edge of a garment. It is usually fastened to the neckline of the garment.  Used as a neck covering to complete another garment and to decorate it.

A clip which consists of two parallel, flat metal bars joined at one end with a pivot, or sometimes closed with a spring mechanism. Often ornamental. Used to fasten two ends of a necktie together or to attach a necktie to a shirt. Also worn to adorn a tie.
A variably sized and shaped metal fastening device, often ornamented and equipped with a clip, hook, or other fastening mechanism. Used to fasten parts of clothing or personal accessories together.

A clasp which has leather thongs, ribbons, or chains, sometimes ornemental in design and worn on the belt. Used to hold various utilitarian objects, such as a watch, a purse, keys, or scissors. It is also used for decoration.

A long strip of leather, fabric, cord, or other flexible material that may be knotted or fastened with a hook and eye, or more commonly, with a buckle. Worn around the waist or hips to hold up or to draw clothes in. Also used for simple adornment.

A band of cloth, metal, or rubber which is elasticized or may be adjusted to the arm by a buckle. Sometimes different colours were worn to mark the week days (dark) or Sundays (white). Used to hold a shirt-sleeve in a particular position on the arm.

Objects originally created to be worn on the human body for ornamentation.  Adornment lacks the communicative aspect of objects listed in the Personal Symbols class and is more decorative than those listed in the Personal Gear class.  This class does not include objects created to adorn clothing, which are listed in Clothing Accessories.
Objects originally created as ornaments for hair, as implements for securing a hairstyle, or as artificial substitutes for hair.

A covering, made of human, horse, or goat hair, or synthetic fibres in various styles, and woven or attached at the root ends to a piece of net or a skullcap (a caul) wich is shaped to the head. Used as fashionable attire for the head to complete the hairstyle, or to cover bald spots or patches of thin hair.
A two-pronged, U-shaped pin made of metal or horn with undulations along its length. Used to hold hair or hairpiece in place. Also used for decorative effect.
A flat, spring like hairpin that is crimped along its shaft. Used to hold hair in place while styling and drying hair. It may be used in conjunction with curlers.

A small, purse-shaped bag consisting of a long piece of fabric, generally taffeta, decorated with a ribbon or rosette and closed by a lace tie. Used by men to partially cover powdered hair so as to protect their clothes from soilure.
Locks of natural or synthetic hair which form a curl, a switch, a fall, a braid or a chignon. Used to embellish a hairstyle or to cover a bald spot.
Objects originally created as ornaments for parts of the body other than hair.

A variably-shaped hanging piece of jewelry, usually made of precious metal or other decorative material, often adorned with jewels or ornate designs, having a ring at the top for suspension from a necklace, bracelet, or earring, and sometimes also having a fastener for attachment to a garment as a brooch. Used for adornment.

A small, variably-shaped ornament, charm, or seal, usually often made of decorated precious metal and with a ring or a loop attached at the top. Used for personal adornment when suspended from a chain. Originally, it was hung on a man’s watch chain.

A small, flat, ornamental case, usually oval, circular, or rectangular, made of precious metal and generally consisting of two hinged halves held together by a clasp with a ring and generally suspended from a necklace or a fastener. Used for adornment and also used to hold a memento, such as a miniature portrait or a lock of hair.

An ornament of varying size and shape, often circular or oval, usually made of wood, shell, stone, or metal, and sometimes decorated with jewels or carved designs. Worn inserted into a hole in the lower lip. Used for adornment or to indicate rank or sexual maturity.

A piece of jewelry consisting of a band, circlet or chain of precious metal or other material worn around the wrist or lower arm, sometimes adorned with jewels or other decorations, consisting of a solid or flexible piece, usually circular or two semi-circular pieces hinged together which clasp. Used for adornment.

A piece of jewelry of cloth, metal, or other material worn around the arm  consisting of a solid piece, usually circular or of two semi-circular pieces, hinged together and fastened by means of a clasp. Used to adorn the upper arm.
A piece of jewelry consisting of a band or chain sometimes decorated with a small nameplate. Used to adorn the ankle.

Objects originally created to facilitate human activity and to provide for the  physical needs of people, generally by offering comfort, convenience, or protection.  Clothing is excluded from this category as it addresses only the needs of a specific individual.  Furnishings are not objects used as active agents in other processes, such as objects used as tools or equipment; they passively enable human activity.
Objects, usually soft furnishings, originally created to provide support for sleeping or to accessorize a bed.  This class does not include beds and bed components, which are included in Furniture.

A bedding accessory consisting of a flat and gathered or pleated piece of fabric, often matching the bedspread, attached to the rails or springs of a bed. Used to cover the bed frame and the bed legs. Also used for decoration.
A plain or patterned curtain, gathered or pleated, hung around a bed from a bed canopy, bed cabin or a ceiling. Used for warmth, control of light, privacy, and ornamentation.
A cover in the shape of a rectangular bag, usually made of ticking. Used to form a pillow by stuffing it with some soft substance, such as feathers.
A covering that is horizontally stretched or suspended from a structure several feet above a bed. Used for ornamentation.

A long, usually cylindrical, stuffed pillow. It typically extends across the bed and is placed under the pillows. Used to support the head of a person resting or sleeping and sometimes to support a person’s back while sitting. It may also be used for decoration.

A rectangular piece of warm, soft fabric, such as wool, linen, cotton or napped cotton (flannel or flannelette) with little or no decoration. Used over a sheet to cover a person’s body in order to provide warmth, usually while sleeping.
A rectangular piece of woven wool fabric, often striped, sometimes marked with points specifying grade. Served as a trade item and subsequently used as clothing for warmth.

A large, rectangular piece of fabric (cotton, linen or flannel). It is typically found in pairs so that one is immediately above and the other immediately beneath the sleeper. Used to protect the mattress and the blanket from dirt and wear.

A bed covering made of two layers of cloth (serge, cotton, linen), usually with a thin layer of cotton, wool or filling between them, stitched in decorative patterns through all thicknesses. The layers are held together by continuous running stitches. Used for warmth or decoration.

A blanket made of two layers of fabric, usually with a filling of feathers or thick fabric, between them. The layers are held together by threads or yarns that are tied together in individual decorated tufts. Used as a bed covering for warmth or decoration.
A fabric covering for the top of a bed that also hangs over the sides and is typically put on as the last layer when making up a bed. Used as an ornamental cover for a bed.

A decorative covering that is laid over a pillow or that covers an entire pillow like an envelope. The later style includes an opening at the center back or at one end into which the pillow is inserted and which may be fastened closed. Used for ornamentation.

A removable covering for a pillow that is usually made of linen or cotton, sometimes fitted with some type of closure at one end. It may be decorated with needlework or trimming. Used to protect the pillow from dirt and wear.

A square or rectangular bag or envelope typically made of ticking and stuffed with feathers, down, or other soft material. Used to support the head of a person resting or sleeping or sometimes used to support a person’s back while sitting.

A rectangular mat consisting of a flat and pliant piece of material, such as woven rushes, straw, hemp, or similar fibres. It is typically placed on the floor. Used as surface on which to sleep or sit.

Objects originally created to cover or adorn a window, door, or doorway.  This class does not include relatively permanent structural parts of buildings such as canopies, exterior shutters, and window sashes.  These items are included in Door & Window Elements.

A covering in the form of either a short, flat, gathered or pleated fabric; or a frame of stamped or pressed metal on a wood backing, or of a fabric-covered wooden or cardboard panel. It is located at the top of a window and is usually used in conjunction with curtains. Used to conceal the top portion of curtains, blinds, etc., as well as the curtain hardware. It is also used for decoration.

A section of gathered drapery which is suspended across the top or hanging down the sides of a curtain, window, portière, or doorway. It is hung at intervals to form loose, horizontal or crescent-shaped loops or scalloped folds. Used to decorate an archway, a doorway, or a window.

A rectangular piece of treated or coated paper, bamboo, or fabric that is mounted on a spring roller, with a wooden slat inserted in a single hem at the bottom, or with a lace or other panel insertion and a shade pull at the bottom. It may be decorated with painted designs, braid, lace, or tassels. Used to cover a window in order to screen or shut out light or heat; it is also decorative.

A detachable ornament, located at each end of a curtain rod, that is usually made of wood, glass, or stamped brass or other metal, and usually ornate in shape. Used for decoration and for preventing curtain rings from sliding off the end of the curtain rod.

A fastener of various forms such as a metal chain, clip, or disk of stamped metal, glass, or wood, a cord of heavy braid with tassels, or a finished cloth strip of the same fabric as the curtain. It may be mounted or fasten to a wall bracket. Used to restrain a curtain or a drapery to the side of a window or door.

A plain or patterned cloth hanging, gathered or pleated, that is generally finished with casings, pleats, or ruffles and hems which may also be weighted. It may sometimes have a lining. It is usually hung by the top edge on a curtain rod. Used to cover a window or a doorway in order to control light and draughts, and provide privacy. Also used for decoration.

A type of heavy fabric that is pleated, gathered, folded, bunched, etc., into patterns or shapes. It can also be placed over curtains. Used to cover a window in order to control light and draughts, and to provide privacy. Also used for decoration.

A cloth screen that is usually made of pile fabric or heavy upholstery fabric, heavily trimmed with braids or fringes. It may be partially floded down at the top to form a valance. It may also consist of an arrangement of beads or cords that hang in a fringe-like manner in a decorative pattern. Used to separate one room from another, to reduce draughts, or to provide privacy. Also used for decoration. It hangs in a doorway or sometimes over doors.

A device consisting of numerous horizontal slats that are usually made of wood, plastic, light metal, stiffened paper, or fabric, which are suspended, one above the other, on vertical tapes or cords. It may be raised or lowered as a unit or the slats can be set simultaneously at one of several angles. Installed in front of a window, used to regulate the amount of light that enters a room. Also used to assure the privacy of dwelling occupants.

Objects originally created to enable people to control the temperature of their immediate environment according to their needs.  This class does not include devices to control temperature for purposes other than human comfort, as is the case with bake ovens and kilns.  Nor does it include relatively permanent structural parts of a building, such as fireplaces or flues or whole-structure systems for environmental control; such items are included in Building Components.

Objects originally created to assist in the management of fire within a stove or fireplace, including tools and their associated holders, protective screens and doors, supports, and radiant surfaces.  This sub-class also includes functional components of stoves (whether heating stoves or cookstoves) as well as objects originally created to store supplies of fuel or tinder or contain burning substances for use in igniting fires.  Structural components of fireplaces such as flues and chimney hoods are included in Environmental Control Elements.
A device consisting of a slightly curved metal rod with a flat tab at one end and a handle of various shapes and styles at the other. Used to handle stove plates.
A metal or wooden scoop consisting of an open-ended box and a short handle. Used to shovel coal into a stove.
A scraper comprising a long metal or wooden handle and a perpendicular metal blade which is typically rectangular or semi-circular in shape. Used to scrape coal dust or ashes from the fireplace.

An instrument consisting of a metal rod that is fitted with or wrought into a handle or a hook and ring at one end and curved or hooked at the other. Used to adjust, stir, or move logs, coals, or similar burning materials in order to stoke the flame.

A rectangular container, usually made of wood, often with a raised back panel and which may be fitted with one or more lids and handles placed on the sides.  It is usually placed in the kitchen near the stove or outside in a lean-to by the door. Used for storing firewood.

A box of various shapes, such as oval, round, or rectangular, typically made of metal or wood. It has an attached or removable lid and sometimes includes a candle holder. Used to hold tinder, a flint, and a steel.
A large, rectangular wooden or metal bin, often with a slanted lid. Used for storing large quantities of coal for use in heaters or stoves.

A piece of tubing made of light-gauge sheet metal. It typically consists of straight or angular sections which are often crimped or corrugated at one end to allow them to fit one inside the other. Used as a stove chimney or to connect the stove to the chimney flue, allowing smoke and unburned volatiles to leave the stove. Also used to carry heat from one room to another.
A circular steel plate that is capable of rotating on a long and pointed steel spike. Used to control the rate of burning of the fuel.
A square or rectangular board with rounded corners that is typically made of tin or cast iron or consisting of a wooden base that has a tin cover. Used to protect the floor area underneath the stove.
A receptacle, usually resembling an open-ended, U-shaped trough that is made of metal, canvas, or other materials and that is equipped with a handle. Used to hold and carry logs.

Iron tongs consisting of two rods with flattened or pronged tips at one end and joined in a pivoting box-joint at the other end and a short handle stemming from the joint. Used to pick up embers and to manipulate burning logs.

An iron or brass support, typically consisting of a pan-shaped base mounted on short legs, a vertical stem with a finial or a handle, and a horizontal support bar. Used to hang the fireset tools, such as a poker, a broom, tongs, etc., when not in use.
A shovel comprising a handle (that is typically longer than that of the stove shovel), and a metal blade of various shapes. Used to remove ashes from a fireplace.
A metal frame with sliding wire grating or glass doors. Used for protection from heat or flying sparks coming from the fireplace and, also, for decorative purposes.

A portable piece of furniture consisting of a framed rectangular panel that is made of tapestry, needlework, or hand paintings and that is either mounted on a four-legged base or an adjustable wooden pole with a tripod or flat base. Used in a parlor and a chamber to deflect the intense heat of the hearth fire and to protect the sitters from draughts.

An iron framework of sloping parallel or crossed bar, in various sizes, but usually square in shape. It is typically mounted on four legs, but is sometimes supported on an andiron. Used as a support on which to burn coal or wood.
An iron U-shaped fork, typically comprising a long handle and two prongs. Used to move the wood in the fireplace.

A low metal fence of iron or brass placed in front of the fireplace. It is sometimes pierced and decorated with motifs and is often designed to match the apron of the grate. Used to prevent coals or ashes from rolling into the room and burning the floor or carpet. It is also used as decoration.

A receptacle consisting of an often rectangular and tinned iron shovel with a perforated lid equipped with an iron or wooden handle. Used to carry hot coals away from the fireplace, often with the purpose of starting another fire elsewhere or to place them in a heater or a bed warmer.
An utensil, often consisting of an iron or wood handle, and with a rectangular base into which natural, elongated, and non-flammable bristles are fitted. Used to sweep ashes from the fireplace.

An iron or brass bracket of various shapes and motifs, which fits into a back plate. It is typically mounted on a wall near a fireplace. Used to support fireset tools, such as a shovel, a broom, a poker, and tongs.

A metal stand, usually made of iron or brass, consisting of a horizontal bar that is mounted on three short legs. It usually has an ornamented finial at the front. Used typically in pairs to support logs in a fireplace and to increase combustion.

Objects originally created to heat or cool individual spaces by burning substances, by connection to an energy source such as electricity, or by hand-operated devices.  Whole-structure heating and cooling systems and humidity control devices are included in Environmental Control Elements.

A closed heater of various shapes (box, oval, and pot-bellied) that is made of various materials (metal, brick, porcelain, and soapstone), which uses various fuels (wood, charcoal, and kerosene). It may be supported by three or four legs. Used to heat one or more rooms.

A self-contained device made of metal or of some other non-combustible material, consisting of a box-like or cylindrical compartment for holding burning fuel, such as wood, coal, or alcohol, or hot air that has been heated by a separate apparatus. It may include legs, doors, and a system of pipes leading to or from it. Used to heat a room.

A collar-like device with vents that fits over the top of a lamp chimney or a collapsible circular wire rack with two or more prongs protruding from the centre fixing it to the top of a lamp chimney. Used to support various objects, such as curling tongs, and liquids to be heated by a lamp.

Objects originally created to produce or assist in producing fire, or to serve as a source of fuel.  This sub-class includes matchbooks, charcoal, and tinderpistols.  It does not include lighters, which are included in Smoking & Recreational Drug Equipment.
A lighter in the form of a flintlock pistol with a metal body and no barrel. Used to light tinder. When the trigger is pulled, the flint strikes the steel producing a shower of sparks.
A dry, spongy substance, prepared from various fungi, that is moulded into a stick. Used to light the kindling on the hearth or in a stove. Formerly used to make lighter wick.
A compact mass of coal dust, sawdust, or charcoal which is typically moulded into the shape of a brick. Used as starter fuel in a fireplace or stove.
A piece of quartz of varying shapes, sizes, and colours. It may be rough or worked. Used to create a spark by striking it downward onto the steel to ignite the tinder.

An instrument consisting of a piece of tempered steel of various shapes and made in such a way as to fit the fingers through when held in the hand. It is typically stored in a tinderbox. Used in conjunction with a flint to create a spark and light up the tinder.

A straight wooden rod with a separate wooden base that has a small hole at the top. It may also include a small, curved bow that is usually made of wood, bone, or antler, and a palm-size piece of wood or stone. Used to kindle fire. A small amount of dry grass or moss is placed into the hole of the base, over which the rod is then inserted perpendicularly and rotated rapidly downwards, either with the hands or with the bow, which is looped around the rod, one hand moving the bow horizontally while the other hand holds the piece of wood or stone over the top of the rod.

Objects originally created to provide illumination.  This class includes lighting accessories such as candlesnuffers and wick trimmers, general purpose portable lighting devices such as kerosene lanterns, and specialized fixtures such as streetlamps and theater lighting devices.

Lighting objects that do not meet the definitions of this class’s other sub-classes.  This sub-class includes objects originally created: as functional or decorative components of lamps or fixtures; as controls for illumination sources, either through mechanical means or through the ignition or extinguishing of burning substances; or to service lamps or fixtures.  This sub-class also includes objects originally created to be burned as a source of illumination or to produce artificial light in a lighting device.

A cord, ribbon, or tube of twisted, woven, or braided cotton or hemp threads, which is encased or dipped in flammable fuel. Used to provide a longer-lasting flame in a candle, a lamp, or the like, by drawing up fuel which is vaporized and burned at its upper end.

A scissor-like instrument usually made of iron or steel, in the shape of two blades riveted together. One blade is generally tray-like, while the other blade, which may be shorter, is thin and pointed. (Unlike a candlesnuffer, this instrument does not have a box compartment to collect snuff). Used to trim the wide flat wicks on kerosine lamps.

A generally hemispherical or conical lamp attachment of glass, metal, fabric, cardboard, paper, or other translucent or opaque material. It encircles the chimney and burner of a fuel lamp, or the bulb and socket of an electric lamp. Used to diffuse or reduce the light of a lamp, or to direct it over a particular area.

A candle consisting of the soft pitch from a rush plant (juncus effusus) which has been dried and dipped in melted tallow, lard, or other flammable fatty substances. Used to produce a bright illumination.
A metal implement consisting of a boat-shaped pan with a handle that rests on three short feet. Placed in the hearth, used to melt the tallow or fat that soaks rushlights.

A pear- or acorn-shaped weight, made of metal (lead shot, brass or porcelain). It is also fitted with a brass fork which holds a pulley through which the pendant lamp wire slides. Used to balance and regulate the height of a ceiling or pendant lamp.

A scissor-like instrument of iron, brass, or silver with two blades of different lengths that are riveted together. The long, lower blade is pointed and has a small box attached, and the shorter, top blade usually has a lid for the box. Small feet may be affixed to the lower blade and to the handles thus supporting the instrument when not in use. Used to remove partially burned wick (snuff) from a candle, and consequently to increase the brilliance of the flame, to stop the candle from smoking.The lid serves to press the snuff into the box and to seal the box so that the charred wick remnants do not scatter. The point of the longer blade is used to straighten a wick end to permit trimming and to remove candle stubs from sockets.

A self-supporting column of solid combustible fuel, such as tallow, stearine, spermaceti, beeswax, or, more commonly, paraffin wax, with an internal wick. Generally long and slender, it is made either by dipping or by casting in a mould. Used for illumination and sometimes for decorative purposes. It is often used for emergency lighting.

The metal part of the lamp that is screwed into the collar of the font. It usually consists of a circular base which is typically perforated for air intake and which has a dome-shaped body rising from the center with a narrow slit on top through which a wick is fed and through which the flame emerges. The wick is generally attached to a shaft which passes through the base and ends in a thumb wheel at the side. Several prongs or a collar-type holder may extend upwards from the base. Some types have more than one central dome to support multiple wicks. Used to draw and guide the wick from the font to position it in such a manner as to supply a sufficient amount of light as required. The intensity of light can be increased or decreased by adjusting the position of the wick with the thumb wheel. Also used to support the lamp chimney.
A slightly cupped glass, plastic, or metal collar that fits tightly around the base of a candle. Used on the socket of a candle holder to catch the wax drippings of a candle.
Objects originally created to hold or support an unshielded exposed flame.  Shielded forms of illumination are included in  Lighting Devices.

A metal or wood device consisting of two thin, slightly diverging arms that are pivoted together or joined by a spring mechanism. It may rest on a table or on the floor, or be affixed to a wall. Used to hold a burning splint or a piece of resinous wood for illuminating dark areas.

An iron support resembling a pair of pincers, in which one arm is usually straight and fixed upright in a base of iron, wood or cork, or supported on iron feet, while the other arm, often U- or L-shaped, is movable and generally terminates in a counterweight that serves to hold the pincers closed. Springed blades sometimes replace the pincers. Some types have an auxiliary socket which is generally assumed to be a candle holder. Placed on a table or on the floor, used to hold a rushlight, generally at an angle for optimal burning and minimal dripping.

A metal basket or vessel that is fixed to or hooked from the end of a long handle or pole. Used to light up a street, a public area, or a garden. The basket holds coals, charcoal, or other burning illuminants.

An ornamental, usually branched candlestick for more than one candle, supported by a base or wall bracket, usually having elaborate decorations, such as garlands or glass prisms. Used generally in pairs for interior illumination and decoration, often during festive occasions.

Objects originally created to shield and protect a burning substance such as oil, or that are connected to an energy source such as electricity.  Lighting devices may be free-standing, portable, or fixed in place.  Exposed forms of illumination are included in Lighting Holders.

A device resembling a small searchlight with an adjustable reflector and typically with an incandescent or arc light mounted on an adjustable bracket. Used to direct a narrow intense beam of light on a small area, such as a stage.

A device consisting of a single light source and a reflector that are mounted on a swivel mechanism. Used to illuminate a particular area by producing a powerful beam of light by concentrating the light rays directed towards a chosen focus.

A usually portable device consisting of a metal, or sometimes wooden, framework case, which may be cylindrical, semi-circular, or have three or more sides that are panels of glass, horn pane, or other transparent or translucent material. The framework may also include a hinged door and the base contains a cylindrical fixture for holding a candle or a burner unit. The top has a ring or bail-type handle, or a hook. Typically used outdoors to illuminate dark areas. It is also used to carry and protect the light source from the elements. It is also used to illuminate the interior or outbuildings (a barn, a garage or a stable).

A device of various shapes and sizes that may be made of wood, glass, metal, or other materials, and that is powered by different fuels. The main parts of the liquid or gas device may include a base, a font, a burner, a wick, a wick tube, one or more reflectors, a chimney, and a shade. The electric device has a base or a stand, a stem which supports a light socket and a bulb. Usually used indoors to produce artificial light in order to illuminate dark areas. It is sometimes used to provide heat.

A usually metal or tin plated wall support with a mounting hole pierced in the back. Simple varieties generally consist of a reflective, parabolic back supported on a usually semicircular, rimmed base with a candle socket and sometimes a glass globe. More elaborate types generally consist of one or more decorative arms fitted with candle sockets and mounted on an ornamental wall bracket. Used to hold a candle or a lamp on a wall for interior illumination.

A device which is suspended from the ceiling and which consists of two or more, usually upward-curving branches extending around a central axis for supporting lights, often decorated with glass, porcelain, or metal pearl garlands. Used to illuminate a room, such as a dining room or a parlor, or an entrance.

Objects originally created to be placed in or around a building for the convenience of people to enhance, complement, or facilitate the maintenance of their environment.  This class includes: small furnishings, such as card receivers; non-furniture objects used for storage and display, such as boxes; and objects that protect furniture such as antimacassars.  This class does not include furnishings intended primarily to communicate; they are classified as Art.  Nor does this class include devices used in productive housekeeping activity such as cooking or maintenance. Curtains are included in Window & Door Coverings.

Household accessories that do not meet the definitions of this class’s other sub-classes.  This sub-class includes objects used to control pests, dispense fragrance, and facilitate certain activities in the home such as tightening rope beds.  This sub-class does not include objects listed in such classes and sub-classes as Toilet Articles, Maintenance T&E, Regulative & Protective T&E, Art, and Holiday Objects.
A circular pan, usually made of copper, with a pierced lid and a long wooden or metal handle. Placed between the bedsheets, used to hold hot coals in order to warm up a bed.

A hinged seat, usually with a cover, attached to the rim of a toilet bowl or to the surrounding cabinetwork. It is typically made of wood or plastic and is either oval, circular, or semi-circular. Used to support a person on the toilet.

A sharp-edged metal plate or bar with the edge set upward in a small frame. It is usually fixed to the door-step. Used to remove mud or snow from the bottom of shoes or boots before entering a building.

A heavy weight placed on the floor next to the door. Usually made of iron or lead, it is found in various designs and is sometimes partly covered with rubber. Used to hold a door open at a particular angle.

A small jar with a delicately perforated cover, sometimes to form a design. It is usually made of porcelain or pottery, and is made in a variety of decorative styles. Used to hold dry flower petals mixed with spices (potpourri) for their perfume qualities in order to scent a room or a cupboard.
A vase-like container made of variety of material and often fitted with a pierced cover. It is usually decorated.  Used to burn aromatic pastilles or liquid perfume for scenting room.
A small bowl made from a variety of materials and often fitted with a pierced cover. It is usually decorated. Used to burn incense for scenting a room.

A device, often consisting of a wire or a glass globe, with a conical base that has a small opening for flies. Sugar, syrup, or honey is often placed inside to attract flies. Used to catch and eliminate flies.

A strip of paper coated with a sticky, sweet and poisonous substance and rolled into a cardboard tube. It is usually tacked to the ceiling. When unrolled, the paper is used to catch and to kill flies. The flies stick to the paper and eventually die.

A small usually metal fan typically consisting of a base with a shaft to which two arms, with a blade at each end, are attached, and which is operated by a clockwork mechanism. Used to keep flies away.

A round plate of the same diameter or slightly larger than a flue and fitted with straps or springs, which allow temporary attachment to it. It can be made of various materials, such as cast iron, galvanized sheet iron, or stamped tin. Used to cover a flue hole when the flue is not in use or to stop the smoke and soot from entering a room when the flue is in use.

A device made from metal or wood with extended arms to grasp the heel of a boot and with either a hook or a notched front forming a V. It may also have hand grips or be permanently standing. It is often decorated. It is often found just inside the main door. Used to pull a boot loose from the foot.

Objects, too small to be considered furniture, originally created to store or display such items as small furnishings, articles of clothing, works of art, and household linens either on walls, floors, or horizontal surfaces such as tables.  Large or more substantial storage and display pieces are included in Storage & Display Furniture.  Other storage objects are included in Food Preparation Accessories, Toilet Articles, and other classes featuring the objects they contain.
A small, decorative tray of various shapes, generally made of metal, ceramic, or glass, which is usually placed on a piece of furniture, such as a dresser or commode. Used to hold toilet articles.

A decorative tray or plate, usually made of silver or metal and varying greatly in design. It may be occasionally mounted on one or more feet. Placed in the entrance hall, used to hold and bring greeting, business, and calling cards.

A wall-mounted container found in a variety of materials with a lid and sometimes with a striking surface. It is also designed so that it can contain matches of variable sizes. Used to hold and to store matches. Also used to light matches.
A wooden or iron rack, usually decorative and open-worked, consisting of two or more tiered shelves that rest on legs. Used indoors or outdoors to hold and display plants.

A rack consisting of a wooden box or frame that is pegged or carved with notches either at the top and bottom or at the sides. It is usually mounted on the wall and may have a locking mechanism. Used for the vertical or horizontal storage of one or more small arms.
A rack consisting of a wooden or metal board, fitted with several pegs or hooks, which is hung on a wall. Used for hanging and temporarily storing coats, cloaks, hats, and rain gear.

A small, dome-shaped, usually glass jar that widens at the lip. It usually has two parts: a cover topped by a finial handle and a separate base. Used to cover and to protect plants and objects from dust or damage. Also used for display.

A tall wooden, container which tapers at the bottom. It usually has a hinged lid, which is on a slant, and has a higher back panel that may be decoratively carved and have a hole for hanging. It is often found near the fireplace. Used for holding spills in order to light a fire and to convey the flame from the hearth to lamps, candles, etc.

A portable box made of strong materials, such as iron or steel, with a removable or hinged lid, usually with handles, and a locking mechanism. It is often fitted with fixed or removable compartments on the inside. Used to store money and valuables.
A cylindrical, or rectangular, metal or wooden box usually with a hinged or sliding lid. It may sometimes be mounted on a wall. Used to store candles.

A rectangular, carved box usually made of oak about the size of a Bible. It sometimes has a hinged sloping lid and may have a locking mechanism. Used to hold a Bible on a chest or table. When closed, it may also be used as a reading stand to support a book.

Objects originally created to hold living plants, cut specimens, or bulbs in the home.  Horticultural containers can be purely functional or serve in a decorative capacity, either as the original container or as a vessel used to conceal the original container.

A receptacle found in various patterns and materials, usually rounded and deeper than it is wide. It can be very decorative. Usually placed on a piece of furniture in the living room or dining room. Used to hold fresh or dried flowers and also used for decoration.

A large ornamental pot or stand often made of porcelain or faience, but sometimes of metal, wood, or basketry. It usually has a flared top. It may have a pedestal or small legs. Used indoors or outdoors to hold and display growing plants.

A round and often conical pot with a draining hole in the centre of its base. Found in various patterns, it is made of earthenware or plastic with a tray made of the same material beneath it. Used to contain earth in which plants are grown or displayed.
A small perforated earthenware, metal or glass container designed to fit in a flower bowl or a flowerpot. Used to hold flowers upright.
A round pot or jar, sometimes with handles, made from a variety of materials. Used to hold and hide a common flowerpot.
A low, wide, often earthenware or glass bowl found in a variety of designs. Used as a vase to hold fresh flowers. It is usually used with a frog.

Objects originally created as a protective and often decorative cover for furniture.  This sub-class does not include bedcovers, which are included in Bedding, or tablecloths, which are included in Food Service Accessories.
A large piece of fabric, with various designs and usually decorated with fringed borders. Used to cover and protect furniture. It is also used for decoration and often for warmth.

A throw typically made of chenille, plush, velvet, or tapestry, that is the size of a table or slightly larger. It may sometimes be embroidered and have a fringe on the sides. Used to cover and decorate a table.
A usually very long, rectangular, and decorative piece of cloth made of various materials with crocheted edges or fringes. Used to decorate and protect a piano from dirt and dust.
An oblong and decorative piece of cloth made of various materials, with crocheted edges or fringes. Used to cover and protect a dresser or the like.
A long, narrow strip of linen, embroidery, or lace. Used to protect and cover the furniture. Also used as decoration.
A removable mat found in a variety of fabrics, shapes, and patterns that is generally embroidered. Used under vases or dishes to protect the table from wear. Also used for decoration.

A small, decorative mat made of lace, crocheted fabric, plastic, or paper. It is usually placed under such objects as a vase or a flowerpot. Used to protect an underlying surface, such as a table. Also used for decoration.

A loose removable cloth or plastic cover, found in various patterns and materials, and designed to fit furniture. It is sometimes fitted with a fastening. Used to cover and protect furniture, especially from dust or from fading. Also used for decoration.

A crocheted or knitted doily placed on the arms or headrest of upholstered chairs and sofas. Used to protect upholstered furniture from Macassar oil or other hair preparations. Also used as decoration.

Objects originally created primarily for decorative purposes.  Decorative articles may have a secondary functional use, such as a plate, but their intended use is for display.  Decorative ornaments used for special occasions are included in Holiday Objects and Party Accessories.   Note: Terms from Art also may be used, as appropriate.

A usually covered vessel of various forms, such as a vase, and materials, usually fitted with a narrow base leading to a foot or a pedestal and sometimes with handles. Used as an ornament for display.

Objects originally created to hold tobacco or smoking equipment or to serve as receptacles for tobacco-related waste such as ashes.  Objects used by individuals to store smoking-related items on their persons are included in Personal Gear.

A covered rectangular, oval or oblong container with chamfered corners. Made from various materials, it may have a cork lining and is often engraved or chased. Used to store and keep tobacco moist, fresh and out of the light.
A rectangular covered box made from various materials and in different sizes. It is usually displayed on a table or a desk. Used to hold and store cigarettes.

A stand consisting of a typically rectangular tray that may be set on legs and that is fitted with various racks, pans, and containers. Used to hold the various accessories that makes up a smoker’s kit (such as pipes, matches, ashtrays, etc.).

Objects originally created to answer the physical requirements and comforts of people in their living and work spaces.  This class includes desks, tables, beds, chairs, and outdoor furniture, but it excludes appliances and tools such as washing machines and ladders.
Objects that do not meet the definitions of this class’s other sub-classes.  This sub-class includes such objects as mirrors or screens.

A piece of furnishing consisting of a flat piece of polished metal or glass which is coated with metal film to reflect light. It can be any shape or size and with or without a frame. Used to view the reflection of a person or of something. It is also used as a decoration.

A mirror of various shapes which is usually set in a wooden or a metal frame. It is often hung on the chimney wall or between two windows. Used to view one’s reflection. It is also used for decoration.

A small, round, oval or rectangular framed mirror that is usually placed on a dressing-table or a chest of drawers. It is usually supported by a stand or attached to a small cabinet with drawers. Used to view one’s face when grooming.

A tall, oval or rectangular dressing mirror in a footed wooden frame. It can be moved or tilted by means of swivel screws that support it, and sometimes its height can be adjusted. May also be equipped with lighting devices fixed to either side of the frame. Used to view one’s full reflection, usually when dressing.
Objects originally created to support and sometimes store or display items without encasement, to function as steps, or to serve as horizontal surfaces for such activities as working or dining.
A piece of furniture consisting of a solid, horizontal surface supported by a number of pillars, legs, or trestles. Sometimes has drawers. Used for holding various objects, food and beverages.

A small, square or rectangular table, usually with a hinged top and with one or more drawers containing fitted compartments. It usually has a cloth bag or pouch, or a small basket suspended below. It may have a drop leaf section on either side. Used as a work area when sewing. It is also used to store the work in progress, sewing notions, and other sewing equipment.

A large and wide table with thick legs and with several compartments under or on top of the table top that are covered by a number of small doors. It is usually placed in the vestry. Used to store various pieces of vestments worn by priests and other church officials.

A small, low table designed to stand against a wall between two windows and beneath a pier glass. It is supported by one or more legs and has various styles and designs. Used to fill in the space between two windows (window pier) and to display decorative objects.

A small table that has one or two drawers or a small cupboard below the table top. It is usually the same height as a bed. Used, often in pairs, next to a bed to store and hold a toilet utensil and various objects.

A table that consists of a set of wide shelves that are sometimes flanked by drawers or cabinets. It may have a rolling wheel base and is usually placed at the side of a dining table or against a wall in a dining room. Used to carry and serve a variety of food and beverages, as well as articles of table service, such as dishes and cutlery.

A rectangular or circular table with a carved or inlaid game-board table top, or with a hinged and folding table top that is usually covered with felt or baize and that opens out flat. The table top can be lifted up to reveal a series of small compartments. It is often decorative and the edges may be enhanced by inlays or carvings. Used as a surface on which to play games (backgammon, cards, chess).

A table with a built-in arrangement of various sets of drawers and compartments of different sizes and with an attached mirror. It may sometimes have a marbled top. Used to store and to hold various toiletry objects and accessories.
A large table that is usually found in the middle of a room, usually a living room. It is found in various styles and designs. Used as an all-purpose table to display various decorative objects.

A folding table or pedestal table that rests on three or four feet and usually has a hinged and rotating lid which opens to reveal a shallow felt or paper compartment. It may have holes carved into the surface. Used as a game table but specifically used for card games with one or more players. Also used to store cards, poker chips, etc.

A set of two or more low, generally wooden steps, usually enclosed in panels and upholstered. Used for climbing into high beds. It was often a multipurpose piece of furniture and concealed certain nighttime necessities, such as the chamber pot.

A stand consisting of one or two shelves that rest on tall legs. It is designed to hold a washbasin and a pitcher. It has a raised back piece and sides and may have a towel rack and an attached mirror. Placed in the bedroom, used to hold toilet accessories for washing one’s hands and face. It is also used to hold other toilet articles, such as soap, towels, etc.

A stand consisting one or more shelves or drawers that rests on a three- or four-footed pedestal. It usually has a small, adjustable mirror attached. Used by men to hold and store shaving supplies and other toilet articles, as well as to look at one’s face in the mirror when shaving.

A round or square table-like stand that is tall, slender, and upright and usually made of wood. It may have a columnar support or may rest on three or four feet. It is sometimes decorated. Used to hold and display plants, lamps, sculptures, and other objects.
An upright metal framework with several pairs of horizontal slide rails and stops fixed to the sides and wheels at the bottom. Used to hold one or more cooling racks or trays.

A tall, folding stand consisting of an upright frame with a ledge across the middle. Made of wood or iron, it may have a mechanism to adjust its height and inclination, and usually rests on three legs. Used to hold or to display a picture or a painting at a desired angle.

Objects originally created to store, protect, and sometimes display items by means of an encasement with such features as shelves, drawers, cubbyholes, and doors.  This sub-class does not include furniture created to store food, which is listed in Food Storage Equipment.

A tall, upright, wide, and massively built wooden piece of case furniture consisting of a set of heavy panels that form a large hanging space, which is enclosed by front doors that often have decorative elements. Sometimes may have shelves or drawers. Used to store and hang various pieces of clothing, especially suits and dresses.

A wooden piece of case furniture with sometimes a mirror, shelves, drawers, a , a cupboard, or compartments beneath its table top. Placed in dining room, used to store various cutlery, dishes, and other articles of table service.

A sturdy box or chest, usually made of iron or steel, with a locking mechanism. It has various sizes and designs and is sometimes equipped with carrying handles. Used to securely store money or other valuables for protection against fire or theft.

A piece of furniture consisting of a set of tiered wooden shelves, sometimes with small drawers, either free-standing or forming a light unit on top of another piece of furniture. It may have a mirrored back. Used to store or display books, ornaments, and various small objects.

A wooden table or frame with a horizontal surface, drawers and small, open compartments underneath, sometimes a locking mechanism, and usually an empty space in the middle for a chair to fit. The horizontal surface is used for reading and writing while the drawers or the compartments are used for storing papers, books, etc.

A flat-topped table which is often inset with a panel of leather and has an under portion fitted with one or more drawers. It rests on four or more legs. It has various styles and designs. Used as a writing surface. Also used to store a variety of writing materials, such as ink bottles, pens, and writing paper.

A wooden writing cabinet mounted on a chest of drawers or on a stand. It usually has a hinged, a locking mechanism and sometimes slanted, front that drops down to form a writing surface. Generally, it has drawers and pigeonholes. The drawers and pigeonholes are used to store papers, documents, etc. When the front is dropped down, the horizontal surface is used for reading and writing.

A wooden desk or a long table for one or more students, usually supported by an iron base and legs. It may have a slanted, hinged top portion which reveals a book box or shelf underneath. There is usually a receptacle in one corner for an ink bottle and a hinged seat may be attached to the front.  Used as a writing or reading surface and for storing books and school supplies.

A desk that has a top portion with a semi-circular or curved cover, called a roll-top, made of thin strips of wood glued to a flexible backing, which slides open to reveal a writing surface. Used as a writing and reading surface when the cover is rolled up. When the cover is rolled down, the inside part is used to hide things from view.

A desk with a locking mechanism and a vertical wooden slab which folds down to form a writing surface and which is held horizontal by chains or metal hinges or with pull-out bars. Used as a reading and writing surface when the slab is folded down and for storing personal objects or papers when closed.

A desk with four legs and with an inwardly slanted lid that is supported by arms, lopers or chains. The lid can be opened perpendicularly revealing a large compartment which may have a small drawer below it. Used as a reading and writing surface when the lid is down. The compartment is used for storing books and papers.

A wooden piece of case furniture, either fixed or movable, fitted with shelves and generally enclosed by hinged and sometimes glass doors. Used to store, and sometimes to display dishes, cups, and other tableware.

A wooden piece of furniture consisting of a receptacle, sometimes with a metal lined bottom; equipped with one or more drain holes and set on a frame or cupboard and with feet. It is not connected to a water system supply. Used to hold produce or to wash dishes.
A two-tiered wooden cupboard. The lower tier is fitted either with drawers, compartments, or shelves. The upper tier is enclosed by hinged doors. Used to store clothing and linens.
A small cupboard that is affixed to a wall without floor support or is placed on top of another piece of furniture. Used to store and sometimes to display dishes, cups, and other tableware.

A counter, typically made of wood, that is usually straight, but that may also be L or U shaped, that has cupboard space and drawers below, and that  sometimes has bar rails. The top is used as a table on which to serve liquor and other beverages, and sometimes to serve light meals, and the cupboard space and drawers are used for storage.

A wooden piece of case furniture that consists of a frame and a set of wide drawers. It is usually mounted on short legs or feet and usually contains four drawers. It may sometimes have an attached mirror. Placed in the bedroom, used to hold and store clothing and household linens.

A combination piece of furniture containing a wardrobe on one side and a chest of drawers on the other. Sometimes it has an attached mirror. It is usually found in the bedroom or in the hallway. Used to store clothing and jewelry.

A large, rectangular, and usually wooden box with a metal hinged lid and sometimes with a lock. It may be set on short feet and is often decoratively carved or painted. Used as a receptacle for storing clothes, linens, fabrics, wall hangings, and other possessions, or for the safekeeping of treasures or valuables. It may also serve as a travelling box for carrying these possessions on a journey. It is sometimes used as a seat, a table, or a sleeping area for a child.

A small, rectangular, square, or polygonal box, usually wooden, with a lid and a lock, divided with partitions. It may have side handles for carrying. Used to store wine and liquor bottles, decanters and glasses.

A square or rectangular, low, ornamented, and open-topped music rack with slatted partitions. It is usually made of mahogany, bamboo, or papier mâché and rests on four short legs. Sometimes it has one or two small drawers below the partitions. It is usually placed by a piano. Used to hold sheet music, music books, and loose papers.

A wooden piece of case furniture consisting of a set of small drawers and/or one or more compartments, generally fronted by one or more hinged or sliding doors. Varying in size and style, it usually rests on a stand, a lower cupboard section or on a chest of drawers. Placed in the kitchen or the dining room, used to store dishes, cups, and other tableware. Sometimes used to display small, precious objects.

A wooden piece of case furniture that is affixed to a wall, consisting of one or more compartments, generally fronted by one or more hinged or sliding doors and sometimes a small drawer. Used for storing valuables or for displaying porcelain, china, and other small, precious objects.
A tall, upright wooden or metal, sometimes cardboard cabinet with many drawers and divisions, and sometimes doors. Used for filing or storing documents.

A large rectangular cabinet that has an upper tier with glazed doors and an interior fitted with shelves. Placed in the living room, used to store and display fine ceramics, porcelains, or precious objects.
Objects originally created to allow one or more persons to lay down or recline.  Component parts of beds such as headboards and footboards are also included in this sub-class.
A long seat that is either upholstered or supplied with cushions, backless or with half a back, and usually with a headrest or arm at one end. Used for reclining or sitting.

A piece of furniture of various sizes and styles in the form of a wooden or iron framework that is composed of a flat horizontal surface supported by four vertical legs. It may have side rails, and a footboard and headboard that may sometimes have posts attached to it. The flat surface is often a mattress or bedding held up by cross bars, straps or springs, but it may also be a solid plane. Used as a surface on which to sleep, recline, and rest.

A portable bed with hinged side rails that enable the main part to be folded up against the head rail. The main frame has four supporting legs with additional folding supports at each end of the frame. Used as an extra bed, a surface on which to sleep, recline, and rest.

A small bed, sometimes with sliding side-rails and plain or decorative panels. the legs may have casters. Used by a child as a surface on which to sleep, recline, and rest. The side-rails and panels protect a child from falling or climbing down.

A baby’s bed that usually oscillates on rockers or swings on pivots. It is either a box or a crib, sometimes with a shaped hood, mounted on a rocker at each end or slung from a frame. Used by a baby for sleeping. It is also used to rock a baby to sleep.

Objects originally created to allow one or more persons to sit upon or support a portion of their body, as in the case of footstools.  Seating furniture includes both indoor and outdoor furniture and may be stationary pieces such as slipper chairs or allow for some movement such as rocking chairs.  This class includes upright furniture that adjusts to a reclining position, but non-adjustable furniture that is designed for reclining is included in Sleeping & Reclining Furniture.
A single narrow wooden seat supported by three or four legs. It has no back or arms. Used to seat one person.
A solid round, square, or rectangular stool supported by a set of three short legs. May have a leather carrying strap. Used to sit on when milking a cow.

A low square, rectangular, or round stool, usually made of wood and resting on four feet. Sometimes it has a hinged top or removable lid revealing a small receptacle. It can also be partially or entirely upholstered and may even team with a chair. Used to support the feet of a person sitting on a chair. It is also used as a storage bin.

A low, heavily upholstered seat that is usually rectangular in shape. It generally has no arms or back fixed to the main part of it. (In French furnishings, the "ottomane" has a back which curves around to the sides to form arms.) Used to seat one or more persons.
A long upholstered seat with a cushion back and two arms or raised ends. Placed in a living room, it is used to seat three or more people.
A long, wide seat with an open or upholstered back and usually arms. It may be made of wood or cane, or it may be fabric-covered. Used to seat two or more people.
A large chair or small sofa just wide enough for two people. Placed in a living room, boudoir or smoking room, it is used to seat two people side by side.

An upholstered sofa that can be converted into a bed, either by folding out the seat or by lowering its hinged back into a horizontal position. Used as a surface on which to sit, sleep, recline, and rest.

A movable seat with a back and with or without arms. It is generally made of wood, usually has four legs for support and sometimes has an upholstered seat and back. (In French, the term chaise represents a seat without arms.) Used to seat one person.

A chair that is mounted on two curved strips of wood (called rockers or bends) which connect the front and back legs, allowing it to be rocked backward and forward. It usually has a high, straight, or slightly curved back and often open arms. Used for comfortable sitting or relaxing while rocking.

A wooden chair, sometimes with arms, with a solid seat, and usually with a high back, that was often elaborately carved. A common motif carved into the back is a family crest. Used as a show chair to add style to the halls and corridors and to seat one person.

A chair, sometimes with arms and a light, folding wooden frame, sometimes with crossed stretchers. The seat and back are usually made of wood, canvas, carpet, or leather. It can be collapsed flat for easy storage or transport. Used as an extra chair to seat one person.
A chair, with or without arms, designed to hold a toilet utensil, such as a basin or a chamber pot, under an open seat, sometimes with a fitted lid. Used to sit on while urinating or defecating.

A chair with arms and very long legs. It sometimes has a footrest and usually has a drop front feeding or removable tray. Used to seat a child during meals and to raise him or her to a level convenient for feeding.

A chair with arms to which a large round, oval, square, or rectangular back is attached by hinges. The back can be pulled down to rest on the arms, converting it into a table. It may sometimes have a drawer beneath the seat. Used as a chair for sitting when the back is lifted up or as table when the back is pulled down.

A large, low-seated, high-backed, and usually heavily upholstered or padded chair with arms. It typically has a deep seat. Upholstery materials often include velvet, tapestry, leather, and panels of oriental carpeting. It is flanked by wings or lugs to give protection from draughts. Placed in a bedroom or living room, used for comfortable lounging and relaxing.
A chair with arms and usually with an upholstered seat and back. Used for sitting.

A long, narrow, and usually wooden seat, with or without a back or arm rests, made to accommodate several persons. It is supported by various legs and stretchers. Used as a surface on which to sit. It is often accompanied by a table or is placed along a wall.

A short bench or settee on rockers with a detachable fence that forms a cradle bed across two-thirds of its length. Used by a mother or a babysitter to rock or lull an infant to sleep, usually while doing some type of work , such as knitting. A baby lies in the bed without rolling off and the mother or babysitter sits beside it.
A bench or stand with shelves and sometimes shallow drawers placed near the kitchen entry.  Used as a repository for water buckets or milk pails.

Matched groupings of objects originally created to meet the basic furniture needs of a specific area such as a nursery or bedroom.  Note: Other terms also may be used to represent specific set components from other Furniture sub-classes, e.g., Seating Furniture, Support Furniture.

A set of matched furniture, usually comprised of the basic pieces necessary for the bedroom. For example: a bed, a chest of drawers, a chair, a night table, a washstand, etc. Used to furnish a bedroom.

Objects originally created as portable or temporary coverings for indoor or outdoor floors.  This class includes rugs and carpeting but not permanently attached tile or linoleum, which are included in Building Components.

A long, narrow, and rectangular-shaped rug. Used in high traffic areas, such as in hallways and foyers, to protect the floor below, to reduce noise, and to provide warmth from the cold floor. It can also be used on stairs, where it is held in place by stair rods.

A covering made of cotton, wool, hemp, silk, or synthetics that are woven, crocheted, knitted, felted, pieced, or braided. It is usually rectangular in shape, but may also be round, oval, or octagonal. The edges may be hemmed, bound, overcast, fringed, or left as selvages. It is designed to cover a portion of the floor. Used to protect and decorate the floor.

A usually decorative covering in the form of a small rug usually a rectangular or oval. Placed randomly on the floor, such as by the bedside, used to cover, protect, and decorate the floor, and to provide warmth.

A rug made of animal skin, such as bear or goat, which may have a felt or woven fabric backing and a decorative, often pinkfelt trim. It may follow the shape of the animal or may be cut into more traditional shapes, such as a rectangle or oval. Used to cover and decorate the floor, and to provide warmth and comfort in small areas of the floor, such as in the front of a fireplace, by a bedside.

A covering made as a yardage or yard goods of woven or felted fabrics that are composed of wool, cotton, hemp, straw, or synthetic fibres. Sections may be sewn together. Fastened to the floor, it is used to cover the floor of a room completely from wall to wall. It is also used to protect it, to provide warmth, and for decorative purposes.

A flat covering usually made of coarse materials, such as straw, hemp, coir, rushes, reeds, or grasses, which are woven or braided, usually into a rectangle or an oval. Used outside or inside to protect the floor or the rug below from dirt on feet, boots, or shoes. It may also be used for decorative purposes.
A small mat. Used outside or inside a door to wipe dirt from shoes or boots. When placed inside, it is also used to protect the floor.

A covering consisting of a sturdy, large cloth of burlap, canvas, or sail cloth. It is varnished, oiled, and painted or printed with designs, such as geometric patterns and motifs of flowers. Fastened down to the floor, it is used to cover and protect the floor of a room in order to protect it and to provide an easy to clean surface. It is for decoration.
Objects originally created to define space for human activities or to be used as components of space-defining objects.

Objects originally created to provide or define a space for human activities.  Structures may be permanent, portable, climate-controlled, or open-air, and can be used for a variety of purposes including ceremonial, agricultural, recreational, commercial, cultural, civic, industrial, and social.  Architectural samples integral to buildings such as wall sections, as well as separable, distinct, and interchangeable components, such as doorknobs or window sashes, are included in Building Components.
Structures that do not meet the definitions of this class’s other sub-classes.

A portable shelter or temporary collapsible structure consisting of fabric or animal skins stretched over and supported by poles and usually secured by stades hammered into the ground. Used as a temporary shelter to protect people and goods from the elements, during outdoor camping, for example.

Structures and complexes originally created to facilitate the transportation of people and things.  Such structures provide embarkation and debarkation points, allow passage from one point to another, house conveyance equipment, or serve as collection facilities for fares or tolls.

Buildings originally created for specific domestic activities such as baking or washing or for the storage of residential equipment and materials needed for domestic activities.  Outbuildings are generally secondary structures adjacent to or nearby a dwelling or farm complex.

A roofed structure that is often closed at some of its sides or ends. It is usually built of wood and can be of different sizes and shapes and often with a sloping roof. Used for storage and/or as a shelter for equipment, vehicles, and materials.
Buildings originally created for such institutional purposes as health and welfare services, educational instruction, or corrections.
Structures and complexes originally created for the extraction and processing of raw materials, the generation of power, the manufacture of goods, or the housing of industrial machinery.
Structures originally created to collect, convey, regulate, or contain water for distribution, flood control, or power generation.

A valve consisting of a solid gate of wood or of metal which can move vertically by means of a windlass, a flume, or a through in a waterway. Used to regulate the flow of water in a ground level channel.

Residential structures originally created for long-term habitation rather than temporary housing.  Dwellings are considered homes, places where domestic activities are conducted and personal effects are stored.

A structure built in many different shapes and sizes of a number of different materials, including concrete, wood, brick, metal, and stone. Most types have a foundation, a roof, walls, one or more floors, doors and windows providing access to people and allowing light and air to enter. Used as a dwelling for humans.

A round or oval hut, usually with an arched top, consisting of a pole framework that is overlaid with animal skins, bark, or grass mats. It is easily disassembled and transported. Used as a dwelling for people and a shelter for goods by some North American Indigenous groups.

Structures originally created for such defensive purposes as storing armament and munitions, sheltering personnel, or providing fortified observational posts capable of facilitating or resisting attacks.

A narrow structure, usually made of wood that has the general shape of a hut or a cabin, sometimes equipped with viewpoint and is placed at the entry of a site. Used to shelter a sentinel on guard duty.

Structures originally created for cultural or recreational activities. Included in this sub-class are structures that provide exhibition space for music, fine arts, dance, drama, or collections of objects, flora, or fauna displayed for public benefit.  Also included are structures that provide space for sporting or entertainment activities, usually for groups and occasionally for individuals.

Structures originally created for the selling, exchanging, or housing of goods and services.  This sub-class includes service industry-related structures, financial institutions, eating and drinking establishments, and mercantile buildings.

Structures originally created to be used by governmental entities or community organizations for such purposes as governance activities, mail distribution, public safety, or social activities.  This sub-class also includes structures used by trade, fraternal, professional, or special-interest groups or associations for such organizational purposes as conducting meetings or ceremonies or housing group-related objects such as regalia or records.

Structures originally created for ceremonial activities such as conducting religious services or preparing or housing the remains of the dead.  Such structures may also provide space for devotional activities, such as those associated with holy objects, or offer shelter for transformative practices or traditional rituals such as tea ceremonies.
